DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1997 RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rising to speak on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1997. It is a complex issue but I would like to start by saying that retirement savings accounts are promoted as choice. We believe they are not choice; they are effectively the same thing as other superannuation vehicles—that is, a requirement that workers reduce their disposable income in an effort to ensure that government can in the future reduce its obligation in respect of older people. It is a further step in the dismantling of the universal pension. That step began under Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that retirement savings accounts are different from other vehicles for obligatory self‐funded retirement investment, they are different because they send this obligatory income reduction to banks rather than to other financial institutions. They are also different in that in most superannuation funds the investments are under at least some minimal control of some group at least theoretically representing the contributors. RSAs, retirement savings accounts, represent investment that is not transparent and which is determined by banks.

This is then a rather transparent attempt to curry favour with banks by giving them a cut in the large $260 billion pool of superannuation funds, a pool that is growing at a rate of $25 billion to $30 billion a year. Banks are increasingly large transnational organisations. Investment in the banking sector is open to international players now. Increasingly, even those banks whose character is presented as `Australian' have substantial investments, including ownership of banks abroad.

Ownership of foreign banks often entails a management structure where foreign interests are directly represented and funds are freely transferred and invested in any nation and assets collected in this nation may be lent in any nation. The interests of management in such banks may be totally divorced from the interests of Australia, Australian investors, Australian industry or the Australian economy.

Alternatively, superannuation companies are also large concentrations of capital but still predominantly national in nature. Even so, it is a concern to the Greens (WA) that superannuation funds are increasingly investing in large corporations and increasingly investing overseas. This goes with the computer formula for investment.

An important difference is that, with superannuation funds, the fund members have put some input into the investment regime of most funds, even if that is through representatives on fund management committees. With RSAs the banks have complete discretion as to the investment of RSA contributor funds. Any control lies solely in the decision to contribute to an RSA.

Another more basic issue lies with disclosure of investment and investment strategy where complying superannuation funds are required under the SIS regulations 2.29 and 4.09 to provide information about investments and investment strategies to members. Senator Sherry would certainly remember that this was a commitment that he agreed to in a debate about three years ago in relation to superannuation funds, that people should have the right to know where their portfolios are invested in superannuation.

RSAs seem to have no equivalent requirement. Not only do people have no power over their investment, they may find it difficult to determine the nature of those investments. It is therefore of concern when the main report, on page 49, seems to perceive disclosure issues as relating solely to fees, charges, rates of return and such issues outlined under 3.64. The Democrats, on page 62 of the committee report on this bill, welcome the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) that disclosure regulations for RSAs will be `quite similar' to those of superannuation funds. Given the lack of disclosure for compulsory funds, and the fact that under section 51 of the act RSA membership may be effectively compulsory, I am not so reassured.

In many respects, if compulsory savings programs along the lines of RSAs are the choice of parliament, we would prefer to see perhaps credit unions used as a vehicle, since depositors are voting members. There are effective size limits and some means at least of regional control, and investment patterns by credit unions tend to direct capital to small and medium, locally and regionally owned businesses which provide the majority of employment.

It has been a continual call from the Greens to assure a greater level of choice in obligatory retirement savings schemes. However, the focus of choice is not on which financial institutions can make similar investments but on the choice of investment targets.

Particularly, we support options which support the Australian economy and employment within an ethical context. We have several times pursued options within superannuation funds for: investment in locally or regionally owned small or medium business; ecologically sustainable investment; non‐military oriented peaceful investment; and investment that does not exploit people from developing nations.

There has also been a call from the Greens to recognise that obligatory investment programs such as compulsory superannuation or RSAs are not necessarily the best investment vehicle for workers, and that investment in such things as a small business or a home may provide more substantial and far‐reaching benefits. This goes beyond the direct benefits as financial investments and recognises that there may be substantial and ongoing human benefits in terms of use value of such investments and, in the case of investment in small business, in ensuring the capacity of older people to continue working.

Earlier this year, there was a major uproar over the requirement that unemployed people over 55 utilise superannuation assets before being eligible for full unemployment benefits. How can this treatment of older workers be justified at the same time as workers are being required to contribute to superannuation funds or RSAs, ostensibly for their retirement, and to increase savings?

Under legislation announced at the last budget, from September 1997, those applying for unemployment or other benefits who are above the age of 55 are given a different status from those other unemployed people and expected to utilise their savings, including superannuation savings, before becoming a burden on the taxpayers. This is normally an exempt asset for younger unemployed people. Not only are assets tested; more perniciously `deemed income' is assessed. In other words, if a superannuation fund earns real or `deemed' interest, this is counted as income, and it comes off unemployment benefits at a rate of 50c in the dollar. This utterly undermines any rhetoric in relation to savings and self‐funded retirement, showing it to be sheer hypocrisy on the part of government. The cost to savings and self‐funded retirement was predicted in the last budget as in excess of $44 million per year, taken from the superannuation of unemployed people aged 55 to 65.

RSAs are being promoted both as an increase in choice and as a means of protecting small retirement contributions made compulsorily by employers or perhaps by employees if that aspect of the Labor tax‐break promise goes ahead. Reading from the papers this morning, we have still to see what is going to happen there. Under section 51, RSA legislation can allow companies to open retirement savings accounts for employees without their consent. This effectively echoes the type of superannuation funds where membership in a specific fund is compulsory. It is not consumer choice. It just allows companies to make deals with a bank, in competition with a superannuation fund. It may mean that employees are forced to support a transnational bank instead of being forced into a certain superannuation fund. This is of particular concern, given that it has been acknowledged that retirement savings accounts are likely to provide lower returns than superannuation funds.

Under the Small Superannuation Accounts Act 1995, small accounts cannot be duplicated—there can be only one account—and notification must occur when accounts reach $1,200, when workers are advised to transfer the amounts to a real superannuation fund. Contrast this to the retirement savings accounts where notification and suggestions—not compulsions—to transfer to superannuation funds do not occur until accounts reach $10,000. Contrast this with the mechanisms allowing multiple RSAs.

The Greens (WA) are fundamentally opposed to RSAs as: unnecessary; failing to provide any significant benefit or choice; likely to create situations where workers are compelled to support RSAs; and creating an investment vehicle that is more likely to be counterproductive to the interests of the Australian economy than to provide either jobs or ecologically or socially sustainable development. Nonetheless, we support the majority of Labor and Democrat amendments as minor improvements to a bill which, from what we can see, is likely to pass with a nod from the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contributions to the debate. Quite a range of issues were raised, some of which I think are better dealt with in the committee stage. We are keen to have the bill properly and fully debated. It is an important bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill is a clear case of the government delivering on its election promises. We went to an election with a policy of allowing financial institutions such as banks, building societies and credit unions to offer retirement savings accounts for individual superannuation. RSAs are to be subject to the same retirement income and superannuation standards and will attract the same taxation benefits as traditional superannuation funds. The intention of introducing RSAs is not to replace existing superannuation funds but to complement existing arrangements by expanding the range of options open to consumers.

What has been foreshadowed by some speakers is a range of amendments which are clearly designed to undermine the attractiveness of RSAs as a superannuation product in the market. In this way, we believe that the opposition in particular is seeking to undermine the government's election commitment and, in some ways, to shore up the privileged position of superannuation funds. There were a number of statements which were made during the debate which were plain wrong and which were made with the clear and explicit purpose of justifying opposition amendments.

Let me just address a number of issues. Firstly, Senator Sherry raised the concern that employers will be able to open an RSA account on behalf of an employee and that this runs contrary to section 153 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, which requires employees to give their consent before a superannuation account can be opened by an employer.

There is no such provision in section 153 of the SIS Act. Subparagraphs 153(1)(b)(i) and 153(2) allow a standard employer sponsor of the entity, being a superannuation fund, to make an application on behalf of a person being an employee. It does not require an employee to provide consent with that application. What we are proposing is consistent with section 51 of the RSA bill. On that matter Senator Sherry was wrong.

A second concern was raised that superannuation funds should be allowed to offer RSAs and that this was an omission from the draft cabinet submission that was apparently leaked to Senator Sherry's office. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced in the budget that public offer superannuation funds will be able to offer a product similar to RSAs. However, they will still be sold under a trust structure and will be regulated under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993.

There is no need for any amendments to be made to the RSA legislation to allow for public offer superannuation funds to offer these look alike RSAs. The necessary amendments will be made to the SIS regulations and this is the appropriate legislation to provide for look alike RSAs offered by public offer superannuation funds.

A third concern raised by a number of speakers was that RSAs should be protected from any reduction in the account balance by fees, charges or taxes. The government has no intention of amending the definition of capital guarantee in the RSA bill to provide that no fees and charges can be imposed on an RSA. The complete prohibition of fees and charges on RSAs would represent unwarranted commercial interference. In addition, it would be inconsistent with both the more commonly understood meaning of capital guarantee and the existing commercial practice in respect of traditional deposit arrangements and capital guaranteed life offer superannuation products.

Another concern was raised that RSA providers should not be allowed to offer special incentives to employees in return for having their employees open an RSA. Senator Sherry in his remarks believed that this practice would result in employees being coerced into remaining in an RSA to their detriment. This practice is commonly referred to as third line forcing. It is prohibited by the Trade Practices Act 1994 and the RSA bill provides a number of options for an employee if he or she does not wish to retain benefits in an RSA which has been opened by an employer on his or her behalf. We can debate some of those additional matters during the committee stage.

Senator Sherry's fifth concern—and it is the concern of perhaps one or two others—was the need to have a series of so-called health warnings concerning the longer term impact on superannuation benefits if a person remains in an RSA due to the lower returns when compared to a traditional superannuation fund. The government has recognised the need for consumers to be informed of the possible lower returns on these products and to this end it is intended that the RSA regulations will require RSA providers to inform people about the low risk, low return nature of RSAs and that other superannuation arrangements may provide a greater return in the long term. These matters again will be discussed during the committee stage.

Senator Sherry has also raised a concern about the 14‐day cooling off period. Senator Sherry proposes that the cooling off period should be extended to 28 days. The 14‐day cooling off period is a feature of the SIS Act and the Insurance Contracts Act. Both these acts were introduced by the previous government and would appear to be acceptable to the consumer movement. The 14‐day cooling off period in the RSA bill is consistent with the equivalent provision in these acts. There does not appear to be any valid reason for making it different from these acts. Again, I make the point that this is another attempt to try to add extra burdens onto RSAs which are simply not imposed on other superannuation products in the superannuation industry.

In conclusion, these bills give effect to an election commitment. We take our election commitments seriously. We believe it is important that this bill be passed by the Senate. We believe that the bill as presented is a fair bill. It takes into account a large range of views which were expressed to the government and I urge the Senate to support the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNT BILL 1997
The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Clause 11, page 5 (line 7), after "company", insert ", complying superannuation fund".
(4) Clause 23, page 20 (line 17), after "company", insert ", complying superannuation fund".

Firstly, I stress that we are not going to in any way try to unduly prolong the debate on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill. I intend to make a number of points as briefly as I can about each of our amendments as we go.

Our amendments 1 and 4 go to the issue of any complying superannuation fund being able to offer the RSA product. It was very clear in the government's election manifesto—I will not seek to embarrass the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) by tabling it—that any complying superannuation fund would be able to offer RSAs. That is not in this legislation. We received a leaked copy of the cabinet document two weeks prior to last year's budget, and the provision that any complying superannuation fund could offer RSAs was in the cabinet recommendations. On budget night it was dropped out. We still do not know why.

The government says that superannuation funds will be able to provide RSA look‐alikes. We believe that is unacceptable. The ability for superannuation funds to offer RSA look‐alikes is contained in the regulations. Another reason why this approach is unacceptable is that we have not yet been able to view the regulations.

One of our continuing problems with respect to superannuation legislation from this government is a moving feast of both amendments and new bills and the difficulties in being able to determine in any detail, in the absence of regulations, very important aspects of superannuation legislation. This is one area where we have some concerns. We believe it is a serious problem for us to be debating these bills without regulations, or at least some idea about them. Senator Kemp has stressed competitive neutrality. How can these bills create a level playing field when one sector of industry is excluded from offering the RSA product? We would contend that, effectively, what you are doing is giving banks—there are some other financial institutions, but it is largely the banks that this legislation is benefiting—and not the traditional superannuation industry, if they so wish, the ability to offer RSAs. I certainly am aware that in some areas traditional industry will want to offer RSAs.

Those comments go to our amendments 1 and 4. I have looked at the Democrats' amendment. There is not a significant conflict in our approach. There is some relatively minor wording change, but I think we certainly are on the same track with the same principle. That is why we would urge the Senate to support our amendments; if not our amendments, the Democrats' amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Democrats will support the opposition's amendments 1 and 4. They are, as Senator Sherry has indicated, almost identical to our amendments 1 and 2.
—So do you withdraw amendments 1 and 2?

—Yes. As Senator Sherry has indicated, they will allow superannuation funds to offer RSAs. If the government is interested in a fully competitive superannuation scene, then this ought to be made available to superannuation funds along with banks, credit unions, insurance companies and the like.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the committee's attention to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, which says that several witnesses and submitters argued that existing superannuation trustees should be able to offer RSAs

and, indeed, be able to use the term `RSA' as a product description. It says that the Investment Funds of Australia argued that there was no difference between an RSA and a cash based superannuation fund. They submitted that super funds trustees should `have access to the simpler and cheaper structure that is being proposed for RSAs' and that this was a very important aspect of competitive neutrality. ASFA also argued that to do otherwise would confuse consumers and provide RSA institutions with an unfair competitive advantage. The Democrats were certainly persuaded by those arguments put during the hearing on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the contributions to the debate on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill. We are trying to keep this fairly brief. I note the offer that Senator Sherry made and the constructive approach that he has flagged in relation to this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The government will oppose the amendment which has been announced by Senator Sherry and supported by the Democrats. The government has announced that public office super funds will be able to offer RSA look‐alike products. Similar disclosure and other standards will apply for RSAs regulated under RSA regulations, and this policy will be implemented through the SIS regulations.

The policy should not be implemented through amendments to the RSA bill as the opposition and the Democrats have proposed. This is because the RSA bill deals with only non-trust based superannuation. If superannuation funds were referred to in the RSA bill, the funds would be subject to two regimes: the SIS regime and the RSA regime. They would need to lodge two annual returns, two audit certificates, to obtain approval. It would lead to increased compliance costs.

The point I am making is that we have announced that public offer super funds will be allowed to offer RSA look‐alike products. There is no argument on that score. Similar disclosure and other standards will apply for RSAs as regulated under RSA legislation. Only public offer funds can offer RSA look‐alikes because these are retail funds—in other words, funds marketing super funds for the general public. Complying funds—I think that was an issue raised by Senator Sherry—where they are regulated as public funds will be able to offer RSA look‐alikes through the SIS regulations.

I think that covers the matters which have been raised. I urge the Senate to reject the amendments put forward by Senator Sherry. We believe they will be covered to the extent they can practically be covered in the regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just contend, Senator Kemp, that you are incorrect when you say that, if RSAs were extended to a complying superannuation fund, they would be subject to two regulatory regimes. Our advice from the industry is that that would not happen, because the complying superannuation funds would establish the RSA product separately to ensure that they are not covered by the two regulatory regimes, if that was indeed a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, one of the great advantages of a complying superannuation fund having the ability to offer an RSA is that it is a low return product—no-one has disputed that—and if a person is in an RSA, a lower return product, and if that RSA is indirectly linked to a complying superannuation fund, a traditional fund, we would contend it would be easier for a member of an RSA to move their money when it is convenient to them out of the low return RSA product into a complying superannuation fund, which will carry a higher rate of return. We contend it would be easier practically to do that than it would be for a person in an RSA product offered by a bank to shift their money out of that RSA offered by a bank into some other product. We would argue that, practically, the individual in the RSA will find it easier to move their money into the complying superannuation fund, where the return is greater.

I would contend that it is in a bank's best interests to ensure as much money is locked up in a low return RSA type product because it is to the bank's financial advantage to do so. Whilst the bank can issue a health warning or various advice to a member in an RSA bank product that it is to their disadvantage, I do not believe they will pursue that approach with any enthusiasm whatsoever, because RSAs will become for banks effectively like the old passbook account—a very low interest product that the banks will seek to obtain the maximum return on by reinvesting the money, albeit it has to be in a capital guaranteed product. So we really cannot understand your opposition, Senator Kemp, on practical grounds and on principle grounds. It is in the best interests of RSA members to end up with a RSA product with a complying superannuation fund who offers the product.

The other point is that it is consistent with your election commitment but somehow between the cabinet submission before the budget last year it slipped out. You have given us some reasons, but I will not ask you what happened in cabinet. I suspect the banks had a word to the Treasurer in the meantime, but I do not want to be unduly provocative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry has canvassed the arguments about compliance. The minister says that there will be additional compliance costs, and Senator Sherry points out that this is unlikely. I make the point that, if there are, the superannuation funds themselves can decide whether that makes it viable or not viable. If the government is talking about commercial interference, this is a case in point. The government wants to interfere in order to protect, if you like, the superannuation funds from themselves if it is worried about the costs that might be applied. I suggest that is not a reasonable argument against these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Sherry is not grappling with the legal problems that we have here. Senator, I have listened carefully to your comments. You disputed the advice that I gave to the Senate. Naturally, I went back and sought further advice to ensure what had been said was correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Your amendment is to the definition of RSA institutions. Therefore, they would have to be subject to approval under the bill. This means they would have to be approved twice. The compliance problems which I raised with you would apply. So the first point I would make is that there is a legal problem with the issue that you have raised. I repeat that we have announced that public offer super funds will be able to offer RSA look‐alike products. That is the government's commitment.

The policy will be implemented through the SIS regulations. It cannot be offered, according to my advice, to all employer sponsored funds because some will not be subject to any capital requirements or any ISC formal ap proval processes. We are adopting a very responsible attitude to this to the extent that with RSAs we wish to have a level playing field, as you say, and we are entirely supportive of superannuation funds offering RSA look‐alike products.

I think Senator Sherry may have unwittingly revealed his hand in relation to the comments on banks. The reality is, Senator, that you do not like RSAs much. Your colleagues do not like RSAs much. You recognise, and give lip service to, the fact that it was an election commitment but your amendments are designed in toto to undermine the competitive nature of RSAs. That is essentially what you are on about.

The legal issue is that it sets up a problem which I have related in terms of reporting arrangements. That is the legal problem. The substantive issue is that we are dealing with that by allowing public office superannuation funds to offer look‐alike RSA products, so we are dealing with that. We have raised the issue in relation to all complying funds—there are problems and we have dealt with that issue. I would urge the Senate not to pass the amendments because they are simply not needed and add to the complexity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, on the legal advice, Senator Kemp, if we tracked the legal advice you have got on the so‐called surcharge that we will be dealing with tomorrow, I think you would be mightily embarrassed. I hope you have not got the same lawyers advising you on this.

SPEECH.PARA: RSAs, if offered by a complying superannuation fund, will be subject to this legislation—correct. But, Senator Kemp, the way in which—and I have had extensive consultation with and listened to industry—industry itself structures its RSAs will be its choice. I am informed by my industry advisers, whom we have been meeting frequently on these matters over the last few months in particular—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet you have.
—Yes, we have and we've been listening to them. Frankly, Senator Kemp, I find it difficult to find anyone who agrees with you and disagrees with us. That is our struggle at the moment.
—I agree with him.

—I'm sure you would. Yes, they will be subject to the retirement savings legislation if they offer an RSA product, but they will so structure their product that they will not be subject to two regimes. Even if they do not structure their product, even if they make the choice not to structure their product to be subject to the two regimes, and even if they decide that they are going to be subject to the two regimes, depending on how they decide to structure their product, the point made by Senator Allison is valid: that is a choice that they make and a cost they choose to bear if it is commercially viable to offer the product.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I make, Senator Kemp, is that you have raised this issue of dual legislative coverage. There are other places in this legislation where banks are required to be subject to the jurisdiction of this legislation as well as other superannuation legislation. So if your concern is about dual legislative coverage and competing costs, I would contend that you have got a problem with this legislation in respect of banks being subject to the same sorts of problems.

But that is a commercial decision for the institutions offering RSAs to make. If it is too costly, they will not offer the product, but my advice—certainly from the funds we have consulted—is that it is not going to be a problem. Where they choose to offer an RSA, they will bear whatever the cost is regardless of the legislative framework that they are subject to. What they want is the right, as banks have, to make that choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —May I just pick up a point that Senator Sherry made because maybe he does not quite understand the significance of the difference between an RSA and what he referred to as `a capital guaranteed fund'. It is important to note that a capital guaranteed fund does not, in a technical sense, guarantee the capital in the fund. The reason is that the capital guaranteed funds work by retaining either a portion of the dividend which is paid, or a portion of the notional capital gain in a reserve account. They use that to guarantee the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not correct to say that a capital guaranteed fund, so structured, can meet the criteria of an RSA, and there is a very good reason for saying that. If you get into a period when you do not have sustained growth or you have a situation where you have a fund which is only recently constructed and you get into a period when the market starts to decline, it may well be the case that the reserve fund is exceeded. If you have a spate of redemptions from the fund, you will have that technical problem, and I think that should be recognised.

Senator Kemp has said that the government is quite happy to allow superannuation funds to offer look‐alike products, but I think that you have got to be very careful when you refer to capital guaranteed funds and capital stable funds, which use fixed interest products as an alternative to RSAs. One of the problems with fixed interest products is that the government bond in which they invest can actually move up and down in value and that can create some technical difficulties, too. So I do not think it is correct to say that a capital guaranteed fund can be a replacement for the RSA structure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up with the minister a couple of quite specific issues. The first issue is what is being proposed here, which is that superannuation industry funds be allowed to offer look-alike products. In your second reading speech and in all the material that the government has circulated you have based your position on the issue of choice. This is a perfect example of you contradicting yourself in respect of the outcome. By not supporting this amendment, you are specifically excluding a sector of the industry that is extremely well placed to provide such a structure as what is proposed in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: How do you reconcile your opposition to this amendment with your rhetoric that it increases choice, given that Senator Sherry and others have quite clearly demonstrated that it would be the industry funds' choice as to how they structure their RSA look-alikes? They are not seeking any exemptions from existing regulations, but they are wanting to play on the playing field that you are establishing with respect to retirement savings accounts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the question raised by Senator Lundy first and then return to the matters raised by Senator Sherry. I do not think you listen to the debate, Senator Lundy. I said that we will allow public offer super funds to offer RSA look-alike products. I have said that two or three times already. Similar disclosure and other standards will apply as for RSAs regulated under the RSA legislation. The policy of public offer super funds being able to offer RSAs will be implemented through the SIS regulations. Is that clear? I have made that point three times. Public offer superannuation funds will be able to offer RSA look-alike products and they will be implemented through the SIS regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go to the legal problems. Senator Sherry, you have said that they can structure their products how they like. But the reality is that, if you include them in the way that you are trying to do with this amendment, they will have no ability, according to my advice, to freely structure. They will have no choice because they are defined as an RSA institution. Your proposal goes to the heart of the problem that you are pretending to address. They will be subject, once they are defined as RSA institutions—and Senator Conroy should know this because of his work as a superannuation officer for the TWU—to the full gamut of the RSA legislation. Your issue about the ability to freely structure is defeated by the very amendment that you are moving, Senator Sherry. I do not think you are helping your cause with this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you say that superannuation funds can offer look-alike RSAs. Can they call them RSAs?
—Public offer superannuation funds can offer RSAs and they can call them RSAs.

—I am interested in your legal advice, Senator Kemp. Are you saying that your legal advice is that it is not possible for a fund to structure itself in a way to comply with your legislation? Or is your advice that there are difficulties? Are you saying that there is no way that they can structure their circumstances to comply?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think you missed part of the debate. Senator Sherry said that they can freely structure their products as they wish to. I have said that once they are defined as an RSA institution—and that is what Senator Sherry's amendment would do—they will be subject to the full gamut of the RSA legislation. That is the point we are making.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in favour of choice. Senator Lundy, I welcome your support for choice. I do not think Senator Murphy is a great supporter of choice, but we welcome and appreciate your support for choice. Senator Sherry is a bit equivocal on the issue of choice. Perhaps he is trying to cover up the real intentions to prevent choice. But we are supportive of choice. We do not believe that the amendment moved by Senator Sherry will help the particular issue that he is seeking to address.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the question that I asked you, Minister. Irrespective of whether there are constraints by making the commercial decision that a fund may choose to make, are you saying that your legal advice is that it is not possible for them to structure themselves in a way if they commercially choose to do so?

—I hope I will assist you again, Senator Conroy. The RSA Bill applies to non-trust based entities. That is what the RSA Bill does. Superannuation funds are trusts. Therefore, the RSA Bill cannot be subject to super funds. There is a difference.
—You are contradicting yourself.
—What we are saying, Senator Lundy, just so you are entirely com fortable with this, is that public offer superannuation funds can offer RSA look-alike products and they can be called RSAs.
—Is that only public offer funds?
—That is what we have said: public offer superannuation funds.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand, Senator Kemp, that complying superannuation funds will establish a non-trust product.

—Once they are outside the trust structure, they are outside SIS. They are not regulated by anybody. I think the issue, as it is broken down here, is: is there going to be a choice? Senator Lundy made that point.
—You're trying to dodge the issue. That is your problem.

—Well, I have said there is going to be a choice. We have said that we do not agree with the amendment but, nonetheless, public offer superannuation funds will be able to offer RSA look-alike products. So I think we have dealt with the issue. This will be covered under the SIS regs. I think we have dealt with the issue that you have raised, Senator, and I think we have dealt with the problem that Senator Sherry has raised, but time will tell.

—Minister, the way you are describing this is a direct contradiction. What we are proposing here is an amendment to the RSA Bill that will allow for complying superannuation funds to participate. Yet you are saying that the mechanism to allow superannuation funds to offer look-alike products is entirely distinct and separate from the RSA Bill. Have you prepared any relevant amendments to the SIS regulations that would provide for that, or are you just putting this up to push aside the real issue, which is to make sure that this bill provides for a mechanism to allow super funds to offer those RSA accounts? Are you simply saying, `Well, they can, and do, do that, but it sure won't be covered by these particular bills. It is outside of this bill'? It seems to me that you cannot have it both ways.

—Senator, as I understand it, what you want to do is to have public offer superannuation funds being able to offer RSA look-alike products. That is what you want. We have said—and I will say this for the fifth time—that the answer is that they will be able to offer RSA look-alike products, and they will be able to do it under the SIS regs, which are currently being prepared. That is what we have said, Senator. We have said that the superannuation funds operate under a trust structure. The RSA bill does not deal with trust structures. We are meeting what you want us to do, and we are on record as saying that. I have now gone on the record three, four or five times assuring you, yet you keep on getting up, Senator, and disputing that fact.
—Do you know the difference between complying funds and public offer funds?

—Yes, we know the difference. I wonder whether you know the difference, Senator Conroy. That is what we are proposing, Senator. So if your real concern is about public offer superannuation funds offering RSAs, we are saying to you, Senator, that that is going to happen and it will be done under the SIS regulations. That is what we are saying.
—Minister, we are talking about complying funds.

—Perhaps Senator Kemp could tell us in what sense they are just broadly equivalent. I think this probably goes to the heart of the matter. In what way would the superannuation funds be restricted should they offer look-alike RSAs? Would there be any restrictions under the SIS requirements, or is this a case of us not knowing that until we see the regulation? It seems to me that we want to make sure, now that we are dealing with this bill, that we have those provisions in place. Can you assure us that a look-alike is, in fact, exactly the same and would not be restricted in any way in comparison with those offered by banks and credit unions and the like?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I have stated my position. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced in the budget that public offer superannuation funds would be able to offer a product similar to RSAs. However, they will still be sold under a trust structure and will be regulated under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. As I have said, there is no need for any amendments to be made to the RSA legislation to allow for public offer superannuation funds to offer these look-alike products.

SPEECH.PARA: These look-alikes will be required to provide the same capital guarantee as an RSA; that is, the contributions on accumulated earnings in the account will not be able to be reduced by negative investment earnings. Standards for ensuring that this capital guarantee is appropriately backed by the public offer superannuation fund in the absence of solvency or capital adequacy rules are currently under consideration within the government.

We are consulting widely with the industry on these things. The supervision regulations will be amended in consultation with industry. We will work with industry, as we do, so that there is neutrality between disclosure rules for RSAs and similar capital guaranteed products offered by public offer superannuation funds.

In answer to matters raised by Senator Conroy and, I think, Senator Sherry, only public offer funds can offer RSA look-alikes, because these are analogous to life offices and banks, given that they are marketing interest to the general public. Public offer funds are subject to formal ISC approval and minimum capital requirements. Not all complying funds would be allowed to offer, because these are employer sponsored funds dealing with particular employees in particular workplaces. They are not general retail funds.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just turn to the leaked cabinet-in-confidence document? I did not want to have to go to that. I do not know that you will accept the veracity of it, but I have got it here. It says:

BREAK.PARA: The government announced its commitment to allow banks, building societies, credit unions, life insurance companies, life offices—
which are all in this legislation—
and complying superannuation funds and other financial intermediaries to offer RSA products.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether you have got a cabinet document or not, to be quite frank. It is not my role, and I guess it has never been the practice in your party, to discuss what may or may not be in cabinet and the discussions involved there.

—Senator Conroy, restrain your enthusiasm. You will soon be on the front bench, so just restrain your enthusiasm so we can speed the journey a little bit here. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

The legal arrangements you are proposing, I think, simply do not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

SPEECH.PARA: If you are real about the newly discovered reason—that is, the fact that there are 140,000 complying superannuation funds—the cabinet document does not raise that as a problem at all. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

SPEECH.PARA: I put to you, Minister, that there is absolutely no justification upon which you can base this decision. The second point I would like to make relates to the application of this bill. Going back to the point I made earlier about your rhetoric about improving choice, I am not convinced that these RSAs are going to improve choice at all. TALK.START.PARA: —Choose to offer RSAs.

—They could chose to—thank you, Senator Conroy. They could in fact choose to offer RSAs. Unless you get this contradiction sorted out, or unless you put on the table what the government's motivation is for excluding complying funds quite specifically, quite obviously against the advice contained in this leaked cabinet submission that Senator Sherry is referring to, you have no basis on which to oppose this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I sometimes wonder. We go through the arguments, we carefully ascertain the differences between RSAs and perhaps the public offer superannuation funds and how they can offer look-alike products, we discuss the issue of complying funds, and you get up and you say, `There are no reasons.'
—You haven't put an argument.

—Senator, for you to raise your voice to strongly assert what is blatantly absurd does not prove your point. It does not prove it at all. The Hansard will show that you relentlessly refuse to look at reasons which are offered to you. You stand up and—if you do not mind me paraphrasing—you say, `Well, you've got no reasons,' and then you throw your hands in the air. You might not like the reasons, Senator, you might not accept the reasons, but it is absurd to say that reasons have not been proffered on this.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an issue in relation to complying funds, which we have carefully gone through. I have to tell you that the amendment you are supporting will have legal problems. We have mentioned that, because superannuation funds are under a trust structure. We have met the substantive part of your argument that superannuation funds will be able to offer an RSA look-alike product. We have dealt with that issue. We have raised with you that all complying funds do raise other problems. We mentioned the number of complying funds and we mentioned in relation to that that this would lead to an absurdity. You might not like the reasons but I do not know what more we can do.

I notice that you were spoken to—probably by Senator Conroy who, I would have to say, is not the greatest choice man on superannuation—and that you have now corrected the Hansard record on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your rhetoric, Senator Kemp, not ours.
—It is an election promise, Senator.
—That you are breaking.

—We're breaking an election promise! We will see how these amendments go through. Senator, I think that we have addressed your concerns and you throwing your hands in the air and raising your voice does not alter that one jot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given a lot of consideration to this outside the chamber and I have listened carefully to the debate so far. I see this amendment moved by Senator Sherry as part and parcel of a number of amendments that are going to be moved by him later on. I see it as an important amendment because, let us face it, we are dealing not with employers' funds, bank funds or the funds of superannuation organisations but with workers' funds.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as I am concerned, I believe that under those circumstances, there must be accepted a fundamental principle that these are essentially trust funds. You can call them retirement savings accounts, and so on, but they really should be dealt with as trust funds to be held in trust by the organisations, whether they be these or whether they be the superannuation funds. Later on I will move an amendment that goes to that particular question. I know that time is very short, with a lot of legislation to get through before we get up for Easter, but I indicate to the chamber that I am going to support the amendments moved by Senator Sherry, unless there are absolutely overwhelming arguments to the contrary,

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I ask Senator Kemp the following question. You keep indicating that there are problems for complying funds. Well, stand up and give us a guarantee that there is an insurmountable legal problem to a complying fund actually offering RSA, and be prepared to table it. That is the key question. If you are saying that there is legal advice that you have that says it is not possible for a complying fund in some manner to offer an RSA, then put your money where your mouth is and table the advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am giving you the advice. I am doing even better than that. I am going on the Hansard record on the advice of the officials that I have beside me. I am even doing better than what you want. I have mentioned to you that you are opening up an area which we do not believe is merited and which you have failed to substantiate any arguments for.

SPEECH.PARA: We have mentioned the wider range of complying funds—the 140,000. You have relentlessly refused to address that particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the legal problem?

—We have been through this. We will go through it again for you. The fact of the matter is that it is a technically unworkable amendment, we believe: because it is a specific amendment to an RSA institution, it is technically unworkable. It makes the funds subject to two regimes. That is the point that we have made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I anticipate we are just about to get to decision time on this and I do not want to further the debate any longer. Perhaps through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I could make a request to Senator Colston. I do not want to call divisions unnecessarily. Senator Harradine has indicated his position. It is entirely up to you, Senator Colston. Perhaps if you were willing to offer an indication of what you are prepared to do it would save us the necessity of calling a division. The government may want to call one or we may want to call one on principle, but I certainly do not intend to call divisions on these issues on principle if it is apparent we have a majority on a particular amendment.

—I have been listening very carefully to the arguments on both sides and I actually raised this matter with the minister earlier today. I do have a question and perhaps I could ask the question first before I indicate what my stance is. Minister, you were saying that regulations would be issued. —Senator, they will be in place, we hope, at the same time, before 1 July, so that there will be a competitive structure which has been established and one particular group will not get the jump, so to speak, on the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, can I indicate that on this occasion I am persuaded by the minister and I will be voting with the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 14, page 5 (line 22), at the end of subclause (1), add ", fees, charges, surcharges or taxes".

(3) Clause 14, page 5 (lines 25 and 26), omit "or any reduction in the value of assets in which the policy is invested", substitute ", any reduction in the value of assets in which the policy is invested or any fees, charges, surcharges or taxes".
(7) Clause 42, page 30 (line 21), after paragraph (b), insert:
or
(c) reduce the contributions or accumulated carriages of an RSA by the debiting of any fees, charges, surcharges or taxes.

We regard our amendments Nos 2, 3 and 7 as absolutely critical. Amendment No. 2 will impose a requirement, in the case of capital guarantee, not to allow fees, charges, surcharges or taxes to reduce the amount in the RSA product. We believe that is fundamentally important. A capital guarantee means that the level of contributions cannot be reduced by any amount—that is to say, the amount is in fact guaranteed, and we see that in reading the definition of `capital guarantee' in this legislation. It is guaranteed against negative interest and also guaranteed against losses.

We believe it would be entirely unacceptable for contributions—and it is admitted that for many people contributions are likely to be relatively small amounts—to be dwindled away by excessive fees and charges. It would also be unacceptable for the amount to be dwindled away by taxes and surcharges—we call them taxes on superannuation; I know the government calls them surcharges, but we have put `surcharge' in there just to make sure—

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice you have conceded the surcharge, Senator. I might even use that in question time today.

—If we were dealing with tomorrow's legislation today, we would know whether it was a tax or a surcharge, wouldn't we, because we would know which amendments were carried. I am anticipating both outcomes, not just one.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that member protection exists, but again it is in the regulations. We do not find that a satisfactory approach; it should be in the main body of the legislation. This is a product that is designed to protect small accounts and low income earners. The credit unions have already said that they do not believe that their members will levy fees and charges on the accounts because of the fact that these accounts are designed to protect low income workers.

In respect of amendment No. 3, the arguments that I have already advanced largely canvass the same issue: member protection and protection of small amounts. I should point out that under the SIS regulations at the moment amounts of under $1,000 will be subject to the same rules as apply to SIS. However, it will be in the regulations. We have not had the opportunity to see the regulations. I know Senator Colston was reassured on a previous occasion but we are not reassured, because we do not have the regulations; we have not been able to see them. And it is best to protect members in the bills anyway.

Both the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Taxation Office went on record before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, which conducted public hearings on these bills, as saying that it is possible that the balance of the account could be less than the total amount of the contributions should fees and charges be applied. We would find that a totally unacceptable position.
The same arguments that I put in respect of amendments 2 and 3 apply to amendment No. 7.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats will support these amendments, but foreshadow that our amendments Nos 3 and 4 will remove fees altogether. I think it was made fairly clear to us at the inquiry that RSOs are going to be lucrative, so we see no reason not to put in safeguards which would ensure that those fees do not reduce the capital. But, as I say, I foreshadow our amendments which would withdraw fees altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Complete prohibition, as proposed by Senator Sherry, on fees and charges is really an unwarranted commercial interference and again it reflects the Labor Party's attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy gets up and gets all excited. I am going to state the reasons for you. Please, when you stand up, do not say, `Well, you did not answer the question,' because I will go very carefully through what Senator Sherry has said. Senator Lundy, if you get up I want you to be able to address an issue which I will raise at the end of this—if you are going to support this amendment.

BREAK.PARA: RSA providers, like all commercial operators, should be allowed to levy fees and charges, provided they are fully disclosed. Apart from member protection of accounts below $1,000, which Senator Sherry raised, there is no direct regulation of fees and charges in the superannuation industry. Are you are aware of that? Senator Lundy initially was for choice and presumably she initially wanted to make sure that it was all on a level playing field. Your initial position should give you some comfort. Listen to this, however, and then I will sit down so the Labor people can get up and explain to me why this is wrong.

Making RSAs immune from a tax or a surcharge—that is what your amendment does; that is what it says—would make RSAs a tax haven and open up an enormous loophole. That is what Senator Sherry's amendment does. That is exactly what you have done now. Senator Sherry, unlike some of your colleagues you do not have a reputation for being the shadow minister for tax rorts. I think that some of your colleagues are more liable to be attacked on that front, but not you. I think that you have adopted a responsible attitude, Senator Sherry, but with one little amendment you have opened up an enormous tax haven. That is what you have done, Senator Sherry. Can you get up and explain to me why you have not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up a few points that Senator Kemp raised, given he quite specifically invited me to do so, and explain to him that we are not talking about a tax haven here. We are talking about protecting the money of the working people who may put their money in RSAs if this act proceeds. We are talking about ensuring that the banks cannot tap into these accounts and bleed them with extraordinarily high and unfair fees and charges.

SPEECH.PARA: The motivation for this amendment is protection of the interests of the low income earners who will be the ones pushed towards the use of RSAs. So, Senator Kemp, I reject completely the notion you are putting forward. In fact, it highlights once again that not only have you not got a grip on this issue but also you resort to furphy arguments to try to substantiate your position. Quite clearly we are concerned about the interests of the working people—a significant proportion of them probably low income earners. If their hard‐earned money is put into these RSAs, they will be bled dry by the banks with fees and charges. You cannot say that we have not seen example after example of this happening to date with bank charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, Senator Lundy, you relentlessly repeat slogans and say, `Oh, you haven't answered the question,' or `you haven't got a grip on it.' We just carefully went through all the points simply because you do not listen or refuse to understand. But, Senator Lundy, have you forgotten that the Labor Party does not represent the workers? It is our side of politics—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The chardonnay‐latte set is over there, it is not over here. You are, as usual, quite provocative in saying that the Labor Party represents the workers. I have to say most people in the committee would regard that as a joke. How easily, just with a wave of the hand, you dismiss a substantive point. I draw your attention to the amendment you are now supporting—clause 14, page 5, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: omit "or any reduction in the value of assets in which the policy is invested", substitute ", any reduction in the value of assets in which the policy is invested or any fees, charges, surcharges or taxes".

Senator Lundy, I am surprised that you are giving any support to tax havens, but that is exactly what you have done with a wave of the hand and a refusal to answer any questions. The Hansard record will show, Senator Lundy, that you refused to address that issue. I am pointing this out to you. Am I right in saying that the assets value cannot be reduced because of any fees, charges, surcharges or taxes? If that is the case, Senator Lundy, you have opened up a major tax haven. Could you stand up and explain to me why you have? Explain, do not just dismiss it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would be more impressed by the argument that, if this amendment were carried, the entire RSA product would open up tax havens if we had some clear proof and advice of this, Senator Kemp. We have got a minute and a half to go, perhaps you would consider giving us some legal advice about this grandiose new tax dodge that you allege will be opened up? Frankly, I am very sceptical if this is to be your approach on amendments in respect of this legislation—if there is going to be this sort of allegation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted the time, so I am sure we will not be going on to another amendment. Regrettably, Senator Kemp, despite our best efforts we have unfortunately not been able to get past the first couple of amendments. I think we will have to consult after question time and endeavour to ensure we have got a process in place which ensures a more rapid consideration of the superannuation legislation that we have before the chamber in respect of RSA type products. I make this observation because the Senate is faced with the very daunting task of concluding before Easter. We are faced with the daunting task of dealing with—

TALK.START.PARA: —An inadequate minister.

—I have not got to the inadequacies of the minister yet. We are faced with the daunting task of dealing with the inadequacies surrounding the so‐called surcharge legislation tomorrow. We believe it is manifestly inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, do you acknowledge that on Wednesday, 11 March, on the AM program, the Treasurer, Mr Costello, assured the Australian public that the government had taken into account legal opinions similar to that of Mr Dennis Rose QC, who had claimed that your so-called surcharge was unconstitutional because of the provisions of the critical clause, clause 34? Why then have you done a legal somersault, tabling amend ments in the House of Representatives last Thursday deleting clause 34, in an attempt to correct the legal mess of your legislation? Why didn't you make a public statement to admit your massive legal blunder?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't we make a public statement? I think you mentioned that it was tabled in the House of Representatives, Senator. I think that is pretty public. From memory, in order to assist you and to indicate the cooperative attitude that I adopt to requests from you, we actually had one brought around to your office last week. I do not think there has been any attempt to hide it. If we were attempting to hide this, it would not have been noted in the House of Representatives and it would not have been brought promptly around to your office. The proposition you have put—as is so often the case—is completely absurd.

ANSWER.PARA: As we have stated on a number of occasions, the Attorney-General's Department advise that the surcharge legislation, as originally drafted, was valid under the constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why change it?

—Just listen. You get so excited, Senator Sherry. You asked a question. I am slowly taking you through the answer because in your supplementary you will probably say, `As usual, Senator Kemp did not answer the question.' I am taking you through it slowly so you can avoid that problem. I will repeat myself: the Attorney-General's Department advise that they believe the surcharge legislation, as originally drafted, was valid under the constitution. This remains their view after considering Mr Rose's opinion.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been indications—I think even from you, Senator Sherry—that the constitutionality of the surcharge legislation would be challenged in the High Court. To remove any remaining doubt that some people may have as to its constitutional validity, the surcharge legislation has been amended to remove proposed clause 34. Do you understand that, Senator? In our belief, this shows that Mr Rose's opinion was no knock-out blow to the surcharge. As I have said, we hold to the original position as an issue that was raised.
