TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you spent the last two weeks defending the constitutionality of the bills as they were originally written. You are now publicly acknowledging that you got it wrong and that the bill is open to challenge. You have now had to change that. To add insult to injury, you have tried to hide that. This is the third major change to your package of legislation to correct major errors since it was tabled on 13 February. It comes on top of additional bills to exempt federal judges, major amendments to include federal government employees, which you had forgotten, and now we have this third major change. Isn't this latest major change just further evidence of the continuing shambles and chaos surrounding your attempts to collect this new tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, all your huffing and puffing makes no difference to the facts of the matter, as I have outlined to you. There was no attempt to hide it, because we brought it around to your office. If we were going to hide it, what a funny way to hide it! Neither did we make any concession of the type that you mentioned in your question. I will repeat myself because, again, you read out your supplementary without listening to the answer. The Attorney-General's Department advised that they believed that the surcharge legislation, as originally drafted, was valid under the constitution. That remains their view after considering Mr Rose's opinion.

ANSWER.PARA: Our position has been entirely consistent. Your huffing and puffing and attempting to mislead the public does not alter the fact that we have been entirely consistent on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, the government's small business statement, More time for business , released yesterday, has been hailed by the business community at large as showing strong sensitivity to the problems facing small business. What has been the response of those on the ground, who found it so hard under 13 years of Labor government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the statement has been received very positively by the small business community, as has been demonstrated by the statements of various industry representatives. It is heartening that business is recognising that it finally has a government that is sensitive to its interests and concerns, recognises how important it is to creating wealth and providing employment and appreciates that there is a role and responsibility for government in assisting in sensible ways.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, the Housing Industry Association Ltd put out a statement yesterday saying that the HIA welcomes the initiatives in the Prime Minister's More time for business statement which will significantly reduce the paperwork and compliance burden for small business. This is very important because we have heard so often that small business is overwhelmed by the paperwork and red tape requirements. Here is the HIA saying that this statement, as implemented, will `significantly reduce the paperwork and compliance burden for small business through liberalisation of FBT and unfair dismissal requirements'.

I remind the Senate that the HIA represents some 30,000 firms in the building industry—not an insignificant player, Senator Cook, although you might not appreciate it. It said it was particularly pleased to see the commitment by all governments to regulatory reform in the building industry. At last, Senator Cook, regulatory reform in the building industry in response to the Small Business Deregulation Task Force recommendations.
Also the Real Estate Institute put out a statement welcoming the response by the Prime Minister on the Bell report on small business deregulation. It said:
The Government's response shows strong sensitivity to the pressures facing small business. It will assist to strengthen small business activity and reduce regulatory costs.
It continues:
The Prime Minister's response also holds benefits for potential employment growth as small businesses can commit greater focus on commercial development.
The tourism industry, a major employer in Australia, also put out a statement welcoming the government's response. It said:

The initiatives like the abolition of fringe benefits taxes in some areas, exemptions of unfair dismissal laws for employees working less than 12 months and extra funding will help boost small businesses throughout Australia.
It made the point that the Australian tourism industry has such capacity to generate jobs. This statement is, therefore, so welcome from that perspective as well.

In contrast, the response from the Labor Party has been muddled. Senator Cook was not quite sure what he said on it yesterday morning. In fact, he had to put out a press release saying that he did not say what he thought he might have said. He said at today's door stop:
I may have said that the opposition will try to block the small business unfair dismissal provisions in the Senate. This is not what I meant to convey.

It brings back memories of the old innovation statement, Senator Cook—really not quite sure what you are seeking to convey. With all the elegance and statesmanship we were expecting from Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, he said, `I have good news for you; we will pass this little doozey.' That is the best Mr Beazley could say.

As I said, the Australian small business community has been crying out for a government that is responsive to their needs. The statement of yesterday is a demonstration that they have finally got it and it is good to see that they have recognised it with their statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, isn't it true that, in your rush to correct the constitutional problems that you denied existed with your so-called superannuation surcharge bills, you have forgotten or missed in your incompetence necessary amendments that will allow the employer under section 58 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act to direct trustees of schemes to reduce members' benefits to pay the tax? Without these amendments either the employer will have to pay the tax themselves in the case of defined benefit funds or trustees will have to collect the tax from funds on all the fund earnings, passing on the subsequent reduction to all fund members, including those earning less than $70,000 a year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, we always welcome questions in relation to superannuation because there are a few issues that you have to tackle yourself. My understanding—and I will check this and, if I need to, confirm it after question time—is that the matters you raised can be fixed under the SIS regulations. The problem you are alleging I do not think exists, but I will get some further advice and see whether I need to add anything to that answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, I wonder how much advice you are accepting on the amendments that you may be proposing in relation to the superannuation surcharge. I have got a letter here from ASFA.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: the minister has just said in answer to Senator Sherry's question, effectively, that he has not got a clue; he does not know the answer; he will seek advice and try to answer Senator Sherry's question after question time. He is now going off on some other flight of fancy. Rule him out of order, Madam President. Sit him down. Let us get on with question time.

—There were a number of aspects to the question and some preamble that Senator Sherry put. Certainly I heard Senator Kemp defer part of it, but he may have something to offer on other parts of the question. It was quite a detailed question.

—Thank you, Madam President. You are quite right and Senator Faulkner, as usual, got it wrong. I mentioned, Senator Faulkner, that I believe those matters are addressed under the SIS regulations. Senator, I said that, if I needed to come back to the chamber, I certainly would.
—Now sit down! You haven't got a clue.

—The old glass jaw is causing a problem there, Senator Faulkner. We have a large pile of amendments prepared by ASFA. I wonder how much consultation the Labor Party has had in relation to those amendments. I wonder whether the Labor Party will be attempting to use those amendments to substantially change the collection approach which has been outlined by the government and whether the Labor Party has assessed the enormous compliance costs on small business.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We can wait till tomorrow, but you raised particular issues. I have answered the issue you raised and now I am raising with you the issue.

—On a point of order, Madam President, that goes to relevance: he has just said he has answered the particular issue that I have raised. How can he go further? I would submit that what he is going into now is irrelevant. He has said on the record that he has answered the matter I have raised.
—Senator Kemp, you should be directing your answer to the question that was asked. If you have finished that, conclude.

—Thank you, Madam President. In the hysterical question we got from Senator Sherry he raised particular concerns. I am just responding to those concerns and showing the public the utter hypocrisy of the Labor Party on this particular matter.

ANSWER.PARA: We are waiting to see whether this is indeed the Labor Party of old which accepts all the views of a particular lobby group at the expense of wider community interests. Senator, we are looking forward to your response on that. We shall wait with great interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. This issue of section 58 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act is a very serious matter that flows from the constitutional changes you have had to make. Will you give us an assurance that there are no further major problems at all with the superannuation tax bills? If you cannot give us that assurance and there are further major problems, will you resign?

—One thing we do not want you to do, Senator Sherry, is to resign. We like you just there; just keep on staying there. We are very confident about these bills because they are fair and equitable. We believe that the measures we have put forward will be welcomed by the community because of their fairness and we hope, in the end, that the Labor Party will come to its senses and strongly support the bill.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. There has been overwhelming support for the coalition government small business package by those groups most affected. Labor has once again distinguished itself by displaying total confusion. Will you give us a description of the level of support for the government's package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Howard government's More time for business document is a commitment to small business throughout Australia, which is the engine room of employment growth in the economy. It is a commitment which has been enthusiastically welcomed by small business, business organisations, the myriad of professional bodies that support and are supported by small business and the media. Guess who can find nothing good with it? That fount of political wisdom, that group so much out of touch with the little people, the battlers and small business—the Australian Labor Party. Is it any wonder that Gary Gray despairingly warns the ALP federal executive that, after a year in the wilderness, Labor have learnt absolutely nothing? In fact, they have achieved the impossible by sinking further into obscurity because they are so out of touch with community expectations.

ANSWER.PARA: A classic example of the Labor Party malaise is the doorstop remark by none other than the deputy leader, Mr Gareth Evans. What were Mr Evans's illuminating remarks about the More time for business package? He said, `Overall the package deserves the raspberry it is getting, including from small business organisations.' Talk about relevance deprivation! They bring it on their own heads, that crowd. For the edification of Mr Evans and for the edification of the people on the Labor side, I would like to quote the verdicts of the third umpires, the people who run small business, business organisations and professional groups. Let us see what they had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that word again?

—Relevance deprivation, Senator. Can I say it again—relevance edification. Would you like me to spell it—slowly? This is what the various business groups have said. The Australian Business Chamber said:

ANSWER.PARA: The initiative announced by Mr Howard will send the signals small business has been looking for to help encourage new growth and investment.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not like this, Senator Kernot, do you? The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Government's response to the small business deregulation task force's recommendations will significantly cut the compliance burden on small business and boost confidence in the sector.
And:
. . . the government has responded to the concerns of small business—major changes in big ticket items will deliver enormous benefits to many small businesses.
The Council of Small Business Organisations, in regard to wrongful dismissal changes, said:
While people can be more easily dismissed more will be employed under the additional changes announced by Mr Howard.
The Small Business Network said:
The package is a step in the right direction.
The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia said:
The package is pretty pleasing. Certainly, the Howard Government has taken a step in the right direction for small business.
The Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry said:
It has been worth the wait. It will provide an important catalyst for job growth.
The Australian Business Chamber said:

BREAK.PARA: A significant confidence booster. Will send the signals small business had been looking for to . . . encourage new growth and investment.
Charlie Bell said:
They agreed in full or in part to 57 of the 62 recommendations, so to get a 90 per cent endorsement rate is pretty good.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, can you confirm that, without the necessary amendments to section 58 of the SI(S) Act to correct the new set of problems that you have created and that I referred to in my previous question, the government will not be able to collect revenue from many superannuation funds containing a substantial number of employees earning more than $70,000 a year? As a result, you could lose up to half the revenue that you have projected of $1.5 billion?
—Senator, what happens to the bills ultimately will depend on the votes in this chamber.
—Excuse me?
—On the votes in this chamber. What happens—
—Doesn't the government have a say?

—That is what I am saying to you. The ultimate outturn with these bills will depend on what in fact happens with the votes in this chamber. We are confident that the bills as announced will ensure a fair and equitable outcome.
—We have to correct all your mistakes.

—Just contain yourself, Senator Ray. What finally goes through this chamber will depend on the votes of the senators. But we are confident, with the arguments which will be canvassed in this chamber, that these bills will be seen to be fair and equitable.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The problem is that the bills as tabled on 13 February keep having to be changed because of mistakes and errors that the government has made. You have had to include additional bills to exempt federal judges, you forgot to include federal government employees, you had to rewrite the constitutionality of the bill so you could avoid it being challenged and now you have major problems collecting half your revenue. This is a shambles. Assure the Senate that there are no more major problems with this legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The shambles is on your side. We are quite confident with the revenue projections we made. We are confident. The shambles is on your side because of utter confusion that you have. You allegedly support the 15 per cent surcharge. Your leader says he will put the bills through. You are all over the place. We are still seeking the Labor Party amendments and, boy, are they being well hidden! They would not be the ASFA amendments by any chance, would they?

ANSWER.PARA: Would you not think that in the interests of proper debate the Labor Party after all this time would be prepared to put forward the amendments they are proposing, but they are still being hidden. Do you know why? Because as soon as you put them forward, they will be full of holes. Senator Sherry is trying to hide the compliance costs that they are trying to put on small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Are you aware that the cost of finance provided by the banks to small business is provided at a cost 2 to 3 per cent higher than that provided to big business? Is the government concerned that Australian real interest rates for small business, that is the prime lending rate less inflation, is the highest of any industrialised OECD country and higher than before banking deregulation in 1983? Do you concede that this is because of a clear market failure in the banking sector? Is Aussie Home Loans your sole answer to the banks' failure for small business and where would you be without their lifeline? Is it not the case that 56 per cent of small business have reported having problems with their bank in the previous year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —You made eight out of 10 for trying and continuing to ask questions in regard to the small business sector. I want to encourage Senator Murray to keep asking those questions. Let me say that it would be nice to hear something positive for a change, instead of the complete carping that goes on.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Murray and the Democrats would have more credibility if they were to address their own election policies in regard to business and it is worth having a look at a few. The Democrats' policy is more about legislation, more protection, more government intervention and more paperwork. If you look at the policies of the Democrats, that is what it is. One of the things that clearly stands out is the carbon tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order and I think it is self‐evident, Madam President. It goes to relevance. Could the minister please answer the question concerning the cost of finance?
—There were five or six questions in the question. Senator Parer will need to go through them in order.

—I can understand the sensitivity—not so much of Senator Murray, but of the Democrats, because Senator Murray is at least trying. I want to encourage him to keep trying. Eventually we will keep the education process going. Senator Murray is asking a question on interest rates and I will come to that question. Before I do, let me make the point that Senator Murray has come in here day after day asking questions on manufacturing. As I said, I encourage it. The more we have those questions, the better. I do not mind that sort of pressure; I think it is great. Keep the pressure on us—that is good.

ANSWER.PARA: However, you have a carbon tax. The industry in Australia that uses most energy is the manufacturing industry. Twenty‐six per cent of all emissions come from the manufacturing industry. You want to hit them with a carbon tax. You come in here making remarks to me about interest rates. Let me mention interest rates. The interest rates in Australia today are the lowest that they have been for years and years and years. Of course, they do reflect the low inflation factor that is going on.

As to the amount of money paid by small business, Senator Murray comes from the small business sector and he would appreciate that that is very much a variable figure. Naturally, we would like to see interest rates down lower. However, it does reflect to a large degree the levels of risk. I would imagine that Senator Murray got a pretty good interest rate, although he was there when the Labor Party was in power and the interest rate was over 20 per cent. Of course, that was the time when we saw the small business sector actually decimated.

All I can say to Senator Murray is that there is no doubt in our view that we want inflation to stay down. We want to have a business environment that encourages investment and the way to achieve that is to make sure that we maintain the low level of inflation that someone said is the lowest since man stood on the moon. In fact, our interest rates are lower than they have been for a decade and we would like to see them lower.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you do try our patience because you do not answer the question. The question is: the cost of finance to small business. It is the greatest concern that small business has. Surely, if the Commonwealth Development Bank is not reinstated, the banking competition issues not dealt with, a low‐cost dispute resolution mechanism not found, then your small business policy response—as warmly as we welcomed it—and the Wallis stocktake on banking, will have clearly failed to deliver on the crying need for small business for cheap and readily available finance? They want a lower rate compared with big business.
—I am not sure what Senator Murray is asking for. I think he is saying that he wants government intervention.
—Absolutely!

—Absolutely, says Senator Murray. Here we are developing in this country a competitive economy—one that is highly competitive—and Senator Murray wants market intervention in an area where we have, and are encouraging more, competition. As I said, and I will repeat it again, it is absolutely vital that we keep inflation down. That is the only way we are going to keep interest rates down.
—What about the growth rate?

—Senator Bolkus interjected about the growth rate. Did he not read what the Reserve Bank of Australia said the other day? It said that if we can keep the inflation rate down we are going to have a period of sustained growth. Do you know what that means, Senator? You might not like it, but it means more real jobs in the Australian economy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, do you recall telling the Age last July that Green Corps's primary aim was to help the long-term unemployed enter the work force and that improving the environment should be only a secondary benefit? You were also quoted as saying that the government would not fund expensive programs that did not offer real hope to the unemployed. How, then, do you explain that fewer than half of the current 240 participants in the Green Corps programs are unemployed and that only 12 per cent are long-term unemployed? How do you justify spending $41.6 million on training these young people who, in the majority of cases, were already employed or in training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. Senator, it will come as no surprise to you or anybody else that I do not carry in my mind an encyclopaedic version of what has been covered in one paper or another going back some nine months. So I cannot help you with whatever was reported in the Age . I do not assert that they have necessarily got it wrong, but, if I bothered to keep a file of where the media get things wrong, there would not be any room in my office for staff to work because it would be taken up with news clippings that got it wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us come to the issue of Green Corps, which is the central point of the question. Senator, I think I have explained to you before that the Green Corps is not a labour market program. It is a program designed to give opportunities to young Australians to contribute to enhancing and protecting the environment at the same time as they get accredited training. Additionally, it provides for those Green Corps participants who might want to continue in a further form of training a cash benefit incentive to do so. That is the purpose of the Green Corps.

It is true that, in the earlier stages, one might have thought that the Green Corps program would take in a more limited range of people than we have agreed to take. As you know, we have agreed to take people whether they are employed or unemployed. I support that decision. It is a sensible decision to make because the main purpose of and desire for the Green Corps, as I have just outlined to you, is to contribute to enhancing and protecting the environment, to get accredited training in that area and to proceed to further training. This is not something that is limited to the long-term unemployed at all. Nor should the program, therefore, be limited to those people. In fact, it is open to those who choose to participate. It is voluntary participation in the program. I hope that answers your questions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. Minister, you have made it clear, therefore, that the Green Corps is not a labour market program and is not about helping the long-term unemployed. You said earlier that it might have been thought that that was an objective of the scheme. Do you think it is important that you explain to the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, this fact, because in parliament on 11 February this year, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: This particular initiative takes its place alongside other initiatives of the government to deal with the problem of youth unemployment—
Clearly, the Prime Minister does not understand that Green Corps is not about tackling youth unemployment. Will you take the opportunity to explain to him the change in policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you could have done better than waste your time asking this question. It is perfectly obvious to anybody who understands how the Green Corps works that there are participants who are unemployed, some short term and some long term, and they will benefit from the scheme as well. Unlike the previous government—the government of which you were a member—we are not so constrained as to say, `This little policy box designed here is specifically for this group of people, and they are the only people who can participate.' That is not the approach that we have taken to the Green Corps. We have taken a broader approach. It is not exclusive of unemployed people. Those who participate we very much expect and hope will benefit from it. What would be the purpose of doing it if we did not think that?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, are you concerned that the ethanol industry received a blow when your government axed the ethanol fuel bounty, effectively pulling the rug out from a viable Australian industry which has created regional jobs and significant value adding to primary production? Guarantees were given at the time that, despite the withdrawal of the bounty, $2 million would go to the ethanol industry. The industry is now alarmed to hear that the money has since been moved into the Energy Research and Development Corporation to fill a budget hole, with no guarantee the money will be moved back. Minister, can you give a guarantee that the money will be redirected to the ethanol industry without delay, or is the government planning to throw this industry on the scrap heap altogether?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley has asked a whole range of questions. I must say that I am totally amazed that you would resurrect the discredited ethanol bounty after what happened to your people in estimates last year. The Senate may recall what happened in, I think, the 1993 budget. As a deal between the Democrats and the past Labor government, to pass legislation through, the government agreed to introduce an ethanol bounty.

ANSWER.PARA: It was found on a proper scientific investigation that the ethanol bounty scheme was a failure on all counts. I could not help but notice either pre or post the last budget that Senator Kernot said they would support any move that had shown something had not worked—or words to that effect. This was one that had not worked, and we had no option but to remove the ethanol bounty.

The ERDC had an amount of $2 million which remained in the budget to be matched by industry in regard to a pilot plant. We decided to hold off that amount of money until a research program being conducted by ERDC was completed, because it seemed pretty silly to go down the track of the pilot plant without the completion of the research program. If my memory serves me correctly, that research is due to be completed in either 1998 or 1999—one of those two years.

Last year cash reserves of the ERDC were taken back, and the amount that was going to be used for the plant which had been postponed was transferred to ERDC in case they needed it. I am led to believe—in fact, I was advised of this only a few days ago—that that money was in fact never taken up by the ERDC. It was not required for their ongoing programs. It will be earmarked and continue to be earmarked for the pilot plant at the completion of the research program. If, at the end of the research program, the information provided indicates that it is not a worthwhile proposition, it will have to be reconsidered then. But it is earmarked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. Obviously, I refute your claim that the program was discredited. The situation is to the contrary. You should talk to your own backbencher who is the member for that area. She will set you straight. Minister, is it not true that the Prime Minister in fact gave a commitment to the ethanol industry that the $2 million earmarked for the ethanol pilot plant at Nowra would be released? When does the government plan to keep that commitment of the Prime Minister?

—I thought I made it very clear that the $2 million sits there. It needs to be matched by industry. There was great difficulty in getting that matching grant from industry in any case, but there is a research program going on by ERDC. That money will not be used for the construction of a pilot plant until the completion of that research program.

—My question is directed to you, Madam President. In the second Senate investigation into Senator Colston's abuse of travelling allowance dated 14 March 1997, Mr Graeme Holt, the Assistant Director of Financial Management in the Senate, stated that `there are a number of potential irregularities on which the department is awaiting further advice from DAS'. As these irregularities are in addition to those already tabled in the Senate, is it your intention to table details of these irregularities and Senator Colston's reply to them? If that is not the case, why not? What will be the status of any report or advice that emanates from them?

—If any further report comes to me from the Senate on any further work done for either the records of the Senate or the records supplied by the Department of Administrative Services to the Senate, then any of that information received by me will of course be made available to Senator Colston to reply to and subsequently made available to the Senate.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for your response. I understand that, in relation to these matters and given the comment from Mr Holt, of course the Senate department is awaiting further advice from the Department of Administrative Services. Does your answer go to that Department of Administrative Services advice also?

—If I understand that supplementary question correctly, I am not aware of any further information that has come from the Department of Administrative Services to the Senate. But I shall certainly inquire as to whether or not that is the case and let you know.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer the minister to the historic pas sage of the telecommunications reform package in the Senate last night and I ask the minister to describe the tangible benefits which will flow to business in general, in particular business in the bush, from increased competition in the telecommunications industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that, as a result of the legislation that finally passed through the Senate last night, Australian consumers have a great deal to look forward to from the new telecommunications liberalised regime which will operate from 1 July. Indeed, it will certainly mean that we will see a lot more competition, particularly outside the capital cities. We are already starting to see that in places such as Ballarat.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt it will occur. It is very clear that the United States experience has been that companies targeting particular regional areas have been able to come up with packaged telephony proposals. People who are telephone integrators who are able to offer one-stop facilities will no doubt apply the same strategies here.

It is quite clear that some of the real benefits that flowed from yesterday's package will include the new price cap regime, which is where we had to save Senator Schacht from himself. Quite clearly, a weighted average cost approach is much more sensible.

It is very regrettable that the opposition seems to have not the slightest interest in these matters. If Senator Faulkner thinks he has to get instructions from Ian Healy over there every time he goes out to bat, then quite clearly the Labor Party is exposed as a party bereft of any interest in real policy issues and is simply interested in gimmicks, in political gutter crawling, in trawling through the minutiae of the matters that they have been dealing with in recent times and not showing any sensible interest.

If the political strategy on the part of Mr Healy over there involves simply trying to devise the latest one-liners and political gimmicks and not addressing these historic benefits, then I have no doubt that the Australian public will see the Labor Party for what it is: a party bereft of any interest in policy issues, not interested in the bush, not interested in ensuring that digital data capabilities are extended to 96 per cent of the population by the end of 1998 or indeed a target set for 100 per cent by 1 January 2000.

These are all major initiatives. The right to untimed local calls being extended to include business, voice and residential data calls, and consumer consultation on industry codes of practice are very significant advances that will be very much to the benefit of consumers. I hope that the Labor Party will realise that they are going nowhere when they pursue all these other irrelevancies. They think that political strategy involves simply trying to distract the public's attention. They should not worry about these issues because these are what will make Australia great again. These are the things that can really open up the markets and provide jobs and opportunities for small business to ensure that the bush gets a fair go.

I hope that we will be able to get back to the real agendas and that we will not have any more of this cheap grandstanding and political gutter crawling all the time, relying on leaks, peddling all those matters that are designed to distract attention from your policy bankruptcy. The public will have no doubt about where you stand when it comes to the next election because you are wasting valuable time. You could be doing some policy work but you are not interested in it. Therefore, it will be up to us to ensure that new jobs are created for the bush and small business as a result of this regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, can you confirm the report in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday that Mr Max Moore-Wilton, the Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, has approved for himself a tax free allowance which includes a component for accommodation of $17,000 a year? Can you inform the Senate of the components of other allowances that Mr Moore‐Wilton has afforded himself: that is, meals and incidental expenses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a note on that yesterday because I thought the Labor Party might be on the job and might ask the question the day it was reported.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Carr.

—As I recall, the advice that I had yesterday was that the payments are in accordance with usual practices for a temporary deployment. There is nothing unusual at all in this matter. Therefore, there is nothing for you to be particularly disturbed about.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I suggest that Senator Hill should read the report in full. It is also asserted in the Sydney Morning Herald that SES officers are generally expected to make a personal contribution to their temporary accommodation allowance. Mr Max Moore‐Wilton has not. On what basis has he exempted himself from that obligation?

—As I understand it, he did not exempt himself from anything. As I recall, he did not make the determination. I will check on that but my advice is, as I said to you a moment ago, that he is being paid in accordance with usual practice. I can give you a list of other temporary deployments who have been paid on a similar basis.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and refers to the Wik decision. Minister, can you give a guarantee that mining companies will be required to treat pastoralists equally with native title claimants or holders in respect of all negotiating rights?

—Yes, and I acknowledge Senator Boswell's continuing interest and concern in relation to this very important matter. As I have said—and I think this is the third question I have answered from Senator Boswell in relation to this matter—the Wik decision raised a number of difficult issues that require resolution. The government is still consulting with all interested parties in the development of its response to the Wik decision. The government will make a fair and considered response which will be thorough and timely. No options have been ruled out and no decisions have yet been made.

BREAK.PARA: For those interested, the Prime Minister met with farmers, miners and ATSIC representatives at the Lodge last Sunday, and he is expected to meet with indigenous leaders again later today. One very important issue is the question of an appropriate future acts regime to apply on pastoral leases, in particular in relation to exploration and mining. The Prime Minister and the government are very conscious of the pastoralists' expectation that they be treated equitably in relation to this particular issue.

The government will give careful consideration to the pastoralists' position in developing its proposals for an equitable regime for the approval of future acts on pastoral leases. As the Prime Minister has indicated, any response cannot be for the government alone but will involve the states and territories in recognition of their land management responsibilities. It is critical that a decision be made that provides a stable foundation for economic development. At the end of the day, all interest groups may need to compromise for the national good.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, do you recall your statement on the Meet the Press program on 16 March this year in which you claimed that Radio Australia operated a declining technology and that `even Foreign Affairs has very serious question marks about the effectiveness of the service'? Can you confirm that the Minister for Foreign Affairs wrote to you on 2 February this year—that is obviously prior to 16 March—expressing concern at the failure of the Mansfield inquiry to take proper account of the genuine foreign and trade policy implications of the closure of Radio Australia?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it true that the foreign minister advised you that Radio Australia is a cost effective means of projecting a positive image of Australia and of countering negative images which have been reinforced in our region by last year's racism debate? Did the foreign minister also highlight the effectiveness of Radio Australia in supporting the marketing of our education services in tourism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not here to publicly canvass private correspondence. What I am here to do is to regret the fact that Senator Forshaw appears not to have read—
—You have just misled.
—Listen, son, you're on very shaky ground at the moment.
—I am not `son' and I am not on shaky ground.
—If you want a character reference, we will give it to you. We are barracking hard for you. We want to see you preselected because you are doing a great job for us right where you are.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Forshaw had read the Mansfield report, on pages 41 and 42 he would see the reservations that were expressed by the department of foreign affairs. They made it clear that they had significant doubts about the effectiveness of the service. They said that a number of matters needed to be addressed. As we know, they have never at any stage—
Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you interested in Radio Australia? You would not know how to spell it. Get back to North Korea.
—Senator Alston, I invite you to answer Senator Forshaw's question and direct your remarks to me and ignore interjections.

—What Mansfield did was indicate that short wave is a declining technology. The figures quoted in that report, I think, underline that fact. As Senator Forshaw well knows, the department of foreign affairs has consistently declined opportunities to be forthcoming with funding to support the service. It ought to be quite clear that it is one thing to point to what the BBC world service does and to perhaps stand on the sidelines and say, `Wouldn't it be nice if we were able to maintain the status quo?' The fact is that it costs in excess of $20 million a year.

ANSWER.PARA: If the ABC is to meet its budget reduction of $55 million, as you well know, the $28 million from the One ABC policy, announced in December last year, goes about halfway towards meeting that target. If you want to argue that somehow you ought to preserve Radio Australia in its entirety and, as a result, force the ABC to discontinue a number of programs, to slash and burn in regional Australia, to cut back dramatically on news and current affairs, then it is a very interesting set of priorities that you have, because I do not think the Australian public agree with that.

The Australian public wants the Mansfield report adopted. It wants guarantees of entrenchment in relation to news and current affairs, rural and remote services and children's television. It wants all of those built into the charter, which you have consistently refused to do and which Mansfield says is well overdue. I am delighted that Senator Schacht has finally come around to the party. He is obviously having a big lie down after last night's debate. The fact is that the ALP has belatedly realised that the ABC is vulnerable unless the charter entrenches those sorts of protections.

If you are going to entrench them, the money has to be there to deliver the goods. If you want to see Radio Australia preserved at the cost of $20 million, then you are inevitably going to force the ABC to get into slash and burn mode for the rest of its services. That is not what we want to see happen. That is not what the Australian community wants to see happen. Indeed, they want it fully protected. So you cannot have it both ways. You have to be a bit responsible. I am delighted you are chairing the committee, and it is a pity you could not get yourself a proper time frame that would have enabled you to give us some recommendations that were relevant to the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a liar.

—The fact is that you still have an obligation to look at this issue in a responsible fashion and decide what the priorities ought to be. If you think they are offshore rather than domestic, you are right out of touch.
—Senator Faulkner, would you withdraw that remark?
—I withdraw, Madam President.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is Radio Australia that is on shaky ground here because of the decisions of your government to rip $55 million out of the ABC budget. What you have done is you have given Radio Australia a death sentence and then said, `What do you want—death by hanging or death by a firing squad?' Minister, the point is that Minister Downer wrote to you on 2 February. Given that Mr Downer had already written to you on 2 February expressing his serious concerns, why did you—assuming you were aware of the letter—make the comments that you did on the Meet the Press program on 16 March? Minister, did you read the letter from Mr Downer—and I point out that it is now available on the Internet so, if you would like to go surfing, you will find it there—or is it the case that you treated Mr Downer like the rest of your colleagues treat him; that is, you just did not take him or his letter seriously?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very cheap and sleazy comment. It is clearly contrary to standing orders. I think, as I have already said, what you would expect a responsible government to do is to canvass a number of important issues between ministers and to make sure that all the arguments stack up before the decisions are taken.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of colleagues that need to be consulted in respect of decisions of this significance and, quite clearly, I respect Mr Downer's views. He has a very important role to play in judging Australia's place in the region. But that does not give you the sort of glib answer that you want.

The fact is that there are people in the region who can get access to information, news and current affairs, that was undreamed of when short wave was in its prime. It has been declining consistently over the last 15 years, as Mansfield points out, and there are other means of ensuring that people are able to get access to the information they require. (Time expired)

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

What is the rationale for the government's decision and what impact will it have on our relations with our Asian neighbours?
—It will have no impact, but I would like to get a full—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the additional information I have for Senator Murphy, Mr Moore-Wilton's terms and conditions are consistent with those for secretaries appointed for fixed terms. In accepting a fixed term appointment, he is not required to permanently relocate to Canberra.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Moore-Wilton receives temporary accommodation allowance, which is calculated in accordance with Public Service Board determination No. 46 of 1984. This determination relates to SES officers but, because there are no specific regulations for secretaries, it is also applied to secretaries as a guide. The rationale is that secretaries' allowances should at the minimum be consistent with those for SES officers.

The components of Mr Moore-Wilton's TAA are: reimbursement of accommodation, $330 per week; meals allowance, $192.40 per week; and incidentals allowance, $41.30 per week. The accommodation component is the exact cost of rental of a two bedroom apart ment in Canberra. The meals and incidental expenses allowances are set by the Department of Industrial Relations and apply to all SES officers and above. Clause 3.6 of PSB determination No. 46 of 1984 specifies that the amount of TAA may be increased commensurate with reasonable expenses incurred by Mr Moore-Wilton.

In relation to accommodation, staff from the appropriate area of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet undertook a detailed examination of various accommodation options in the inner Canberra area, involving contact with all major real estate experts. Based on this examination, the relevant staff considered it reasonable to reimburse Mr Moore-Wilton the full cost of his rental accommodation. The responsibility for approval resides within each department.

Mr Moore-Wilton is not required to make an officer contribution. The facts as set out in clause 3.9 of PSB determination No. 46 of 1984 were considered in determining that no officer contribution was required in Mr Moore-Wilton's circumstances. Mr Moore-Wilton does not retain any of the rental allowance. Mr Moore-Wilton retains his normal residence for his wife and family in Sydney on a continuing basis and does not, of course, receive travelling allowance when in Sydney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to questions without notice asked by Senator Sherry today, relating to the superannuation surcharge.

Tomorrow we are to consider the government's major budget revenue raising measure—a new half a billion dollar tax a year on superannuation. Two weeks ago, Mr Rose QC, on behalf of the Business Council of Australia, submitted legal advice to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation saying that—and this is paraphrasing him—clause 34 of that package of legislation was invalid under the constitution. It was invalid because it imposed a tax—and he called it a tax—indirectly on fund members through the superannuation funds.

BREAK.PARA: This was a basic flaw in the legislation—and I hope that Senator Kemp is listening to this. What happened? That night, Senator Kemp, and, the next morning, Mr Costello, the Treasurer, and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) all rushed to defend the constitutional basis of the legislation. They all rushed into the media, saying, `Look, there is nothing wrong with our legislation. We have taken into account the similar legal advice that Mr Rose submitted to the Senate select committee. There is no need to be concerned. We have got it right. Our legislation is constitutional. There is no cause for concern.'

And what happens? Last Thursday, the government rushes amendments into the House of Representatives to take care of the problem that Mr Rose QC had identified. The government rushes amendments into the House of Representatives to delete, amongst other areas, that clause 34 which goes to the heart of the problem of the constitutionality of the government's proposed new tax on superannuation.

What did the government do? Did they say, `Oh, we got it wrong. We are sorry.'? Did they publicly acknowledge that they accepted that the superannuation so‐called surcharge bills were defective constitutionally? No, they did it on the quiet. They rushed it in last Thursday and they did not put out any press release acknowledging that they had got it wrong. They had to rewrite their legislation to minimise its chance of being challenged in the High Court. That could have overthrown that new tax of half a billion dollars a year.

This is not the first time there has been a major problem with this government's package of legislation. The package of bills was tabled on 13 February. We have had assurance after assurance from Senator Kemp, when he can answer a question, and assurance after assurance from Mr Costello, Mr Fahey and the Prime Minister himself that this legislation is okay—it is fair and it is reasonable. They continue to refute the arguments that we have put in criticism of the effects of this new tax legislation. They continue to say there is no major problem, it is fair legislation, despite the fact that we have been raising for some months what we believe are quite legitimate criticisms of the legislation, in addition to the constitutionality issue.

Senator Kemp, I do wish you would stay and listen because if only you had listened after the bills were tabled on 13 February, if only you had listened to what we were advising and if only you would listen to what everyone else is advising. It is not just we, Senator Kemp, who have been raising problems about this new tax. It is everyone else in the superannuation community: the accountants, the lawyers and the superannuation funds. Everyone has been raising problems about this new superannuation tax.

As I said, it is not the first time. The government rushed in additional bills to exempt federal judges after 13 February. They had discovered they had another problem. Then the second problem: they forgot to include the tax in its application to federal government employees. The third problem was that they had to rush in amendments to deal with the constitutional problems. And today we have identified a fourth major problem: in its rush, the government has neglected, or forgotten, because of its general incompetence to amend section 58 of the superannuation industry supervisory act. The effect of that is that employers will have to pay the tax themselves on defined benefit funds, or trustees will have to collect the tax on the earnings of all fund members in order to pay the tax.

Senator Ferguson is going to speak. Senator Kemp is not here. Senator Ferguson, through the chair I challenge you: I bet, on behalf of the opposition, you will have to move amendments to deal with these particular problems we have raised today—amendments created by your own government's incompetence. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Day after day we have heard Senator Sherry misrepresent the government's position in this place. I have heard Senator Sherry make some rather outlandish claims in the last few days, and it is just utter nonsense that he is speaking now. He does not even listen to what the minister has said in answer to his questions. I have heard Senator Sherry say that we used to have a bipartisan approach to superannuation. Senator Sherry's idea of a bipartisan approach is that, as long as everybody agrees with the Labor Party's position, that is a bipartisan approach. That is a bipartisan approach, according to Senator Sherry, and so we hear him say there has been a breakdown of a bipartisan approach.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry, you talk about amendments being secret or of not being told about amendments. Wasn't the amendment taken around to your office, from Senator Kemp's office, so that you could have a look yourself? Wasn't the amendment taken around? It is all very well for you not to listen now when you choose not to, but you stood up in this chamber and made statements which bore no relevance to the answer that was given.

You raised the issue of the validity of the surcharge legislation and the evidence that was given before our committee by Mr Dennis Rose. On that particular occasion when Mr Rose gave that advice to the committee, the Attorney-General's Department advised that they believe that the surcharge legislation, as it was originally drafted, is valid under the constitution. This still remains their opinion after Mr Rose's opinion. It still remains their opinion, but it is only an opinion. You know yourself that when it is only a government's opinion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Any lawyer's opinion is only an opinion.

—Of course it is an opinion, Senator Collins. So, to remove any chance of there being a constitutional challenge to that position, the legislation will be amended to make sure that it does not happen. That does not say that Mr Rose's opinion is right. All it says is that it will remove any chance of there being a constitutional—
—You're scared.

—It is not a matter of being scared, Senator Conroy. It is a matter of making sure that there is no constitutional challenge, because, where there is one opinion from the Attorney-General's Department, there are bound to be other legal opinions which would state a different point of view. For that reason, so as to remove any possible doubt about this legislation's constitutional validity, the surcharge legislation has been amended to remove proposed clause 34.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these things have only been done in response to evidence that was given to our committee, evidence that was heard by the superannuation select committee when it was reviewing this legislation. Until Mr Rose had put that position—his opinion—to the committee, there had been no doubts expressed about the validity of the surcharge legislation in relation to the proposed clause 34. Mr Rose's opinion was no knockout blow as far as this legislation is concerned—none whatsoever.

Governments must take every step to make sure that they do not leave themselves open to a challenge, whether that challenge succeeds or not. You have been in government before, Senator Collins and others, and you know yourself that you must take every precaution to make sure that you do not leave any chance or any option available for people to challenge any constitutional validity relying on an opinion.

In regard to this surcharge legislation, we have heard Senator Sherry come in here, day after day, asking a series of questions. When Senator Sherry is not here he gets Senator Conroy to ask his questions. I am not sure whether they are his questions or the questions of former senator Susan Ryan, but in fact they are questions that have been put. A lot of these issues have been raised by ASFA in their own efforts to thwart this legislation and its passage through the Senate.

Let me say that Senator Sherry can continue, day after day, as long as he likes with these points that he tries to raise. But in regard to the surcharge legislation and in regard to its validity, the action that the government has taken in making sure that it does not allow for any challenge to the constitutional validity of this legislation is the way that this government sees fit to go, because it does not want, at any stage, to leave a position open where there might be the slightest chance of anybody challenging this legislation or its constitutional validity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Ferguson got the opportunity to stand up on his feet. I hope when the preselectors in the South Australian Liberal Party get to hear his sterling performance defending the indefensible, they will know they have a quality member to vote for!

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I want to take up the issue of constitutionality. Senator Ferguson well knows that not only have the government capitulated to Dennis Rose's opinion but also they still have got to get, from the states, agreement, because they also have admitted in the press release of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) himself that they have constitutional difficulties with the states. They have not been able to get any agreement.

Last Friday, we had the state premiers in town for the Premiers Conference. It ended again, as it had the year before, as a shambles—no agreement, no press release and no press conference at the end to announce that they had solved their problems with the unconstitutionality of taxing the state MPs, state judges and state public servants. Where is the big press release being waved around saying that they have fixed the constitutionality problems?

It is disappointing to see the government's attitude to ASFA. I long remember the previous opposition complaining about how harsh our government was towards interest groups that they perceived to have been opposed to our position. Now, because the head of ASFA is a former member of this chamber, we have a vindictive campaign being run out by the government that she is just doing the Labor Party's bidding, and vice versa. What you have is the industry up in arms about this surcharge legislation. It is a joke. It is a shambles. The only defence that the government are prepared to trot out in this chamber is `It's just Sue Ryan.' It is a disgrace that they are not prepared to debate the issues and it is a disgrace that they want to personalise the serious constitutional flaws in this bill down to `It's just Sue Ryan doing the job for the Labor Party.' It is a disgrace.

We come back to the tax file number question. We had evidence before the committee that as few as one per cent in some funds actually should incur the surcharge, with incomes over $70,000. At best estimates—the best estimate from all the people who came before the committee—30 per cent of tax file numbers could be collected in the first 12 months. AMP, a private organisation as opposed to an industry fund—Senator Ferguson, during the committee, suggested that industry funds needed to get closer to their members and that if they were closer to their members they would be able to collect the tax file numbers—gave evidence that the best they were going to do was 12 per cent.

This means that an organisation like the TWU super fund, which made a submission to the committee, will have to keep an extra $7 million of members' funds in the cash part of their investment portfolio. That is way more than they would normally keep. They estimate that this will reduce returns to members by one per cent. That is right, senators. Each individual member of the TWU fund—I am one, I have to announce—will be one per cent worse off because of this surcharge legislation—that is, the 99 per cent who should never have to incur any cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the ones under $70,000.
—Ninety‐nine per cent of them, Senator Bob Collins, who are under $70,000. Every one is going to be one per cent worse off in returns because of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the question of the money not being in the accounts of the 70 per cent who will be hit by the surcharge because they have not supplied their tax file number. What will happen? The government will say, `Well, they'll get the money back; maybe not in the first year and maybe not in the second year, but eventually they will get the money back.' The fact is that the money will not have been in their accounts, so it has not been earning interest. Is there any suggestion that the tax office will pay back the loss of interest? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the motion moved by Senator Sherry to take note of Senator Kemp's answers to the questions put to him with regard to the superannuation tax. Quite clearly we are looking at a situation where the government has painted itself so firmly into a corner that it is now trying quite desperate tactics to manoeuvre itself out of that corner. The first point that is worthy of making is that it has become clear that, in persisting with this ridiculous situation of calling the tax a surcharge, the government has got itself embroiled in a constitutional debacle. We are seeing it played out day by day.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp today refused quite specifically to rule out any future changes to the act. He knew that the minute the government refused to call it a tax it would be stuck in a corner calling it a surcharge. The government has run into constitutional problems that it cannot get away from. The justification for this particular tax is, firstly, calling it a surcharge. They are calling it an `imposition upon higher income earners'. They are saying that that means it is somehow a fairer imposition and that it redistributes the wealth with respect to superannuation. I put this to the government: if your only justification for this tax is that it is more equitable for lower income earners, why is the price being paid by the very low to middle income earners who are currently participating in industry funds?

We have just heard very clearly from Senator Conroy how this cost is transferred across all participants in an industry fund. It is borne by the low to middle income earners of that fund, not just the high to middle income earners. The key is in the process that the government is advocating to collect the tax: that process means that the super funds will do it themselves. The cost imposition upon the industry funds in collecting this tax will impinge on their ability to get the resources to get the letters out, and so forth. I know that one industry fund alone has estimated the cost at $300 million. The fact is that this high cost will spread across all the funds. Regardless of the issue of the cash reserve that Senator Conroy spoke about, returns to all members will be reduced by one per cent. Charges and fees to the funds may well have to be addressed to cover the cost imposition of implementing the process.

In the scheme of things, you do not need to look much further to see what message is being sent to the general community about superannuation. It has already been pointed out today that one of the great successes of Labor's superannuation policy was its provision of a secure place for people to invest their money for their retirement. People could invest their money in industry super schemes and be confident that their income would not tampered with. This tax undermines consumer confidence in the superannuation product generally. Let us face it: super was always the bag of the higher income earners—they have always utilised superannuation. Labor took super to low and middle income earners. I have no doubt—this view was expressed by a number of witnesses at the superannuation select committee hearings—that higher income earners will find a way to avoid this tax, so once again the middle to low income earners who remain in the industry super schemes will be the ones who bear the burden.

Who can blame the Australian community for starting to question the security of their investment in such funds when the government is showing quite clearly that it is prepared to fiddle around with the taxation rules on superannuation? In this case it might in respect to higher income earners, but what happens next? What happens when those higher income earners depart the funds and the middle and lower income earners are left carrying the burden? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to a question without notice asked by Senator Murray today, relating to access to finance in the small business sector.

I want to draw attention to a real problem we have had—that is, consistently, Senator Parer has not responded to both the intent and the content of the question. I will deal with the intent first. The intent of the Australian Democrats is to raise issues which are of fundamental importance not only to our constituency but also to larger constituencies within society.

Today I raised the question of the interest rates that small business do not enjoy—in other words, the same competitive interest rates of large business. My concerns were prompted by an article which I saw in the Economist on 19 February 1997. That article listed the following 15 countries in the OECD: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United States. You will recognise in those names some of the strongest and most sophisticated industrial countries in this world. Thirteen of those 15 countries had lower prime business lending rates than Australia.

We have identified that small business experiences interest rates of two to three per cent higher, on average, than large business. I do not believe that the government would not prefer small business to have lower rates. The problem that the government faces is that, whilst it is no skin off their nose for a small business to get a better deal on bank rates, it is skin off the nose of big business—namely, the banks. It is the banks who benefit from those high interest rates. It is also the banks which pour exceptionally large sums of money into the political donation coffers of the coalition parties. The consequence of that is that you have a conflict of interest. Whilst I accept that you do want to advance the interests of small business, you are unable to do so because of your ties with big business and, in this instance, banks.

What I am urging the government to do is to put your money where your mouth is. If you are genuinely concerned about small business and the issue which is of fundamental importance to them, as all surveys have shown, you should act and intervene through the Wallis inquiry and other mechanisms to force a lowering of real interest rates for small business. Small business fundamentally needs access to cheap and readily available finance. That is the issue. That is what I wanted a response to from Senator Parer. I did not get a response.

We have to have regard to the fact that the government's very welcome announcement yesterday on a number of small business areas which matter to small business does not go far enough. It does not address any of the big ticket items. Every one of the big ticket items is where the coalition finds there is a conflict with big business. That is on the issue of finance availability, cost of finance, the franchising issue, the unconscionable conduct issue and the cuts to business programs. It is all about relationships which you have not yet had the courage to tackle.

You have shown as a government that you have a hard edge in some areas. We in the Australian Democrats are saying that you should pay attention to those areas which small business is crying out for, particularly the cost of credit, which you have not yet addressed. Whilst we warmly welcomed yesterday many of the aspects of your first small business package, we say to you that it is too limited, it does not go far enough and it does not attack the big business items which matter.

We regard the pricing by banks as having been predatory and continuing to be predatory for small business. We regard the control by franchisors over franchisees as predatory. We regard the collapse of the franchising code as absolutely dangerous to small business. We believe that petroleum markets continue to be rigged with the support of the coalition. We believe that the horizontal concentration in our society damages small business. We believe that the coalition support for the nature of trading hours is an abuse of small business. We believe that the commercial tenancy issues result in domination by lessors. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
