PETITION.TITLE: Euthanasia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that euthanasia is the actual intervention by another to end a human life. It is neither curing nor a therapy. It destroys a human life.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
(a) Recognise that euthanasia is not an issue which can be dealt with adequately by the States or Territories;
(b) listen to the public, doctors, health carers and religious organisations who are against euthanasia;
(c) legislate to prevent euthanasia being carried out in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government honour its commitment to the Higher Education sector as stated in the Liberal and National Parties' Higher Education Policy.
We demand the Australian Government:
Review the Actual Means Test for Austudy.
Raise the level of Austudy above the poverty line.
Lower the age of independence to 21.
Review the differential HECS.
Abolish up‐front fees for undergraduate places.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned request the Australian Senate implements the following:
A Senate enquiry into the use of genetic engineering in the Australian Food Supply, including the ethics of its use.
That consultations be undertaken with the general public to ask if we want this technology in our food supply and consent to its use.
That consumers be resourced to attend these consultations.
Any food that is genetically engineered or contains components that are genetically engineered are required to be labelled, including the origin of the genes.
That meaningful right to know legislation be enacted to guarantee public access to toxicology data.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 65th report of the Committee of Privileges titled Person referred to in the Senate (Dr Neil Cherry) .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

This report is the 23rd in a series of reports recommending that a right of reply be accorded to a person who claims to have been adversely affected by being referred to in the Senate. On 5 March 1997, the President received a letter from Dr Neil Cherry relating to remarks made by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) during question time the same day.

The President referred the letter to the committee as a submission under privilege resolution 5. The committee subsequently received a substantive submission from Dr Cherry, which it recommends be incorporated in Hansard. As the committee always reminds the Senate, in matters of this nature it does not judge the truth or otherwise of statements made by honourable senators or persons. Rather, it ensures that a person's submission, and ultimately the response it recommends, accord with the criteria set out in privilege resolution 5. The committee again commends the right of reply procedure as an inexpensive and readily available remedy available to an aggrieved person. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the Senate Dr Neil Cherry's right of reply has been tabled by the Privileges Committee, and it is to be incorporated in Hansard . This right of reply has been afforded Dr Cherry after the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) called this highly credentialled, independent academic scientists `a shameless charlatan' two weeks ago when Dr Cherry was here in Canberra. He was here for the purpose of addressing parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to firstly point out to the Senate that this treatment of Dr Cherry was not some wild outburst by the minister. Rather, it is symptomatic of a mind‐set which is now reflected in an organised campaign by governments here and elsewhere and the telecommunications industry in order to deny that there might be any health effects of electromagnetic radiation. It is as reactionary as it is irresponsible, and it is irresponsible because it is insistently and ludicrously defensive.

When I came to the Senate I expected to find a place in which minds would be open. I expected that parliamentarians would want to be as fully informed as possible on all manner of issues, and to some degree I think this is true. It is the basis on which the Senate operates. We take issues and legislation to Senate committees in order that we can be better informed.

Why is it, then, that the matter of electromagnetic radiation and the research around the world which shows that it can affect human biology, even at extremely low frequencies, should raise such protests of denial? Why is it that scientists such as Dr Neil Cherry are so loudly decried? Why is it that Minister Alston chose to do this when he had not met Dr Cherry, he had not come along to hear what Dr Cherry had to say and, I must presume, he had not read the material from which Dr Cherry quotes? I also presume that he has not had discussions with eminent researchers around the world, as has Dr Cherry.

As Dr Cherry demonstrates by his reply, he is a totally independent academic scientist, employed by Lincoln University in New Zealand. He receives no financial support for his research other than his university study leave and his own personal resources. He cannot be accused of looking for funding, and he has nothing to gain from either his own work or the dissemination of material produced by other researchers.

Dr Cherry is nothing if not a serious, highly qualified scientist with an abiding interest in the protection of public health. In his answer not only does he prove his eminence in terms of scientific qualifications and their relevance to this area; he demonstrates without question his standing in the scientific community, both here and overseas. He is no more a snake oil merchant than Senator Alston is the magic fairy. Senator Alston said in this house that there was absolutely no evidence to support the scaremongering campaign that he thinks Dr Cherry and no doubt the Australian Democrats have been conducting.

The truth is that there is an immense amount of published scientific research showing many non-thermal effects of radiofrequency/microwave radiation at the cellular level, including cell cycle alteration, calcium ion efflux, altered DNA synthesis, single and double strand DNA breakage, altered lymphocyte activity, altered cell membrane permeability, altered cellular signal transduction, to name but a few. I intend to keep the Senate informed on developments in this research from time to time, but there is already such a body of evidence that many weeks would not be adequate to outline the work that is already available.

Electromagnetic radiation is shown to reduce the production of pineal melatonin, which is a clear and direct plausible mechanism for increased cancer risk, sleep disruption, chronic fatigue disorder and reduced immune system competence. Live animal experiments have found all of these cellular changes and many more. Senators should also know that the incidence of brain tumours and breast cancers is increasing. Every year there is an increase of one per cent in brain tumours.

If the minister and this government is at all interested in the health and safety of Australians, it should be asking why. It should not be putting its collective head in the sand alongside an industry and refusing to examine the evidence which is before it. I encountered this kind of closed mind when I visited the Telstra Research Laboratory last year. Here I spoke to people who called themselves scientists but spent all their time defending a position and attempting to discredit anything which appeared to challenge that position.

I am no scientist, but I can recognise a closed mind when I see one. Good science, and good government for that matter, is open. If one thing is true it is the axiom that the more we know the more we know we do not know. I suggest to the minister that he does not know it all, that none of us does. The only way to learn, however, is to be unafraid to learn the truth, to open your mind to new information. That may not be the way in which a barrister prefers to see the world.

Shifting one's view according to the evidence presented may not be Minister Alston's modus operandi, but I put it to senators that in government ministers have a greater responsibility than to defend their position or the status quo or a powerful industry. They have a responsibility to act in the interests of the people of Australia.

Dr Cherry has been at all times dignified and generous in his reaction to the intemperate ravings of the minister. He says that the minister's problems have as much to do with the quality of the advice he receives as any other factor. He says the minister should look at his officials and the type of advice he is receiving. We need an open, constructive, scientific exchange—not the issue being taken into personality politics.

Dr Cherry says the key point about the minister's outburst is that he had not challenged the science. Senator Alston should apologise to Dr Cherry. I suggest that the time has come to put aside party allegiances and petty politics, name‐calling and defensive positions, and to not just challenge the science but act with some urgency to see that the science is put into service in the interests of increasing our knowledge and making us as parliamentarians better able to act in the interests of all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response as recommended by the committee incorporated in Hansard accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: The response read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF 28 FEBRUARY 1988

SPEECH.PARA: In the Australian Senate on 5th March 1997, Senator Alston, Minister for Communications and the Arts, said:

"At lunch time today, Senator Kernot introduced a shameless charlatan by the name of Dr Neil Cherry in relation to the emerging research on EMR. . . . This bloke is a charlatan. His biographical details start off with mindless and irrelevant gobbledygook."
Senator Alston also referred to a New Zealand Environment Court case about a mobile phone base station in which I was involved, stating:
"What he does not . . . say is that his side lost [the case] and he was discredited by the courts."
He also says it is "dangerous . . . to associate" with me because I am a "snake oil merchant".
These statements not only suggest that the information I am distributing is of questionable scientific merit, but that I may receive an illicit benefit from doing so.

I am a totally independent academic scientist employed by Lincoln University in New Zealand, an institution which is held in very high regard, both nationally and internationally. I have received no financial remuneration for my research into EMR effects to date, in fact my recent international study tour was funded partly by my university's study leave fund ($9,000), partly by the conference leave fund ($2,448) and largely by personal finance raised through a mortgage on our house ($18,000). I have appeared for residents in the Environment Court and in many Resource Consent Hearings and received no remuneration, not even for travel costs in these cases.

Three years ago when asked about this issue I openly and publicly stated that while I knew of no scientific evidence at that time to suggest adverse effects, I urged a precautionary approach, especially in relation to children, pregnant women, the frail elderly and the sick, since they would be more vulnerable than the average healthy adult to the effects of environmental contaminants and toxins.

I now have nearly three decades of preparation including advanced education in classical physics at the University of Canterbury, involving electricity and magnetism, radiation physics, the effects of microwaves on the physical properties of crystals and the use of pulsed microwaves for probing the atmosphere through using weather radar systems. This has given me an understanding of the production and transmission of pulsed and modulated radiofrequency and microwave emissions from radio, TV and mobile phones and base stations.

My research into air pollution began in 1972 at McGill University, Montreal. This, along with my research in climatology, involved the use of statistics which I later used in environmental epidemiological studies of the health effects of air pollution. This involved establishing statistically significant associations between exposure to atmospheric contaminants and increased risk of health effects. My research progression through Agricultural Meteorology (commenced in 1974) required the acquisition of biological understanding and concepts and my research into Human Biometeorology (commenced in about 1978) significantly increased my understanding of human physiology and brain function.

Thus, in 1994 I was very well placed to understand and integrate EMR research from physics, biophysics, biology, human physiology and epidemiology. What I lacked, and since have added, is an understanding of biochemistry. I have incorporated research into biochemistry for about 2 years, to complete the interdisciplinary suite of expertise required.

My professional standing and academic integrity has been recognised through my university by progressive promotion on merit to the top of the Senior Lecturer scale. I was elected by my fellow NZ meteorologists to be founding Vice President of the Meteorological Society of New Zealand and I am currently the elected National Chairperson of the Australia/New Zealand Solar Energy Society. I have been an elected Fellow of the Royal Meteorological Society since 1969 and am a professional member of several other learned societies which require a high standard of scientific ethics and performance for maintained membership status.

Internationally my expertise has been utilised by the World Bank, the Governments of the Netherlands and Sri Lanka and the United States Department of Energy through Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratories. I have been engaged as a professional consultant by Telecom (South Island), the Electrici ty Corporation of New Zealand, Horticultural Companies, Insurance Companies and New Zealand Crown Research Institutes.

Senator Alston referred to a New Zealand Environment Court case of a mobile phone base station in which I was the scientific team leader on behalf of residents in opposition to the site. He stated that I, and my team, were discredited because the court allowed the site to proceed.

Our team included Professor John Goldsmith, an internationally eminent Professor of Epidemiology from the Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Israel; and Associate Professor Richard Luben, University of California, Riverside and President of the International Bioelectromagnetics Society and member of several US federal standards committees. None of my team was required to retract any of our evidence under sustained cross‐examination. The expert witness for the applicant, Dr Michael Repacholi, however, was required to step back from a number of his statements, including an admission about a critical piece of evidence, that was only presented "with tongue in cheek".

While the base station was approved, it was subject to the tightest legally enforceable public exposure condition in the Western World, not exceeding 2 W/cm2 at the nearest dwelling. Our team welcomed this decision as a major step forward in the recognition of the appropriateness of limiting exposure to less than 1% of the current Australia/New Zealand public exposure standard.

The decision stated that at this level (2 W/cm2) they knew of no evidence of adverse effects, "even a potential effect of low probability and high potential impact", but that the condition should be reviewed with the availability of new evidence. I have concentrated since that time on collecting, analysing and reviewing this new and unpresented evidence in preparation for the next hearing of the Environment Court. It was a small portion of this evidence which I presented in my talk at Parliament House.

All of the evidence which I use is from internationally published material from reputable peer‐reviewed scientific journals and/or from reports from laboratories and universities of high international scientific standing. I have personally visited many of these institutions and discussed the research results with the original researchers.

My recent visits included the US EPA, Johns Hopkins University, University of Washington, University of North Carolina, Medical College of Virginia, University of California (Davis and Riverside) Loma Linda Veterans' Research Centre, Karolinska Institute, Medical University of Lubeck, University of Aberdeen.
Finally, Senator Alston claimed that "there is absolutely no evidence to support these scaremongering campaigns and they have been discredited in court." This statement is demonstrably untrue.

There is an immense amount of published scientific research showing many non‐thermal effects of radiofrequency/microwave radiation at the cellular level, including cell cycle alteration, calcium ion efflux, altered DNA synthesis, single and double‐strand DNA breakage, altered lymphocyte activity, altered cell membrane permeability, altered cellular cyclic AMP, enhanced Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC) activity and altered cellular signal transduction.

EMR is shown to reduce the production of Pineal Melatonin which is a clear and direct plausible mechanism for increased cancer risk, sleep disruption, chronic fatigue disorder and reduce immune system competence. Live animal experiments have found all of these cellular changes and many others.

Public health studies (epidemiological surveys) have found statistically significant associations in cancers at many sites in the body, sleep disruption, chronic fatigue syndrome, impairment of children's performance, miscarriage and birth defects, altered human EEG and circadian rhythm and several other adverse effects.

It appears likely that the Minister is making his statements in the Senate on the advice of his departmental officials and the staff of the Australian Radiation Laboratory since his statements are consistent with public statements of the members of the DOCA "EMR Road Show". Their statements include the claim that "there is no evidence of effects" or alternatively "no substantiated evidence of effects" and there have been many derogatory and potentially defamatory statements about my work, qualifications and statements.
In conclusion, although I regard the Minister's remarks as intemperate and unhelpful, I do not blame him, so much as regret the quality of the advice that he continues to receive from his department.
I thank the Senate for the opportunity to present this right of reply. I would be happy to make a substantial presentation of the evidence I have collected and reviewed perhaps to one of your Senate
Committees.
Dr Neil Cherry

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Faulkner, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That item 4 of the Childcare Assistance (Fee Relief) Guidelines Variation (CCA/12A/97/1), made under the Child Care Act 1974, be disallowed.

In speaking to this disallowance motion, I first want to declare an interest. I am a consumer of quality child care services in that my youngest son attends a centre for a couple of days a week. I think it is appropriate that I declare that interest. As a result of the government's initiatives, my fees have gone up recently in common with most child‐care consumers in the country.

I am very proud of the record of the previous Labor government in relation to child care. The Labor Party provided good quality, affordable and accessible child care in developing its policies over 13 years. It recognised that families had different needs and that those needs must be met by different kinds of assistance. I think it is a very proud record. Ministers like Senator Crowley and other ministers for child care deserve credit for the effort that they have made.

The Howard Liberal government came to power by espousing similar sentiments about the need for affordable, accessible and quality child care in our community. What we found out after their election was that there was no real commitment to those objectives and no real commitment to child care. What we saw in the last budget, the first Howard budget, was a cut of some $500 million out of programs of assistance for child care. There were cuts to capital funding for the 5,500 new places that were planned. The operational subsidy for community based child‐care centres was abolished. The maximum child‐care assistance was frozen for two years, but the minimum fees will continue to increase. The child‐care assistance income test cut‐offs for families with two or more children were reduced and the additional income disregard for children in the family under the child‐care assistance income test was abolished.

That whole package of changes introduced by the Howard government effectively took $500 million out of assistance for child care in this country. We have opposed those cuts at every opportunity. I am pleased to say that I think on all those occasions we have been joined by the Democrats and the Greens in arguing the case for quality and affordable child care in the Australian community. We tried to restore capital funding when we considered the appropriation bills, although I think the Democrats got a bit confused on that one.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your interpretation.

—I look forward to your explanation, Senator Woodley. We opposed the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill, which abolished operational subsidies for community based child‐care centres. We moved to disallow the instrument which gave effect to the government's cuts to child‐care assistance. We are trying to do that with this instrument: the last component in the government's package of cuts to child care.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite successfully moving an urgency motion in this chamber which expressed concern at the government's moves, we have been unable to gain the numbers to prevent these cuts to child care and these reductions in child‐care assistance. I think that is very disappointing for the Australian community and for the development of a proper child-care system in Australia.

This instrument, if allowed, would cap the number of eligible hours for child‐care assistance for each child at 50 hours. This is a quite difficult concept to come to terms with because it seems, on the face of it, fairly acceptable and because the arguments are fairly technical. Essentially, this measure takes a further $35 million away from child-care assistance to basically low income Australian families. It is the last step in the 1996 budget process of removal of assistance to Australian families. We estimate up to 27,000 hardworking Australian families will be directly affected by this particular cut.

As I have said, on the face of it, this measure seems fairly simple. The government will not be providing child‐care assistance for more than 50 hours of care. On the face of it, it seems a reasonable proposition that most families would not be needing more than 50 hours of care. But what it does not do is deal with the reality of the structure of child care and of funding and the organisation of child‐care centres in Australia. Anyone who has had any dealings with them will understand how they are structured.

Basically they are structured by providing a spread of hours available to parents to provide as much flexibility as possible for working families. The spread of hours might be from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. to allow for people who might be required to start work early or for people who might have to finish late and not be able to collect their children until much before 6 p.m. While each individual family may not require much more than 50 hours, the centre, in order to meet the needs of families, is open for a larger spread of hours.

The funding arrangements have generally been structured so that people pay on a per day fee. I think my childs centre currently charges $32 per day. It does not matter what time you bring the child in or take the child out of the centre, that is the fee for the day. That gives you the flexibility to drop the child off early, to collect them late or to collect them early if you have the opportunity to get off work earlier. So it provides flexibility and choice for families. That structure is provided by child-care centres to meet the needs of their client group: working families of Australia.

This measure basically provides that child-care centres have to either restructure their hours as a result of these changes, by providing a spread of only 10 hours a day—which clearly is not a practical solution, because not every family's needs will be the same—or pass on the costs to parents when they are open beyond 50 hours a week. So they will have to spread the impact of these costs across all the parents who use the centre. The government is not insisting on a strict fee for service solution by this measure. What it is doing is taking $35 million out of child-care funding and passing the costs back to parents.

In my own state I have had examples brought to my attention where child-care centres—largely those in the outer suburbs, where more travelling time is involved for parents—are being forced to pass on fee increases to parents in the order of $9.60, $10.10 and, in one private centre, $20 per week as a result of the changes that are proposed. Obviously, Madam Acting Deputy President Patterson, as you would be aware, those centres that operate in the outer suburbs usually provide for a greater spread of hours because they are catering for some parents who are commuting to work in the city and back. So they provide a spread of hours that recognises those needs of their client group.

BREAK.PARA: What this measure does is artificially impose a 10-hour day on the centres in terms of child‐care assistance provided. Therefore, it forces them either to restrict their hours, which clearly is not an appropriate response, or to increase their fees, which is the one that they are instituting.

I wanted to make the point very clearly, too, that in the earlier child-care debates there was a suggestion that the government was attacking the top end of town and taking away welfare from the highly paid. This is clearly not the case with this measure. I would argue it was not the case with the previous measures either. Clearly, in this case, this is increasing costs for people who are in receipt of child-care assistance, people who are assessed as being eligible for child-care assistance because of their relatively lower income levels.

So it is a very retrograde step. It is forcing hardship on families because of the increases in costs. Families will either have to cut their child-care hours or, in some cases, leave the work force or reduce their commitment to the work force in order to adjust to the changes that are occurring. I think that is an anti-family measure. It is one that fails to take account of the needs of families in our current age.

I want to note the government's exceptions to the general rule, which provide that the cap will not apply if the family has work related commitments and travelling time of more than 50 hours a week. The range of exceptions that has been made, I think, is a commendable measure. We have been pointing out to the government our concerns about the original measure, and we are glad to see that the government seems to have taken some of these comments on board in providing these exceptions. As I say, that does not alter the net impact of this measure across the sector, which is to add an extra $35 million in costs to Australian families. In my view, this is a budget savings‐driven measure, not a child-care policy measure of any merit. It fails to take account of the way child care has been structured and the way the needs of Australian families should be met.

These increases will apply from 1 April if the disallowance motion is not carried. I think we have already seen, from reports in the press and from my own personal discussions with child-care centre staff, that families are responding to the package of measures announced in the last budget. Demand for places seems to have fallen. People are reducing their children's hours. There are reports of people giving up work to avoid increasing child-care costs. The impact is already being felt, and that will only be driven home further if this disallowance motion is not carried today.

Another point that I want to make very strongly is that this measure will make child care even less affordable and accessible for parents. Parents want flexibility. We have to encourage the child-care industry to provide flexibility for parents. This measure reduces the flexibility and capacity of child‐care centres to meet the demands of parents and families in our community. Therefore, it provides fewer choices, not more.

The Howard government is very strong on the rhetoric of choice. The government is very strong on arguing that it is trying to give families choice. Again, we see the reality of these changes as reducing choices for families and, in particular, reducing choices for women, because that is where the impact is most felt. Women are often the ones who are sole carers or the ones who, in the end, have to make decisions about career and work opportunities because of the costs and availability of child care.

I have attended a number of meetings in Perth where women have made it very clear that the total impact of these changes is to reduce the choices available to them, reduce their opportunity to work. Therefore, in my view, that reduces the economic capacity of Australia. If we refuse to provide full opportunities for 50 per cent of our population to contribute, then the economic capacity, the overall wealth and wellbeing of the country, is diminished. So I think this is a very retrograde step.

I also want to take the opportunity to remind the Senate that we know things are going to get worse for parents who are using child care. The government have cut $500 million from child care in the 1996 budget. We now have leaked documentation that suggests the government are planning to cut a further $400 million in the 1997 budget. These changes are part of an overall attack by the government on child care. I think they are driven by an ideological view of the family and its needs, which is related more to the 1950s than to the 1990s.

This is not a government that is pro family. This is a government that is pro some families. These changes do not do anything to assist; rather, they work directly against the interests of those families who choose to access quality affordable child care. I urge the Senate to support the disallowance motion and strike one blow for the protection of a quality child-care program for families in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak in this debate and to indicate that the Democrats will be supporting this disallowance motion. To follow on what Senator Evans was saying, there is a word that is used for people or governments who say one thing and then do another. That word has to be used for this government. I will let your mind wander a little bit, so you can decide for yourself what that word is.

SPEECH.PARA: This government, as Senator Evans said, trumpeted a number of phrases that somehow or other are supposed to encapsulate what it is on about. But in almost every action it has taken since it came into government, it in fact has denied any ordinary meaning of those phrases. One of them is family and another is choice.

As Senator Evans said, the coalition has a very narrow understanding of what family is. Those families who are outside of that definition find it very hard to get a look-in. By choice, this government means choice only for certain families and certainly not for those at the bottom of the heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —A narrower view of choice.

—Yes. The support of the Democrats for this disallowance motion is in line with our continuing commitment to families and to child care. It is consistent with the position we have taken on this issue since the budget was handed down last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats do believe that two factors, choice and quality, are fundamental to early childhood policy. Choice is about a parent being able to stay at home with a child if they want to, or being able to go out to work, be it full time or part time, if that is what they want to do. That is the real choice. The Democrats recognise the tremendous pressure that many families today are under as they try to juggle their work and family commitments. But, again, this measure is ensuring that working-class people, people at the bottom, those who usually are the ones obliged to travel furthest to work, are the ones who will be penalised by this measure.

We recognise that for many families the financial benefits of working only just outweigh the cost of child care and that for some families, an increasing number because of this measure, child care is just no longer an affordable option. This government has reduced, not increased, the choices available to many families by introducing policies which raise the cost of child care. This lack of commitment to families and to child care has increased the hardship which those families suffer.

In the months following the budget, I received thousands of letters—that is not a figure snatched out of the air; it was over 10,000—from families telling me how any rise in the cost of child care would affect them. Many of these letters were very disturbing. Some, particularly those from single parent families, were nothing short of heart-rending.

Many single parents said they would be left with no choice but to leave their job or study and go back onto welfare if the cost of child care were to rise. Again, this government takes policy decisions in isolation. They never think that you have to put policies together because something you do in one area will affect what happens in another area. They simply have a grab bag of cuts to all kinds of programs without any thought that those programs are linked.

Many single parents said that they would be better off on welfare than trying to meet the cost of having their children cared for while they were working or studying. So again you see that the government really is not cutting its overall budget responsibilities because, by the policy of cutting the hours available to parents for child care, they actually increase the budget in the area of welfare. They really are not achieving anything.

It does seem that for some parents the fears they have had are now becoming a reality. I recently spoke to one single mother who has had to postpone her undergraduate degree at university just because she can no longer afford to have her child cared for while she is at lectures. She has gone back on welfare. I have got to say to the government: what's the value in that? Surely, the government does not really believe that forcing parents out of the work force or out of their study is an acceptable or desirable choice. As heartless as this government sometimes appears to be, I am sure that is not its intention. But this is the problem when you have policies which take no account of the effects in other areas.

Stories like this make a mockery of the government's commitment to families. It also makes a mockery of the much heralded family tax initiative. So does the fact that many of the government's other policies have also increased the cost of living for families. I am sorry, because I thought perhaps this would be a different kind of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were expecting too much.

—I am the eternal optimist, Senator Hogg. But my hopes were soon dashed. It did not take very long—a couple of days, actually. Of course the fundamental disappointment that I had was to discover that this government, which made such a noise about the issue of family during the election, has proved its lack of commitment to families by introducing policies which raise the cost of child care. The Democrats do believe in putting families first and it is because of that that we will be supporting this disallowance motion today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, might I say that, whilst I do not declare an interest in this area, my wife and I would one day hope to and we look forward to that day.
—Keep practising, Senator.

—I want to refer to one or two matters that Senator Evans raised—I will take his advice on that last point. This measure, which is to put a 50-hour cap on child-care assistance, was announced last year as part of the government's commitment to better targeting child-care outlays and to deliver a more equitable child-care system. That means that families who have to use more than 50 hours of child care a week will not necessarily be deprived of any assistance. There is an exemption—an exemption which Senator Evans alluded to. I might just outline that to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The exemption applies to families who need more than 50 hours care a week to meet their work related commitments. Work related commitments cover paid work, including operating or setting up a business; formal study or training, including on-the-job training; people who are registered and actively looking for work; and travel between the child-care service and the place of work, study or training. That means that, if a family requires more than 50 hours child care for those reasons, they will be exempt from this cap. I can say to the Senate that 86 per cent of families in these situations who receive assistance require less than 50 hours per week.

That then leaves some 14 per cent of families who are charged by their child-care service provider for more than 50 hours of care a week. But, on closer analysis, only two per cent of those families actually use more than 50 hours, because of the situation that Senator Evans alluded to: it is not so much the hours you use; it is not charged on a sessional basis, although I would add that a quarter of child-care centres these days do charge on a sessional basis. There is a matter of choice there, which has been mentioned by Senator Woodley, in that families can go to a centre where a sessional charge applies as opposed to a blanket charge.

BREAK.PARA: But what you face is that people who are not using that full allocation are charged for 50 hours a week. That is the 12 per cent that I referred to. Fourteen per cent are being charged for more than 50 hours. Yet only two per cent of the 14 per cent are using more than 50 hours of child care. So the problem here relates to the service provider. It is not a problem brought about by government, but it is a problem the government faces, because the government, after all, has to provide assistance. In providing that assistance, it can find itself in a situation where people who are not actually using that excess in child care are receiving the same assistance as those who need in excess of 50 hours. Nonetheless, there is an exemption, which I mentioned, for those families who need it. I might also add that this measure does not impose a daily cap of 10 hours, as I think was suggested. It is a 50‐hour cap applicable over a week.

The other aspect is that there was a mention of increase in fees. Child‐care centres impose an increase of fees on a cyclical basis in any event. Ten dollars has been about the average increase in fees in each of the last few years and that is not linked to the 1996 budget of this government. This government has said, `We will provide child‐care assistance and we will make sure it is equitable. We will make sure that, where families do need more than 50 hours of child care for work related purposes, we will exempt them from this cap and in those circumstances there will be an allowance for those families.'

It will tend to be those families who are struggling who will need more child-care assistance, because, no doubt, they will have both parents working to make ends meet. Those in that situation can be accommodated by the exemption. So what Senators Woodley and Evans have said about this government being quite heartless is entirely untrue. The government has said, `We will provide assistance, but we will provide it on an equitable basis.' Child‐care centres should look to charging their fees on a sessional basis, not just on the basis that if you use a couple of hours a day you get charged for a full day's allowance, or the anomaly, which I mentioned earlier, where you get charged for in excess of 50 hours when you in fact do not use 50 hours of child‐care assistance.

That is what this is all about. The government has a duty to be efficient in how it assists people. The government has an absolute duty to the taxpayers of the country to see that their money is spent wisely, because, after all, with efficiency in expenditure in these areas, it allows us to govern for all people concerned and to apply income in other areas, particularly in a budgetary context, to meet our obligations in reducing the debt we inherited.

These measures which have been introduced by the government are not draconian. They do allow for those who are battling. The situation is really one where the industry needs to look to itself. I believe that the comments that have been raised by the opposition and the Democrats are unfounded. I believe that these measures are fair. As I pointed out, more than a quarter of these centres are now offering sessional rates. The government sees that as an improvement in the child‐care industry.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Faulkner's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Foreman did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

BREAK.PARA: (Senator Cook did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1997 RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1997 and amendments 2, 3 and 7 moved by Senator Sherry for the opposition. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing Labor amendments 2, 3 and 7. I wonder if Senator Kemp could inform the committee whether or not RSAs will be subject to state transactions duties and the other various state charges.

—The answer is yes. Just prior to the break we were discussing the amendment you moved which was to exempt RSAs from fees, charges, surcharges or taxes. The point that I made was that this has opened the way for a tax haven. I do not think that has been responded to, Senator.
—I am just about to.
—Good. You owe the chamber an explanation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did ask you to provide us with advice prior to question time. I understand you would have been preoccupied because of the nature of question time and the important issues that were raised there. But it is very easy for you to make a broad allegation that it opens up tax evasion. How does it specifically do that, Senator Kemp?

—You have exempted, as your amendment says, them from all taxes and surcharges. The fact of the matter is that that provides a very substantial advantage for RSAs compared with other products. I think it is up to you to explain to us why you have gone down that route because the advice I have is that it does open up a tax haven.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will take out `surcharges and taxes'.

—We now have an amendment of an amendment about which Senator Sherry said I was speaking nonsense and now he has decided to amend it—not very fast on the footwork and not, I might say, so convincing. Senator, we do not accept what you have done. We do not accept the amendment. I mentioned to you that RSA accounts are entitled to the same protection of accounts under $1,000 as applies in the superannuation area. We are after a level playing field. Senator, having given RSAs a huge advantage, I have to say—the most amazing advantage—you have now backflipped and you are trying to make sure RSAs do not enjoy what sometimes is colloquially known as a level playing field. Your amended motion is still unsatisfactory to the government because it is imposing on RSAs what you are not prepared to impose on superannuation funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments Nos 2, 3 and 7 to clauses 14 and 42: omit ",charges, surcharges or taxes" (wherever occurring) and substitute "or charges".

I understand in the evidence before the Senate committee that credit unions and building societies all sought this amendment, that no fees and charges should be passed in respect of RSA accounts. Senator Kemp, unlike you and your government, we listen. If we receive reasoned and sound advice we respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if we could just keep to the facts of issues. The fact of the matter is that you are over there because you did not listen, and Gary Gray made that comment in the press this morning.
—Okay, we'll be here all night.

—But you make the point and I respond to it. If you wish to behave in that manner, Senator, you are entitled to do that. You make a political point and—shock, horror—I reserve the right to respond. It is as simple as that.

—May I suggest, Mr Acting Chairman, that Democrats' amendments 3 and 4 will address the government's concerns about surcharges and taxes, and it may be best for the opposition to withdraw its amendments and for us to proceed to discuss our amendments 3 and 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison has made an excellent suggestion. We are happy to support her amendments. I seek leave to withdraw amendments 2, 3 and 7.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 38, page 28 (line 28), omit paragraph (i).
(4) Clause 38, page 29 (after line 6), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) RSA providers must not charge fees in relation to the opening, keeping, depositing, withdrawing or transferring of amounts held in RSAs.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments would prevent RSA providers from charging fees on RSA products. As Senator Sherry has already indicated, the credit unions have already said that they would be quite happy to accept that. The Democrats think it is hard to see why banks or anyone else should need to charge fees on RSAs given that deposits will be infrequent, probably made only quarterly and then by electronic funds transfer. Withdrawals from RSAs will be very rare indeed. As we have already mentioned, these RSAs are likely to be very lucrative for the banks.

In the Democrats' section of the 22nd report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, we reminded the government that it had said that RSAs were to be `a simple, low cost, low risk product'. This move would certainly ensure that they were low cost. The credit unions were the ones that actually made that suggestion that there be no fees at all. On that basis, we think these two amendments are very supportable, given that the government intends that they be low cost. If credit unions can offer such a product without charging fees, we see no reason why other financial institutions cannot do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a commercial decision as to what they do. It is entirely up to them, and we are not attempting to be prescriptive in the way that you are attempting to be. I think that senators, in the context of the debate, are anxious not to unfairly advantage one product compared with another as a result of the rules and regulations which would apply. Senator Allison, we regard what you have put as unwarranted commercial interference. If credit unions do not wish to have fees, that is fine. They do not have to. We are not saying the same people have to, and that is one of the commercial decisions that they will make. There will, of course, be full disclosure of fees and charges. If credit unions do not wish to charge fees, they will certainly disclose that information.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important point—and I detect that there is at least a view around to this effect—is that competitive neutrality should be an appropriate principle which we should apply in this area. Existing super funds are not subject to any fee restrictions except, of course, for small amounts. The same rules apply with RSAs.

As I said, it is a commercial decision for the credit unions to decide whether they charge fees or not. The structure of the fees should be left to the competitive marketplace. I do not imagine you wish to impose that particular rule on super funds—I suspect that is the case—and I underline the fact that there is full disclosure of fees and charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point is that the money which will flow in, in the form of superannuation contributions, is captive—it is compulsory. We are not just dealing here with a normal bank account. These are contributions that are made on behalf of the employee, so it is reasonable for the government to indeed be prescriptive in this matter. You raise the matter of there being no such requirements for the superannuation funds not to charge fees but, as we all understand, there are much higher returns that flow from superannuation funds. I think we have a responsibility, given that they are low return accounts, that they truly be low cost.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has the capacity to be prescriptive in this case. As I say, the flow of funds will be, to some degree, guaranteed. Withdrawals will be rare. They should be very easy accounts for the banks to manage. Because they are low return, they should be low cost. This is one way in which the government can put into place its policy and its stated intention that they be low cost.

Obviously, if the credit unions have offered that this, given the option, is how they would organise their RSAs, it must be possible for the other financial institutions to do so as well. It is a way in which the government can protect consumers against what could well be a low return, but even high cost, product. It is incumbent on the government to take this step. As I say, banks are not forced to go ahead with RSAs. If they find that they cannot afford to do it without charging fees, they are under no obligation to do so, but it is certainly in the interests of consumers for us to take this protective step.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you referred to the regulations. What will be the precise regulation—I remind the Senate that we have not seen those regulations—in respect of fees and charges that apply to RSA products?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a normal aspect of the legislative process that regulations are not produced at the same time as the legislation. You are aware of that, Senator. We are just following the procedures which were well established by your government. I doubt whether there has ever been an insistence that regulations have to be produced at the same time as the bill. The usual process, as you well know, is that the regulations are drafted and then available to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Senator Allison's comments, there will be a full disclosure of fees and charges. It will be entirely up to the institution offering the RSA to determine what it does and to make sure that its product is competitive. I do not accept your view that somehow we have to impose on RSAs regulations, controls and legislation which we do not impose on superannuation. We are seeking a level playing field here, I would have thought. It was not I who used that term first; I think it was Senator Sherry. You are taking an action which is designed typically to be to the detriment of RSAs. We believe that RSAs should be appropriately regulated. They should be a competitive product, people should know what they are going into and there should be full disclosure.

Senator Allison, the proposal that you have made is not acceptable to the government. It certainly avoids the huge problem that Senator Sherry's original amendment had, but it is not acceptable to the government. We believe that it is quite contrary to the principles which I thought everyone had signed on to—the principles of competitive neutrality.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will rephrase the question. Do you know at this point in time what the regulations will say in respect of fees and charges on this product?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Details of fees and charges will be disclosed on opening of accounts, so people know. They will be available annually and they will be available on exit. There are no fees—I stress this because this is important to the debate—on small amounts. This is identical for funds. They are the broad principles which will be encompassed in the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not accept the Democrat amendment and we do not accept the arguments which have been put forward. It is quite contrary to the general principles which I thought all senators had signed on to. We are not saying that they have to charge fees. Credit unions are entirely free. If they can produce a competitive product, that will be a product which will be attractive in the market place. It is up to the institutions themselves. As I said, there will be complete disclosure on the opening of accounts annually and on exit. On small amounts under $1,000 there will be no fees, and this is identical for funds.
I urge the Senate to reject this amendment and ensure that we do not unfairly tilt the playing field in favour of the superannuation funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could Senator Kemp indicate for the purpose of the committee where and under what provision small amounts—I assume you are referring to the $1,000 level—are protected. There are some other issues to pursue as well, but I would like that assistance please.
—The regulations have been made under subclause 38(2)(i).
—Thank you. I think we are getting somewhere. You now telling us that there will be a regulation covering this particular issue, and it will be made under this section of the bill.
—You asked me what the regulations would be and I have mentioned them.
—But you had not mentioned this issue specifically. It is not in the legislation. You are now telling us that that particular provision will be in the regulations.
—Just for the record, that is correct and that is the advice I have received.

—We were not aware of that prior to my asking, because we could not find it in the legislation. I have a couple of general comments, firstly about that issue. It is important that that issue is dealt with because other small amounts of superannuation of $1,000 or less are protected from erosion of fees and charges in traditional superannuation products. We could not find it in the legislation, but it is apparently going to be in the regulations. We would have been assisted if we had been aware of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that superannuation is compulsory, at least to SGC levels. The average charge by industry funds and the traditional employer funds is between 80c and $1.20 per week. At the superannuation committee hearings the banks could not provide us with any precise detail of what their fees and charges regime would be. I do not know whether they just could not because they had not thought about it or they would not.

You argue that RSAs are to be a level playing field. How is it that an RSA is part of a level playing field when the individual can be signed up to the RSA? It is another issue but I take issue with you on what you propose is a level playing field, given that the employer can sign the employee up into the RSA product.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the regulatory framework with a superannuation product is exactly the same—the employer can sign a person up. I will seek some further advice on that, Senator, because that is of concern to you. As I said, I was under the impression that we were trying to create—I think you correctly used the term `competitive neutrality' at the start of this debate—
—On the previous amendment, which you would not accept.

—I think the principle applies, Senator. In relation to amounts under $1,000, you asked the question and we responded to that question. No-one is trying to hide anything. We are always happy to answer your questions, Senator Sherry. You asked how RSAs are part of a level playing field and I pointed out to you that an employer can sign up a person with the relevant fund on the same principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue and a different set of principles. In respect of an in-house employer fund or in respect of an industry fund, currently, at least—it may change, depending on your government's intentions; we do not know what will happen yet—the industrial award provides for automatic coverage of a particular industry fund or in-house employer fund. The award provides for that. It may be more than one, but I think in the majority of cases it is only one.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the employer must sign the employee into the prescribed fund. That is a different position from the position we are dealing with with RSAs. RSAs are an individual product that will be delivered to individuals, either collectively or singularly.

I put it to you that the bargaining power and knowledge of an employee who is required by an employer to join an RSA is significantly different and that the collective bargaining power of a traditional in-house employer fund and an industry fund is enormous. That is one of the reasons why they can drive down the fees and charges. That is why the fees and charges are very competitive.

What we could have emerge with RSAs is similar to the older-type single superannuation products, which were notorious for their high fees and charges, delivered through the traditional agent-type product. We will not have a level playing field in respect of bar gaining power in the delivery of fees and charges. That is why we are so concerned about this issue.
You may care to respond to that. But before you do, the ISC also gave evidence to the Senate committee that there will be no price monitoring of fees and charges of this product.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing fees and charges and in relation to the matters you raised, I understand they are picked up under amendments Nos 9 and 11 to be moved by you. That is the issue that I understand is dealt with under those amendments.
—Will you support them?
—Let us get on with the debate, Senator. Let us deal with fees and charges first and then see how the debate runs.

SPEECH.PARA: For the Independent senators, I think the principles are that there is full disclosure. No-one is saying that people must charge fees; it is entirely up to the institution to decide what it does. We have mentioned that, for accounts under $1,000, there is protection available. We have also mentioned that these arrangements are similar to those enjoyed by superannuation funds.

Senator Sherry has raised the issue of award superannuation funds. In relation to the difference between RSAs and award superannuation funds, my point to you is that we are dealing with those under your amendments Nos. 9 and 11. I am not resiling from the debate, but I think the debate is probably better conducted at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, what do you mean by `full disclosure'? What would be the definition of that within the regulations?
—They will have to disclose the structure of their fees and charges on the opening of accounts. They will have to disclose them annually. They will have to disclose them on exit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that you have mentioned the issue of exit fees. I understand from that that exit fees will be permitted?
—I mentioned the fees which are chargeable when someone decides to exit; I did not mention there would be an exit fee.
—Yes, but your regulations will allow the charging of an exit fee?

—I have disclosed in some detail what we would propose in the regulations, but these regulations will come before the chamber. If people are not happy with what is in the regulations, I guess we will have the debate again.
—Minister, I ask again: will the regulations allow the charging of an exit fee?

—It would not prohibit an exit fee, but that would have to be disclosed. It could not be sprung on somebody. You could not say, `You are going to leave the RSA, so here is an exit fee.' That would all have to be part of the fees and structure, which would have to be disclosed. It would be one of the elements that people would have to take into account.

—I will come back to the exit fee issue in a moment. What about changes to fees? Will there be a requirement in the regulations that changes to fee levels will have to be notified to the member of the RSA?
—Yes, Senator.

—To come back to exit fees, are you aware, Minister, that the majority of traditional industry funds and in‐house employer funds do not charge exit fees and are you aware of why they do not charge exit fees?

—Senator, I will certainly take your word for it. I do not think you would stand up and mislead the chamber. But, if exit fees are an issue, people will structure their particular products to achieve a competitive advantage.

—The issue of exit fees is very important because, under what you are proposing, exit fees are not prohibited, so a bank or other institution can charge an exit fee. What is to stop a bank placing a prohibitive exit fee—you can speculate about the level—so that it becomes prohibitively expensive for a person to leave an RSA, and therefore, they are locked into a low return product?

—They would have had to be informed on the nature of the fees and charges when the RSA was established. I guess the same thing would apply to superannuation funds. As I understand, the regulations of the superannuation funds do not prohibit an exit fee. I could stand up here and run the same scare argument. But the reality is that what we are putting in place are regulations which are, to the extent practicable, very similar to those which apply to superannuation funds. Under the regulations, if superannuation funds wanted to have exit fees, they could have them.
—That does not apply.

—I take your point. You say that is not applied, but, as I said, these things would have to be disclosed on the opening of the account. If an RSA had prohibitive fees and charges, it would hardly be competitive and people would hardly wish to put their money there, I would have thought.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a fundamental difference of approach. We do not accept your contention that there will be perfect information, that it will be a level playing field in respect of the choice. There is no prohibition on third line forcing and other issues; we will get to those issues later. We do not accept that the nature of choice occurs because of the word `choice'. We would argue that it needs to be an informed choice. How will an individual employee be in that position of knowledge and be able to object if their employer says to that employee, `This is the particular RSA product my employees are in; you take it or leave it.'

—They, of course, have a 14‐day period in which to decide whether to stay with the RSA account and, as you and I would expect, they would be given a full disclosure document after the account is opened. The issue of choice, I think, will come up quite frequently in the years to come. But there is no question that a new superannuation type product is now going to be on the market that will provide for many people a useful and practical alternative. It is in line with the policy we offered. We are not seeking for special favours to be given to RSAs. We are seeking a regulatory regime which is, as I said, where practicable, similar to superannuation funds. We do not impose the requirements that you are apparently seeking in support of the Democrat amendment on superannuation funds. On the other hand, the regulations, as I have advised you, do not prevent superannuation funds from charging exit fees. I have just confirmed that advice. In ensuring that there is reasonable competitive neutrality, I cannot see what the objection is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a couple of points need to be made. Senator Sherry has pointed out that we are not really in a position of choice and it does not matter how much disclosure there is—whether it is exit fees, fees generally, operating fees or whatever else. If the employee is not presented with a choice at the outset—that is, a choice between, say, a credit union which charges no fees at all or a bank, or three banks—then you could argue whether choice was available. But that is not what the bill provides for.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the employer determines at the outset which RSA the employees' contributions will be made to. Whilst there may be disclosure, there is no choice at that point. At least if we remove the fees, as is commercially viable and possible—we have already heard that from the credit unions—then the choice will be more equal and employees will not be, I suppose, disadvantaged because they do not know what the other RSAs might provide in relation to fees and charges. I think that is the point. We are not really talking about choice here. If it was a product that was advertised in the paper and on TV and everybody understood the differences between the providers, and when it came time to have their contributions directed somewhere they made the choice, well and good, but that is not what we are talking about here.

TALK.START.PARA: —To a very large extent, the arguments you raise would have been precisely the same if you had taken out the word `RSAs' and substituted `superannuation.' With superannuation, I pointed out to you that the employee has a 14‐day option after the account is opened as to whether to stay with the RSA, and full disclosure is required on all those matters which you are rightly concerned about. Equally, there is a 14‐day rule for public office superannuation funds. This is no different, and I do not quite understand why you are wishing to impose a regulatory regime which seems to be more onerous on RSAs than on public office superannuation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, indeed, I am arguing that they should be more onerous and the reason for that is that they will be low return products. We all know that.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I want to make is that it is all very well for an employee to indicate within 14 days that they would rather have their contributions directed to another fund or another RSA, but within this bill is the provision that the RSA provider can take as long as 12 months to do that. We will no doubt come to that and have a debate about it, but I do not think you can argue that the two products are the same. That is the whole basis behind our position. The opposition's report to the Senate is that they are very different products and one is far less able to provide a good return to the employee than the other, so certain protections need to be put in place in order to make sure that there is not that loss of income for those people who do end up having their contributions sent to the RSAs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they are different products. That is why we are bringing in RSAs. They are different products. No one has argued that they are not different. What we are seeking to put in place is a regulatory regime and structure which is reasonable and fair as amongst competitive products. That is what we are seeking to put in place. I have drawn the analogies in relation to public office superannuation funds, which you have not argued against and which are very similar to what we are putting in place in terms of the key principles for RSAs. But of course, there is no choice in industry funds—
—Or in‐house employer funds.

—The senator has other examples he wishes to bring forward, but we are widening the choice which is available. It is an election promise. These RSAs have got to be regulated in a proper and fair manner which provides appropriate protections, and no one argues that.

SPEECH.PARA: Regulations will come before this chamber and if you, Senator, and Senator Sherry are not happy with the regulations, I dare say that I will be the first to hear about them. You have that choice, when the regulations come forward. But I think that what you are seeking to do is to apply to RSAs rules which do not apply to public office superannuation funds. As I mentioned, the issue of choice does not apply in relation to some of the superannuation funds. So the government will certainly not be supporting the amendment you have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you acknowledged at the commencement of your answer that the RSA product is different from the more traditional products. RSAs were delivered by banks and other institutions, for profit. That is not a dirty word, but that will be their prime motivation. For profit. That is not the case in respect of the traditional industry‐type funds—and, I would argue, most in‐house employer funds—because of the trustee relationship. Those funds do not have to make a profit. All the money returns to the members because the trustees hold the superannuation money on behalf of employees.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of RSAs, banks and other financial institutions will hold the money in order to make a profit. Trustees, because they have a fiduciary duty to the members of the fund, cannot charge what would be regarded as an unreasonable level of fees and charges. There is no sense to it because they do not make a profit. Whereas RSAs, with their delivery by banks and other financial institutions, will presumably have to make a profit.

Given the other issues we have canvassed, we do not accept that it is a level playing field. Why should we allow a situation to occur where some people will be charged what we regard as unreasonable fees and charges? The banks cannot tell us what the fees and charges will be, and you did not respond to the earlier point about the ISC overseeing the level of fees and charges that will be made through the RSA product.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you made a good point when you said that it makes no sense to charge unreasonable fees. It makes no sense at all. If an RSA charges unreasonable fees, it will have no customers. People will not take up RSAs. Why would superannuation funds charge unreasonable fees? They won't. It makes no sense, as Senator Sherry said. Equally, as it makes no sense for superannuation, it makes no sense for RSAs.
