Of course, if there are complaints about fees—and I have indicated there is full disclosure—the ISC will respond to and investigate consumer complaints on fees and charges. I think that provides additional protection, but in a competitive market, as Senator Sherry says, it makes no sense. An institution which acquired a name for charging unreasonable fees, non‐competitive fees, would not be able to establish a customer base.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Conroy did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Bishop did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 38, page 28 (line 28), at the end of paragraph (i), add ", ensuring that the objective of providing a low‐cost product is met".

Democrats' amendment No. 5 is, to some degree, a fall‐back position. This amendment is an alternative, as I have said, to amendments 3 and 4. It seeks to place an obligation on the ISC to administer RSA operating standards in a way which would encourage low fees. As we have said before, this would appear to be the government's intention, but it is not made clear in the act. At the inquiry, the ISC gave evidence that it would not be particularly active in looking at fees. So we think it is important that a positive duty be written into the act to force, if necessary, the ISC to look at the fees if they are to be allowed—it seems they will be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will support Democrats' amendment 5. It is a fall‐back position, which is regrettable. This is supposed to be a low cost, low return product. We think it is important that at least the issue of low cost is taken into account when drafting the regulations. It is a very important principle which should be incorporated in the bill. We have traversed this ground extensively. I make the comment to Senator Allison that, as I recall it, the evidence before the committee was that the ISC would not—not `may not'—be surveying or overseeing the fees and charges of RSAs. I think it was quite categorical.
—The whole nature of an RSA is that they are to be a low cost product. That is the nature of the product that we are seeking to establish.
—Yes, like all the other money the banks have got that they don't pay interest on, or they charge people heaps of money.
—I will ignore the provocation.
—Don't let him intimidate you; he's a big boy.

—On the advice of Senator Collins, I will ignore the provocation—I do not often accept his wise counsel. The whole nature of this is that they are to be a low cost product. If they are not, they will not be competitive and they will not have customers.
—What!

—As I said, that is the whole nature of the marketplace and they will not be able to compete. We do not think Democrats' amendment 5 is necessary. Therefore, we will not be supporting it. I would make it clear to you that the principle underlying it is what we are seeking to establish—a low cost product.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to make any further contribution, but it would be useful if Senator Colston would indicate whether he is prepared to support the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 40, page 29 (after line 24), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) An RSA provider must not enter into any interest off‐set arrangements or combination account arrangements with any employer who, or constitutional corporation which, has established an RSA.
Penalty: 100 penalty units
(6) Clause 40, page 29 (line 25), omit "subclause (1)", substitute "subsection (1) or (1A).

Amendments 5 and 6 are very important to this legislation if we are to have the so-called level playing field. The legislation does not prevent banks from doing a deal with an employer to open accounts on behalf of employees. It is fact that an employer can and will open accounts on behalf of employees. We know that banks can do a deal with an employer to ensure that the employer encourages the employees to join their particular RSA product. In fact, the banks admit this.

The Australian Bankers Association told the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that it is normal commercial practice to engage in deals with employers whereby half a per cent or a full percentage point may be shaved off the margins to provide incentives to the employer. That may not be in the best interests of the employee. Why should an employer enter into a side deal with a bank or other financial institution that delivers employees, at the behest of the employer, into a specific RSA product which, probably in those circumstances, may not be in the best interests of the employees? This product should be about what is in the best interests of the employee above all else. It is workers' money. It is compulsory.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that it is not ethical for employers to have any sort of inducement agreement with banks. The point was made earlier that RSAs are a low growth, low return product. Senator Kemp has admitted that. The banks, too, have admitted that in evidence. These are not suitable products in many cases, particularly in the long term, for employers to induce an employee to join. That is our fundamental ethical problem, and that is why we have moved amendments 5 and 6.

Senator Harradine comes from my state of Tasmania, and we are involved in the union movement together. I know he would know the industrial reality at the workplace. I am sure he is aware that, if employers say to employees, after providing all the information, they would like them to join a particular RSA, nine out of 10 employees would sign up. Employers will be doing a lot of encouraging if they are getting a cut‐price rate on the side from a bank. They will certainly be doing that as enthusiastically as they can. As I have said, we believe such a practice would be totally unethical, and it should be proscribed and not permitted. That is the purpose of our amendments 5 and 6.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to comment on these amendments and draw to the minister's attention how, by not supporting these amendments, the government would be advocating a direct transfer of benefits from employees to employers in terms of the services provided by a superannuation account. I will explain what I mean.

SPEECH.PARA: Employers who open RSAs may be provided with incentives by the banks to do so. Perhaps the benefit for the employer is a slightly lower interest rate on a commercial loan or perhaps some other financial incentive to use the services of the bank. Whatever it is, there would be potentially some benefit to the employer. Industry funds currently provide a whole range of services to employees who are members of those funds and those services come in the form of associated lower interest home loans for super members' home loans, financial services, or death and disability insurance—something which comes with most industry funds.

BREAK.PARA: I do not see a mechanism for RSAs to provide such a benefit to members. In fact, if these amendments do not go through, the only benefit that could possibly arise from an employer taking out an RSA would go not to an employee but straight to the employer. Whilst supporting these amendments would remove the ability for employers to financially be advantaged by some service or perhaps a low interest loan, it will not actually provide the additional service to clients of RSAs that in fact the industry funds provide. Minister, I put to you that unless you support these amendments you are actually supporting the transfer of a subsidiary benefit, if you like, of employees in the case of industry funds to employers, which is potentially the case with RSAs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —These arguments in relation to this clause have got tied up with the debate on a later clause—the so-called third line forcing issue. I think we will be dealing with the third line forcing issue under clause 68 of the bill. A lot of the arguments that Senator Sherry ran related, I think, to the third line forcing issue, which we will deal with later. If you are concerned about third line forcing, I think that is the place to deal with that particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are to clause 40, which relates to interest offsetting; in other words, paying the interest from an ordinary account into an RSA. This can lead to tax avoidance because an RSA is concessionally taxed. Our clause is a tax avoidance clause. That was the reason we put it in: to avoid tax avoidance, because an opportunity may have been opened up for people to pay the interest on an ordinary account into an RSA. That was the purpose of the clause.

We oppose these amendments. There are a number of technical problems with what has been proposed. The existing clause prohibits interest offsetting arrangements where one of the accounts involved is an RSA. The policy rationale for that is to prevent interest from an ordinary deposit account, as I said, to be paid into a concessionally taxed RSA, therefore resulting in tax minimisation. This is a tax avoidance clause. It is not the third line forcing issue, which I think is what some were debating.

The proposed amendments, we believe, are too broad and unnecessary because they prohibit offsetting arrangements where no concessionally taxed vehicles are involved. In other words, we are conscious of tax avoidance and we have drafted this clause to prevent what we saw as a potential for tax avoidance. My view would be that we will deal with the third line forcing issue when we deal with clause 68, so this issue will remain unresolved until then.

As I said, we think the proposed amendments are too broad. This is because the trigger for the prohibition in the amendments is simply that the employer has established an RSA and not that an RSA is involved. There is a distinction there. This would prohibit legitimate interest offsetting arrangements currently permitted under the tax act.

I am also advised that the term `established' has no meaning in the bill. Under the RSA Bill, the employer opens in the name of the employee. Thereafter, the account is controlled by the employee. The notion of an employer establishing an RSA does not fit into this framework because there will be no reference to the employer in the holder of the RSA. This is a tax avoidance measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your clause.

—Our clause. We believe it tackles the issue of tax avoidance. We believe there are some technical problems. I think the underlying principle is consistent in the debate. This clause does what we think is the required job. We see that the amendment is too broad. We see that the third line forcing issue is one that we can undoubtedly join later in the evening under clause 68.

SPEECH.PARA: We all agree that we have to stop tax avoidance in relation to this issue. I think there would be blazing agreement right around the chamber on that. To summarise, we believe there are some technical problems in the proposal put forward in the amendment. Therefore, I urge the Senate to defeat this amendment. I think our clause achieves the result that you are seeking. As the debate continues, we can get on to third line forcing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not really want to say this, but over the years that I have been a senator I have found that, when a minister does not really know what to say, his advisers say `tax avoidance technical problems'. That, in my experience, has been the pat answer that comes from advisers. The amendment put forward by Senator Sherry states:

SPEECH.PARA: An RSA provider must not enter into any interest off‐set arrangements or combination account arrangements with any employer who, or constitutional corporation which, has established an RSA.

That is not a substitution for what the government has in this legislation; it is additional to it. Quite frankly, we cannot see any problem with that. It is recognising that we are dealing with moneys that are paid by the employer but moneys that belong to the workers. Remember that this was an offset for wage increases. The minister has not convinced me that this addition to what is in the bill will cause either tax avoidance problems or technical problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I think your remarks were a trifle unkind and unusually unkind. I mentioned that there were some technical problems with the amendment. Then I explained why there is a problem. I did not just say, `Let's wipe this because there is a technical problem.' I said that there were two particular problems. I also said that the amendment is too broad because it prohibits offsetting arrangements where no concessionally taxed vehicles are involved. This is because the trigger for the prohibition is simply that the employer has established an RSA, not that an RSA is involved. This would prohibit legitimate interest offsetting arrangements that are currently permitted under the tax act. I have sought to explain that.
—They would not establish an RSA.

—You are entitled not to accept that. It is not fair to suggest that I did not explain the point. I then said that the term `established' has no meaning in the bill. That is the advice I have from my advisers. The issue that I think is driving this debate is the third line forcing issue. This is not the substance of the issue; this is a tax avoidance clause, not the third line forcing issue which I think concerns some senators. You may not accept the reasons that I put forward, Senator, and I think that is a pity. But it is not fair to say that I just wiped it without explaining it.

—Minister, that was not my intention. I did hear what you said. You did explain it, but it did not convince me. Established has its ordinary meaning. Presumably an employer will not establish an RSA if the RSA is not going to be utilised. Surely the employer would seek from the employees permission to have the money paid into the RSA. Surely no employer would just establish an RSA without having it operated. I am supporting the amendment that has been moved by Senator Sherry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I find it difficult to understand why you are trying to distinguish between this particular amendment and third line forcing given that this amendment effectively deals with the incentive that would arise to encourage employers with respect to third line forcing. It is essential that this issue be dealt with in the context of what is to come with the third line forcing amendment. To say that it is distinct from that is correct in that it can exist by virtue of the fact that we have not yet got to third line forcing.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that Hansard will show once we proceed through this issue that your support will not necessarily be forthcoming with respect to our amendments on third line forcing. I hope I am proven to be wrong. But for you to argue that the issue of what incentives exist for employers with respect to opening RSAs is totally divorced from third line forcing will have to be played out.

Minister, I have a specific question with respect to interest offset arrangements. Do you envisage that, if RSAs are proceeded with as described, an offset arrangement would be available to the employer or, in fact, the employee—the person who is in control of the retirement savings account—in the same way that the Commonwealth's mortgage interest saver account would apply? Do you see that sort of offset arrangement being available to employers if they, in fact, initiate the opening of the RSA, or do you believe—and I am interested in your point of view, Minister—whether or not that type of product, the Commonwealth's mortgage interest saver account, would be available to the employee if they have an RSA with a particular bank?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator. My advice is that the interest offset is available to the employee. This is not the mechanism, I think, that you feel is essential to third line forcing. This is the tax avoidance clause. The amendments create, in fact, no link between the RSA and the interest offset arrangement. They incorrectly deal with incentive. The proposed amendments deal purely with interest offsetting and are flawed because the RSA is not linked to the interest offsetting.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not an easy debate to resolve. You have to accept that we are advising you, in what I think is good faith, that we can deal with the issue. I understand Labor senators are concerned about third line forcing. We can deal with this at a later time, but this is not part and parcel—that is my advice—of the issue that you are seeking to tackle there, Senator. So we will be opposing the amendments. I have not been able to convince Senator Harradine. I regret that, but that often happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are always very eloquent.

—Thank you very much. Without prolonging this debate, I think there are some more important clauses that we need to get on to. We think, for the reasons that I have explained, the amendments do raise some technical issues. We will, therefore, not support them. We believe that—because I think everyone understands that we want to stop tax avoidance—our clause deals with that. We will deal with the third line forcing issue later.
—Minister, can you just answer the question of whether or not you think employers should be able to utilise the existence of an RSA to implement an interest offset arrangement with the bank?
—I think that question is slightly different from the earlier one. The answer is yes, so long as the RSA is not involved in the offsetting account.
—The question is that the amendments moved by Senator Sherry be agreed to.
—So you are supporting the amendments, Senator Colston?
—I was persuaded by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 50, page 35 (line 26), omit "The RSA provider", substitute "Subject to subsection (2A), the RSA provider".
(7) Clause 50, page 35 (line 30), omit "12 months", substitute "28 days".
(8) Clause 50, page 35 (after line 31), after subclause (2), insert:
(2A) Where an RSA exceeds $10,000, the Commissioner may grant an extension of time to an RSA provider to transfer the amount of the RSA, provided that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Commissioner is satisfied that the extension is necessary to transfer the funds; and
(b) the transfer is not a transfer requested by an RSA holder under sections 50A or 50B.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments reduce the amount of time, from 12 months to 28 days, that an RSA provider has to respond to a request from the account holder to transfer funds to another fund. We think that—given that the RSAs are likely to be fairly small, and that would be less than $10,000—this 12-month period is simply excessive. We think it could be used to disadvantage account holders. Our amendment No. 8 does allow for an exception for larger amounts of money where an extension is genuinely needed—for instance, to access locked up funds. I suggest that this is a measure which would not make the RSAs unworkable. It would certainly give a high level of protection to RSA holders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting the Democrats' amendments Nos 6 to 8. We would not be proceeding with our next amendment, because it deals with the same issue. We, like Senator Allison, find it very surprising that a person has to be locked into an RSA for 12 months against their wishes. We understand there is some need to give reasonable notice to the institution that is operating the RSA, but one year is totally unreasonable in the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly cannot think of any in-house employer fund or industry fund that would require a year's notice. I certainly know they want some reasonable notice because they have to do paperwork—and it might be a month or pushing out to two months—but I certainly cannot recollect any of the funds that I am aware of that would require a year. This is certainly not level playing field material—level playing field material has had a bit of a work over—or choice. Where is the choice, if the employee leaves the employer and decides, for any range of reasons, `I do not like the product, and I have to stay in it for a year'?

I also put this point to Senator Kemp. Let us assume that an employee in an RSA product leaves one employer and moves to a new employer who has a different RSA product and that new employer encourages them to join their RSA product. The employee ends up in two products. Or assume they move to a new employer who has their own in-house fund and that employer requires them to join that in-house product. The employee cannot get out of their existing RSA product to transfer the money into the new fund. They are in for a year and they are charged whatever the fees and charges are for a year. It just seems to us a ludicrous situation that a time frame of a year is being imposed.

I think I am correct in saying that no other legislation on superannuation products stipulates a year. There is no stipulation in existing legislation covering other superannuation products. As I have said, it is certainly very difficult for me to recollect any product that I am aware of that says you have to remain in the product for up to a year if the bank or the other financial institutions requires it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it must be from one of the banks.

—The banks would love this. The money is locked in for a year and cannot be shifted. Where is the freedom of choice? This is worse than a normal bank account. The banks are trying to lock the money into their RSA product for a year. I have heard some criticisms of banks on their general operating of accounts, but I have not yet heard of a bank insisting that you cannot get out of a bank account for a year. I must say that I am quite amazed that the government would be attempting this sort of provision. I am surprised that we would have to encounter this sort of provision, which we are attempting to amend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will not respond to the rhetorical flourishes which seem to have crept back into the debate. Let me just make a couple of points. The coalition, in its election commitment in relation to RSAs, said that the period would be up to 12 months. That was in the election promise. I know that Senator Lundy would not want us to break an election promise.
—You break only the important ones and you keep all the dodgy ones.
—Don't be provoked, Senator. That was in the policy document. The need for a notice period arises because of the fixed term rate of RSAs. RSAs may well be three months, six months or 12 months.
—Oh, come on!
—It is highly likely that that may well be the structure. The longer term products may offer higher rates. In fact, this amendment may have the perverse effect of ensuring lower rates.
—Oh!

—It stands to reason, I would have thought, that if you have any fixed term rate for 12 months, you are likely to get a higher rate. Oh, well. I thought it stood to reason, but I am obviously not persuading at least a couple of senators. We do not believe the bill should be amended to reduce the time frame required for RSA providers to transfer an RSA holder's balance. Thirty days, which this amendment states, will ensure that RSAs have lower rates. I think that was arguing against the position Senator Allison was putting earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a 12-month period. It is up to 12 months. We are not saying that a notice period must be 12 months. We are saying it would be a notice period of up to 12 months and there will be of course, as I have pointed out, RSAs on three-month, six-month and 12-month terms. The longer the term, the higher the rate, presumably. In any case, the balance must be transferred within 12 months of the RSA provider receiving notice. That is the maximum period of time when transferring the balance of an RSA. This, in our view, allows for liquidity risk to be minimised and orderly administrative arrangements for RSA providers to be achieved.

The current requirement regarding portability of benefits in RSAs imposes more stringent requirements on RSA providers than those which apply in respect of superannuation trustees. Trustees are currently under no legislative obligation. I think that is worth noting. Trustees are under no legislative obligation to transfer benefits out of superannuation funds at the request of a member.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do.

—We are ensuring it—there is an obligation here—and it must be done within 12 months. As I said, that reflects the policy we went to the election with and which we stated. I would urge you, for the reasons I have stated, not to support the amendment which is before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have already touched on in the debate, there is a fundamental difference between an RSA product delivered by a bank and a traditional superannuation product. The trustees regulate the traditional superannuation product. They must act in the best interests of the member—non-profit. Accordingly, as I have said, it is not in the best interests of a member to unreasonably be locked into a traditional product, and they do not do it.

SPEECH.PARA: If I were a bank and I saw this provision, I would say, `Gee, this is great. We can lock the money in regardless of circumstances for up to a year and we'll do it. You have cheap, low interest workers' funds, compulsory superannuation—let's lock it in for 12 months.' You might tell us whether the notice period is required to be on the information provided to members as part of the regulation. You might tell us whether that will be a requirement. But, even if it is, I do not think that a lot of people would pick up the bank's notice period of 12 months.

The other point I would make is that many of those traditional superannuation products do offer capital guarantee and they do not need up to 12 months to resolve some sort of liquidity problem, as you are alleging in respect of banks and the other financial institutions here. I certainly cannot recall the credit unions or the building societies expressing a view about this in any way critical in the sense that they wanted a 12-month period. I do not recall that the banks commented at all in the evidence before the select committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to recap, there is no obligation, as I have pointed out to you, on superannuation funds. They are under no legislative obligation to transfer benefits out of funds at the request of a member—no obligation at all. This is actually a tougher rule in relation to RSAs. It is not a soft rule. It is a tougher rule.
—A different product.

—We are not arguing that they are different products. If they were all the same products, we would not be in here, I guess. It is a different product. We are trying to establish a regulatory regime which is appropriate and which does not unnecessarily impinge on competitive neutrality. I have put to the Senate that this directly reflects an election commitment in relation to the 12 months notice. It provides, we believe, that the notice period arises because of the fixed term rate of RSAs, and there may well be three‐, six‐ or 12‐month RSAs. The 12- month period is the maximum period. It is not the minimum period.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the arrangement allows for the development of different products. Longer term products offer higher rates. Senator Allison has been concerned about the low return on RSAs. Her amendment actually will add pressures on that front, for the reasons I have given. Higher rates may well be offered on longer term products. Your amendment goes against what you were saying to us earlier, Senator. For those reasons, we will not be supporting the amendment. Competition, market forces and consumer demands will result in varying notice periods and, of course, many may be less than 12 months.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you address that issue I raised about the regulations? Will they require the notice period?

—Yes, the regulation periods will require the disclosure of the notice period and there will be some which will actually specify less than 12 months. That will be one of the competitive aspects that some institutions will offer. So, if you are offering a short-term product—you may well say a three months product—the notice period will be very substantially less. We are putting a cap of not more than 12 months. But, if you go into an RSA, you will find that, in the 14-day period, the disclosure will require the RSA to set out the notice period. I think we would expect that the notice period may well be substantially less than the 12‐month period. In fact, it is one of the competitive aspects which we think we will bring into the marketplace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is another one of these competitive aspects, I suppose, that, theoretically, the millions of people—if that is the number that subscribe to RSAs—will have to understand. I doubt they will.

SPEECH.PARA: I put this scenario to you, Senator Kemp: a person gives notice—let us say that the period is six months; we will not go to the 12-month period. Let us say that they have to give six months notice. They have moved to another job and they are in another superannuation fund—whatever it is; it might be another RSA. So they are in two funds for that six months. Will they have to pay fees or charges during that six months—the notice period? We are accepting, for the purpose of the argument, six months notice. Will there be any prohibition on fees and charges being made by the banks on the product while it is there for the six months, the employee having given notice that he or she wants to get out of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Any fees and charges will have to be disclosed, as will the notice period. You may well have a one‐month notice period and there will be some RSAs that will be offering a one‐month notice period, presumably. That will be attractive to people who are concerned that they want to have the portability aspects of it maximised. I think there may have been a misunderstanding as the debate developed that this gave unlimited rights to RSAs to set long periods. No, no, no. That is not the case at all. RSAs will, in disclosing their fees and charges, be required to disclose the notice period.

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying that no RSA can go out and say there is more than a 12‐month notice period. But we suspect that, because of the competitive nature of the market, a lot will be offering quite short notice periods. The market, of course, will determine that. I will put it this way: we are putting a restriction on RSAs which we do not put on superannuation funds; we think this is a fair one. The reality is that some of them will be quite short notice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did the period of 12 months come from? Was any survey carried out on the existing average on superannuation products to come up with the period of 12 months?
—Senator, it originally stems from the election promise.
—What was the reason for the electorate promise?

—It was after widespread consultation, presumably for the very good reasons I have stated: for example, that banks may wish to offer longer term products. In other words, they may wish to offer a fixed term of 12 months. There seems to be some logic that they would have a 12‐month period for a longer term product which offered a longer term rate, and presumably a higher term rate. I know I will never convince you, Senator Lundy, so you can save yourself from even shaking your head. That is the basis of it, Senator.

BREAK.PARA: I think we want to avoid any misunderstanding that this allows RSAs to wait until 12 months. It will depend on the particular product which is offered. I stress that that will have to be disclosed. Longer term RSAs will presumably have a longer notice period. I do not think that is unreasonable at all. Shorter term RSAs will have a shorter notice period, which is entirely appropriate. This will put a limit on. It is not meant to provide a prescriptive instruction that all RSAs can wait until 12 months to hand the money back; that is not the case at all. The notice period will be part of the disclosure requirements which will be set out when people establish an RSA.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —You have raised a critical point, Senator Kemp. You used the words—I do not want to misquote you, so I am just paraphrasing—`presumably a greater period of notice'; you said that `presumably there could be a higher interest rate—a higher return'.
—`Could be'.

—`Could be', yes. That is an interesting assumption to make. Let us assume this is defeated. Will the ISC be carrying out any fundamental survey of that issue and the types of notice periods that will be required to be given by the financial institutions? Can you give us an undertaking that the ISC will conduct that research so that we do have some idea about the notice periods and how they relate to return?

—Senator, I am advised that the ISC will be conducting a systematic overview of how the system is operating. But I would have thought it was not a controversial statement to say that money on longer term may well achieve—
—May?

—a higher rate. I would have thought that was non‐controversial. That is why we have said that, nonetheless, there will be a limit of 12 months. But in a competitive marketplace there will presumably be a wide range of RSAs, some of which will have very short notice periods which will be disclosed at the time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did ask for an undertaking. Can you undertake, on behalf of the ISC, that the issue we have been discussing will be part of this overview research that is being carried out?
—Senator, we do not monitor individual prospectuses, but we will conduct, as I said, a systemic review of the matter. I suspect that that issue would be one which would be looked at.
—Suspect?
—We expect that that issue would be covered.

—Just one very brief point. Minister, can you describe—in point form almost—what distinguishes what you have described as an RSA, where you have to provide anywhere up to 12 months notice, from the bank products that are currently in existence called `term deposit accounts'? What are the distinctions between term deposit accounts and RSAs, beside the fact that they attract, quite specifically, superannuation contributions and the fact that employers can open them up on behalf of employees?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the fundamental and exciting aspects of it is that they are concessionally taxed. The longer term deposit accounts which you are referring to do not attract the tax concessions that are available to superannuation and will be available to RSAs. You have stated a number of other aspects which distinguish the difference, but these RSAs appropriately—and this is one of the rationales for them—do attract the tax concessions which are available to superannuation.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Murphy did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Lees did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 36 (after line 5), at the end of Division 2, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 50A Duty to inform RSA holders when balance exceeds $5,000

SPEECH.PARA: (1) When the balance in an RSA exceeds $5,000, the RSA provider must provide to the RSA holder:

PARA.TAB: (a) an information statement, in a form approved by the Commissioner, setting out the following information:

TAB.TAB: (i) the differences between an RSA and superannuation funds; and
(ii) the choices available to the RSA holder of continuing to hold an RSA, joining an industry fund or joining a superannuation fund run by the financial institution; and
(iii) average recent returns on RSAs and similar products, and low risk superannuation funds; and
(iv) such other information as the Commissioner considers necessary; and

PARA.TAB: (b) an application form, approved by the Commissioner, providing the RSA holder with the following choices:

TAB.TAB: (i) transferring the balance of the RSA to a superannuation fund; and
(ii) maintaining the RSA.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) If an RSA holder fails to return an application form sent by an RSA provider pursuant to paragraph (1)(b) within 28 days, the RSA provider must continue to administer the RSA.
(3) An RSA provider may continue to accept deposits into an RSA unless the holder of the RSA in writing directs otherwise or requests the transfer of the balance of the RSA to a superannuation fund.
(10) Page 36 (after line 5), at the end of Division 2, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 50B Duty to inform RSA holders when balance exceeds $10,000

SPEECH.PARA: (1) When the balance in an RSA exceeds $10,000, the RSA provider must provide to the RSA holder:

PARA.TAB: (a) an information statement, in a form approved by the Commissioner, setting out the following information:

TAB.TAB: (i) the differences between an RSA and superannuation funds; and
(ii) the choices available to the RSA holder of continuing to hold an RSA, joining an industry fund or joining a superannuation fund run by the financial institution; and
(iii) average recent returns on RSAs and similar products, and low risk superannuation funds; and
(iv) such other information as the Commissioner considers necessary; and

PARA.TAB: (b) an application form, approved by the Commissioner, providing the RSA holder with the following choices:

TAB.TAB: (i) transferring the balance of the RSA to a superannuation fund; and
(ii) maintaining the RSA.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) If an RSA holder fails to return an application form sent by an RSA provider pursuant to paragraph (1)(b) within 2 months, the RSA provider must:

PARA.TAB: (a) transfer the balance of the RSA into a superannuation fund approved by the Commissioner for this purpose; and
(b) inform the RSA holder of the transfer.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Subject to subsection (2), an RSA provider may continue to accept deposits into an RSA unless the holder of the RSA in writing directs otherwise or requests the transfer of the balance of the RSA to a superannuation fund.

These amendments require an RSA provider to inform an account holder when the account reaches $5,000 and again when the account reaches $10,000. The intention is that the RSA holder would be advised that they are probably better off transferring their funds to a superannuation fund. If they leave large amounts of superannuation in an RSA account, the Consumers Association calculates that their final retirement savings could be reduced by 40 per cent or more, because RSAs, of course, deliver much lower returns.

BREAK.PARA: The amendments, based on ACA recommendations, would allow account holders to opt to continue to keep their funds in an RSA if that suits them, so you have the element of choice. But if an account exceeds $10,000 and the account holder has failed to make any choice, the provisions will require the RSA provider to transfer the balance to a managed fund. In evidence, all the banks advised that they also run superannuation type funds, so this could easily be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting these amendments. I would like to make it clear what our position is. We agree with the amendments that Senator Allison moved as far as they go, but they do not go far enough for Labor. We do not accept the principle—and will not accept the principle—that the employer should be able to open the account. Having said that, we will support the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, we will get to our further amendments later. We believe that they will remove the particular problem we have with employers opening accounts on behalf of employees. As I said, to the extent that they deal with other issues about which we are concerned, we support the Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting the amendments. The RSA regulations will provide that the RSA provider be required to give certain information to the holder of the RSA when the balance first exceeds $10,000 in a period. This information is to be given at the time. That annual information is required to be given in respect of the RSA.

SPEECH.PARA: As the RSAs have not yet commenced, it is difficult to judge at this stage whether the so-called health warning should only be provided upon reaching $10,000. It is not clear whether that would have an adverse effect on significant numbers of superannuation pay-outs on retirement.

We are prepared to give an assurance to the Senate that we may well review the appropriateness of the $10,000 at a later stage. The government does not believe that it is neces sary for RSA providers to repeat this information on a regular basis to those RSA holders who retain more than $10,000 in the RSA accounts.

This is a new product. We are trying to make sure that the regulatory framework is an appropriate one. We support the health warning. Our view is that it should be at the $10,000 mark. As I said, we would keep it under review to see whether that is appropriate. We will not be supporting the amendments that Senator Allison has moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to support the amendments that have been moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 36 (after line 5), at end of Division 2, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 50A RSA provider to have liability as trustee

SPEECH.PARA: Except as provided otherwise in this Act, every director of an RSA institution is subject to the same duties and under the same liability in respect of an act or omission in relation to a trust or fiduciary duty as if he or she had been a trustee and as if RSA holders had been beneficiaries of such a trust, unless the director proves that the act or omission occurred without his or her knowledge and that he or she used all due diligence to prevent the act or omission.

I believe this measure ought to have the unanimous support of the committee. I have circulated this amendment and the other amendment to the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill. They are modelled after subsection 38(8) of the Life Insurance Act 1945 and the first print of the Life Insurance Bill 1994. The philosophy behind the amendments is that trustee duties and liabilities ought to be imposed on institutions taking the money of those seeking to provide for themselves or their dependants against the vicissitudes of life.

As I explained in my speech during the second reading debate, we are dealing here not with the money of the banks, not even with the money of the superannuation funds and not with the money of the employers but with the money of the workers. It is money that is being set aside for people, including those people who are disabled or in their old age, or for their widows and orphans.

For centuries, the law of trusts has been the body of law to which we resort in order to impose obligations where one person entrusts funds to another for the purposes of providing for others. For 50 years, the Life Insurance Act 1945 had that principle enshrined in subsection 38(8). Unfortunately, while that principle was in the first print of the Life Insurance Bill 1994, it somehow later got dropped out without debate as the Life Insurance Bill went through the House of Representatives. I am grateful to the Parliamentary Library for the backgrounder on this. It makes very interesting reading.

No explanation was given to the parliament as to why directors of life insurance companies were to be freed from trustee obligations. I gather the suggestion has been made that the particular statutory duties set out in the Life Insurance Act 1945 are superior. Let me remind senators that the first draft of the bill did not have that excised.

I do not believe the statutory duties would supersede the fiduciary duties, because the law of trusts imposes wider duties than those set out in the Life Insurance Act. In particular, a trustee is answerable to his beneficiaries where he or she makes a profit which could have gone to the beneficiaries but the trustee chooses to take an advantage or profit for himself.

The law in this area is set out in the leading case of Boardman v. Phipps. Both before and since the leading case of Keech v. Sandford in the 18th century, the courts of equity have always been rightly zealous to ensure that trustees put the interests of beneficiaries first.

The amendments I have put forward are based on the former subsection 38(8) of the Life Insurance Act 1945 and the first print of the Life Insurance Bill 1994. They are totally consistent with the policy parliament adhered to for 50 years in relation to life insurance. They are consistent with the trustee obligations imposed on superannuation fund trustees and they are, I believe, the essential starting point for any system of consumer protection. Anyone taking the public's money without a prospectus, as the RSAs will, and promising the public that they will invest that money or hold that money for their old age, disability, dependants or death should be subject to the obligations imposed by the law of trusts.

We impose the obligations of the law of trusts in the case of executors and trustees handling deceased estates. We impose the obligation of the law of trusts in the case of private and public sector superannuation funds. It would be inconsistent and unfairly disadvantageous to the community if we were not to require the accountability of trustees in the legislation before us.

From a technical point of view, I might point out that there is no conceptual problem in marrying the law of trusts and the law of contracts, or debtor and creditor. In Quistclose Investments v. Barclays Bank, the House of Lords found no difficulty in finding trust obligations attached to a loan in a private transaction. Given the legislative precedent of the Life Insurance Act 1945, there is no difficulty in imposing trustee duties and liabilities in the case of both retirement savings accounts and life insurance statutory funds.

Finally, I might also point out that this approach is also followed, and I would like the committee to focus on this, in section 200 of the New South Wales Workers Compensation Act 1987, which imposes almost identical trustee duties and liabilities on the directors of insurance companies undertaking workers compensation business. Clearly, the amendment I am putting forward is consistent with existing policy and is consistent with other proposed amendments to this legislation.

By starting with the trustee concept, we will have a clear legislative framework on which to build. Any modifications or additions to trustee obligations can then be specifically set out in the act. But I repeat: given the purposes for which the moneys are invested, the inequality of bargaining power and the trust and confidence which is reposed in these institutions, the law of contracts is not sufficient alone. The duties and liabilities of trustees are the essential foundations that need to be laid for this act to work in the public interest. I commend the amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know on this occasion that we share, as we have through most of this legislation so far, Senator Harradine's broad philosophical approach to amendments to this legislation. The amendment that Senator Harradine has moved imposes a fiduciary duty on RSA providers. We will be supporting this amendment for the following reasons, although we have some slight concern about the words `fiduciary duty', but I will come to that at the end.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been reiterated time and time again that superannuation is workers' retirement money—no‐one else's. It must be protected at all costs; that is very important. The SGC, the superannuation guarantee charge, is compulsory saving, and it is critical that members of the community are confident that their superannuation money is safe. Labor, when it was in office, with a bipartisan approach to this issue, introduced a new superannuation industry supervision regime, commonly known as SIS, which provided an improved and a higher level of protection for members.

I was involved in that to some extent, because it was at least partly based on a report that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation undertook particularly in regard to some experiences in the United Kingdom with the Maxwell fraud. The committee—which I then chaired and of which the deputy chair at the time, Senator Watson, is now chair—pointed out some of the difficulties in relation to theft and fraud, return on investment and the sole purpose test. Certainly, in part, the new SIS regime that was introduced was based on the concerns identified in that superannuation committee report, as well as on the general change in building the superannuation system. So for these general reasons, we support Senator Harradine's approach.

I do have a concern about the due diligence defence, Senator Harradine. I do not know whether it is possible for you to look at some alternative words in respect of those couple of words on the fifth line of your amendment. I understand the Democrats have some concerns as well. I indicate that, at the end of the day, we will support this amendment, Senator Harradine, but it may be necessary to consider some alternative wording in that area if the amendment is to be passed. But at the end of the day we will be supporting your amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats are also inclined to support Senator Harradine's amendment, but we do have a concern about due diligence. In fact, we would much prefer to see that last phrase about due diligence in the amendment dropped. Our advice from the Consumers Association was that this would, to put it in its words, `allow financial institutions to drive legal trucks through those measures'. So I wonder if Senator Harradine would perhaps outline in a bit more detail the scope that he sees due diligence providing. I would just indicate that, again, we would prefer it if that last part of the amendment was removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to what has been proposed by Senator Harradine, we should always work on the basis—and I think it has been pointed out before—that the money we are dealing with is workers' money. It started off as being workers forgoing a wage increase to actually bring about the introduction of superannuation from a compulsory point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I have a question with regard to the protection measures from the point of view of ensuring that employers actually do pay the money into an RSA. Whilst there appear to be some penalty provisions for breaches of the act, I am not sure how we would go about checking other than under part 10, where you talk about monitoring and investigating RSA providers whereby you make the power available for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to appoint people to actually do that.

I would be interested to see what the government's view is on how the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is situated to do that in the first place, given its funding and given that it has had major problems in conducting its responsibilities even for superannuation funds, let alone for new products such as RSAs, which could be spread across a whole plethora of financial institutions. It is a huge job and I do not think the Insurance and Superannuation Commission would even be capable of doing it; it has not got the funding to do it, for a start.

That is why Senator Harradine's amendment is so important. What happens if penalties are to apply—and, if I understood it correctly, the penalty appears to apply to the provider? The provider could be, for instance, the National Australia Bank. In so far as any breach is concerned, it would have the financial wherewithal to string out for a long period any challenge about any wrongdoing on its part. So, if you take the step of making individuals responsible, as is the case with superannuation funds—in so far as trustees are concerned where they have that fiduciary obligation placed upon them—then I think it is a step that will ensure greater probity, if we are to end up with RSAs. Quite frankly, I think it is the most stupid thing the government has brought before this parliament to this point in time. The government is trying to introduce this and it talks about choice, et cetera when there is no choice. All you are talking about is giving more money to banks to rip off the poor old punters out there that they are currently ripping off.

Nevertheless, we are debating the legislation; I hope it gets defeated ultimately. I will come back to the question of monitoring. I have had experience with regard to employers even paying moneys into a fund. Even though they are obligated by the Industrial Relations Act under award provisions to pay into industry superannuation funds, there is often the case where they do not.

I am not quite sure whether I understand this legislation. You say there are obligations for them to present records, et cetera and requirements about whom they should present them to. How are you going to check whether employers, particularly with regard to itinerant workers, are actually paying the money in? It is a problem now, but at least there is a capacity in certain industries for unions representing workers, by checking on an employer in an industry, to seek information from a particular superannuation fund as to whether or not an employer is actually mak ing contributions on behalf of certain employees. I am not sure that this proposed legislation provides any mechanism for that.

I think it is very thin on the ground with regard to the monitoring and investigating processes. That is why it is important that we at least take another step in the right direction—if we are to have these stupid things—by supporting the amendment of Senator Harradine, which would at least put more obligation on the people who will be managing these pathetic savings accounts at the end of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am not too sure the debate is advanced by some of the epithets you used. This product has been widely welcomed. It was an election promise. You are a strong supporter and wish to protect the industry funds; we understand that. We understand where you are coming from.
—I want to protect workers' money.

—You do not want to protect the workers; you want to protect the unions. There is a bit of a difference. I will deal with Senator Murphy's points first. The payment of contributions deducted from salary and wages must be remitted in relation to the RSA provider within 28 days, and payment of SG contributions by an employer is an enforcement issue of the tax office and is a matter for the tax office. Payment of super contributions under industrial awards is an industrial relations issue. The ISC responsibility is for the moneys once they are in fact in the system.
—You ought to check with the tax office and see how well it worked there.

—I am responding to your questions. The ISC responsibility, as I said, is for the moneys once they are in the super system. That is to ensure that funds and RSA providers comply with standards and RSA providers are subject to the prudential supervision for financial safety and soundness by the RBA.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine has moved an amendment to the Life Insurance Act 1995 and attempts to reinsert a provision which was deleted from the Life Insurance Act 1945. Two senators have spoken in this debate. Senator Sherry had particular concerns with aspects of the amendment. Although he was happy to support it in principle, he was unhappy with the wording. Senator Allison also raised some issues in relation to it and in relation to due diligence and whether those particular words were needed.

Senator Sherry drew on the bipartisanship which used to exist, and we used to give him support. The Labor Party brought in the Life Insurance Act 1995. Senator, it was introduced by your government and it inserted new provisions which required directors of life insurance companies to give priority to the interests of policy owners over shareholders. These are akin, as Senator Sherry would know, to fiduciary duties of trustees, but they recognise the non‐trust based nature of life policies. We thought that you actually got it right in 1995. You brought that provision in, and we supported it. These new provisions, Senator, as you will recall, have made the onerous duties of life insurance directors explicit.

This is consistent with the ruling of the Supreme Court of Victoria in the Occidental‐Regal case, which stated categorically that the statutory funds of life offices were not trusts. This was confirmed by the Court of Appeal. You got it right in 1995, Senator. I am surprised that, for someone who often calls on bipartisanship in this area, which I do not dispute—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's gone. I declared that dead last week.

—I know you declared it dead, because you are not adopting an entirely constructive attitude to some of these things. The courts have categorically ruled that statutory funds of life offices are not trusts. We will not be supporting Senator Harradine's amendment, because it is out of step with contemporary case law, which is reflected in the current life act.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the matter that has been raised by Senator Allison. Senator, this may or may not be your intention, but I will put it on the record so that you may reflect on it. The advice I have notes that the suggested removal of the due diligence defence would place even more onerous burdens, as I understand it, on directors of RSA providers. I do not know whether it was your intention to remove that—perhaps it was. It is your intention? We do not agree with it. We accept the argument if not the rationale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an awful misunderstanding here, and I am sorry if I have contributed to it in any way. When the Assistant Treasurer dealt with my amendment, he indicated that it was an amendment to the Life Insurance Act. It is no such thing. This is an amendment to the legislation that is currently before us and would be inserted on page 36 of that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I believe that no-one in this committee would deny that these RSAs in effect are holding workers' moneys in trust. In trust for whom—for the workers themselves, for their widows and children? This is what we are dealing with. I believe that no-one around the chamber would consider that these moneys should be treated as other than trusts and that, therefore, the duty of trust reposes on the directors.

I would like to indicate that my amendment really recognises this and indicates that there is an obligation for the directors to act industriously and with assiduousness and absolute care in upholding the trust that is reposed in them by the workers. I thought that the government would actually support this amendment.

I turn to the points that have been made by Senator Allison and Senator Sherry about the amendment which related to the defence of due diligence. I acknowledge their point, and I would be prepared to seek leave to amend the provision. In fact, it is a reverse onus of proof: the onus of proof is put onto those who have given their trust to the directors.

I put it to Senator Sherry and Senator Allison that a defence of no knowledge is fair. For example, if a director proves that the action or omission occurred without his or her knowledge, I think that that is a reasonable defence, for goodness sake. I would be happy to delete the last provision which says `and that he or she used all due diligence to prevent the act or omission'. I seek leave to have my amendment so amended.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I referred to the Life Insurance Act 1995 because I think you foreshadowed an amendment to that. I addressed the matters there. In relation to this amendment you have moved, the RSAs are deposits held by a bank, building society, credit union or life insurance company. These arrangements are protected by the creditor‐debtor arrangements of the deposit and contractual nature of life insurance policies. There is no need to provide for the protection of a trust where these structures are in place. RSA providers are non-trust entities, and in place in the non-trust structure is stringent—I stress that—prudential supervision in respect of capital adequacy and solvency under the Reserve Bank, AFIC and life insurance regimes.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from this protection—you were concerned about protection, and rightly so—the bill also provides for RSA holders with the ability to seek damages against an RSA provider if they breach the capital guarantee requirement placed on RSAs. We will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just briefly respond—and I will be brief because I know the time constraints that are upon us all. The minister did not really say why the government would not agree to a simple amendment like this which recognises the very extraordinary fact that the RSAs are to be, in effect, the holders in trust of superannuation moneys which cannot be accessed by the beneficiaries at will. In fact, the beneficiaries in many cases will be the widows and orphans of the beneficiary.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this idea and this concept can live with the statutory requirements to which you referred. Why can't it live with the strategy requirements to which you just referred? Put simply, why can't they coexist?

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate that in place of the type of trust structure which Senator Harradine referred to there is stringent prudential supervision in respect of capital adequacy and solvency under the Reserve Bank, AFIC and life insurance regimes. The imposition of a trust relationship on RSA institutions is inconsistent with the nature of the product and—
—Why?
—You have not explained, Senator, why the trust protection is necessary in light of the very tight prudential supervision. We do not see that it is needed.
—That is not true!
—Senator, you and I may have to differ on that. We do not see that it is needed because there is already tight prudential supervision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for the amendment he has moved. As I indicated, we believe this is an appropriate amendment in the circumstances. RSAs are a new type of product, and we believe that the security for what are compulsory savings should be as enhanced as is practical and feasible, balancing it against the commercial intent of banks but being mindful that the overwhelming consideration here is that of the compulsory savings of workers' retirement income that, as Senator Harradine has pointed out, those workers may not receive in certain circumstances—for example, because of death—and that their next of kin will receive. We believe this approach by Senator Harradine is quite reasonable.
—The question is that Senator Harradine's amendment, as amended, be agreed to.
—I just want to check with Senator Colston how he is voting.
—I abstain.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (9) Clause 51, page 37 (line 6), omit ", or the employer of that person,".
(10) Clause 51, page 37 (lines 14 to 25), omit paragraphs (c) and (d), substitute:
(c) the application is made in respect of not more than one person; and
(d) when the person received the form, the person also received:

TAB.TAB: (i) such additional information (if any) and such additional documents (if any) as are required by a determination made under subsection (3); and
(ii) and information statement that complies with subsection (2A); and

BREAK.PARA: (e) the person making the application certifies that he or she has received the information referred to in paragraph (d) and understands the characteristics of, and risks associated with, RSAs.
(11) Clause 51, page 37 (after line 25), after subclause (2), insert:

TAB.TAB: (2A) A person who applies for a RSA must be provided with a statement, approved by the Commissioner, which sets out in plain English the following information:
(a) a clear and concise statement of the differences between an RSA and a superannuation fund;

(b) a clear and concise statement of the choices available to an RSA holder of maintaining an RSA, or transferring the balance to an industry‐based, employer sponsored or public offer superannuation fund; and
(c) a clear and concise statement of recent average investment performance of RSAs compared with industry‐based, employer sponsored or public offer superannuation funds; and
(d) an explanation about the low‐risk nature of RSAs, their low‐growth potential and their limitations as retirement savings vehicles; and
(e) a clear and concise statement of any fees and charges in relation to the RSA.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 9 removes the ability of the employer to lodge an application form for the provision of an RSA on behalf of an employee. This is absolutely fundamental to the Australian Labor Party. We have touched on this issue previously. Senator Kemp says that employers lodge an application form for employees in current industry and traditional in-house company funds, but RSAs are a different product, a commercial product, offered by banks and other financial institutions. It is a different situation.

We do not believe that employers should be signing up employees. There will unfortunately be elements of coercion on some occasions. We believe that it is totally unacceptable for an employer to open an account on behalf of an employee. It is the employee's money. It is to be their retirement income. Why should the employer have that sort of relatively unrestricted ability to sign up employees?

These RSAs are a low growth, low return product. The Consumers Association produced research that showed that an individual remaining in an RSA during the period of their working life can be up to $200,000 worse off, depending on earnings. This situation is not acceptable to the Labor opposition.

In respect of amendment No. 11, we are inserting a new section after clause 51 to set out in the disclosure statement—that is, to be the provider to the individual when seeking an application to open an RSA. It requires a clear and concise statement. This means that the statement must be in plain English, must be readily understood and must articulate the differences between an RSA and superannuation. That is, an RSA is a low growth, low return product which is not an adequate vehicle for long‐term retirement savings. It must be made known to the applicant that there are alternative choices available when the opening of an RSA occurs. There are public office superannuation, industry and employer sponsored funds.

It must be made clear to the individual that the individual is able to transfer the balance of the RSA to another fund. It must set out the average performance of RSAs as compared to industry, employer and other types of superannuation funds. We have traversed the issue of fees and charges. We believe that these amendments 9 and 11 are absolutely necessary to ensure the security of workers' compulsory retirement savings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats will oppose both amendments 10 and 11. We think amendment 10 is a problem and our amendment allows for an employer to enter into an RSA in the very limited circumstances that the employee has failed to nominate a fund within 28 days. This may or may not be a common occurrence, but we think it is reasonable that there be a mechanism by which an RSA can be opened in the event of that failure.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose amendment 11 because we think it is somewhat too radical. As long as a person has received the information and as long as the ISC has approved the information provided to the consumer, we do not think we need the additional safeguards sought by the opposition. However, I think the opposition's suggestion that applications only be lodged on behalf of one person is a good safeguard and I have circulated a supplementary amendment to insert this after my amendment No. 12. So we would prefer to see in place Democrat amendments Nos 11 to 14, which I will move following these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In my consideration of the government program, I neglected to outline our reasoning for amendment 10. That inserts three new paragraphs which set out what would satisfy the test of an eligible application form. Briefly, our reasoning in respect of paragraph (c) requires that an RSA provider must receive a separate application for each individual. This is in keeping with Labor's position that if the government is to be true to its rhetoric of choice, the choice must be of the individual.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of paragraph (d), this requires that the individual receives certain information prior to signing the application to open an RSA. We believe this is critical information that will ensure the individual is aware of how RSA products compare with industry, public and employer sponsored funds.

In respect of paragraph (e), this amendment has the effect of requiring the individual to sign the application and acknowledge that they have actually witnessed, read and understood the nature of the product.

BREAK.PARA: The Democrats have indicated their opposition to amendment 10. I have paraphrased my support for amendment 10 in the interests of time. I am cognisant of the likely result on 10 and 11.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, not surprisingly, opposed to the amendments moved by Senator Sherry. They have one clear, explicit aim—
—Choice.

—No. Their clear, explicit aim, Senator, as you well know, is to attempt to sink RSAs. That is the implicit aim of what you are on about. You are too honest at times, Senator, but we regard this as an amendment which must be defeated. We regard it as an unfair amendment. The key policy objective of RSAs was to assist small business in meeting SG obligations. RSAs aim to be a convenient, low cost, accessible vehicle for small employers. This will not be achieved if the employer cannot open an RSA on behalf of an employee. So we will be opposing your amendment. The RSA bill is based—and again we get back to the competitive neutrality—on the existing SI(S) Act 1993. Section 153 of the SI(S) Act currently allows for an employer to open an account in a superannuation fund on behalf of their employees and it is current practice for some public offer superannuation funds. As such, a similar requirement has been included in the RSA bill.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are after competitive neutrality—and we are—I would have thought that you are attempting to impose on RSAs an obligation which you are not prepared to see in relation to superannuation. It is worth noting that in response to a question by Senator Conroy on whether an employee must sign an application form to become a member of a master trust, Mr Steven Child, representing LISA, said an employer opens the account for the employee without the need for the employee to complete a separate application form.

It is also consistent with the superannuation guarantee legislation, which places the obligation on the employer to contribute to a fund on behalf of employees. This minimises costs and maximises convenience for employers, particularly in small business, in discharging their SG obligations.

We are very much opposed to the amendment that you have moved, Senator Sherry. Though you recognise that the government has a clear mandate for RSAs, you have revealed with this amendment an attempt to sink the whole concept of RSAs, and we are opposed to what you are trying to do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I wish it would, but it won't. Senator Allison used a description that we rarely hear about the Labor Party these days: `somewhat radical'. I am pleased to accept the compliment, Senator Allison. I am not pleased at your position, but we will get to your amendments. Even though they are not as radical as what we are proposing, we will not have much choice, I suspect, when we get to them next.
—I just wish to reiterate that I think Senator Sherry has confirmed what I was saying: they are very radical amendments.
—Getting radical!
—At times—not all the time but at times—you are a little bit too honest.

—Minister, could you explain to the committee just what identification an employer has to provide to a provider of a RSA upon opening an account on behalf of a particular person. On what basis does the employer have to provide ongoing advice to the provider of the RSA that that account still exists and that in fact the employee is still an employee of the employer? Thirdly, what checks and balances exist within this act to ensure that in fact the employer is satisfying the requirements of the super guarantee with those instalments?
—Senator, later I will be moving some amendments to the Financial Transaction Reports Act; this debate will come up later. They will include, of course, the name, address and date of birth.

—So, Minister, the proof required by the provider of the RSA differs significantly to that information required to open a normal bank account or term deposit account with that institution. I am just seeking clarification as to what concession you are providing banks in opening these accounts.

—Senator, do not get too paranoid about banks. These are what is required to open accounts, but to exit an account greater detail is certainly required. It involves the 100‐point test which banks are under.
—Senator Sherry has moved three amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, could I ask that we deal with amendment No. 9 separately, because the Democrats have indicated a different position, and then take Nos 10 and 11 together.
—You have anticipated my question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 51, page 37 (lines 14 to 25), omit paragraphs (c) and (d), substitute:
(c) if the application is made by the person who will be the holder—when the person received the form, the person also received:

PARA.TAB: (i) such additional information (if any) and such additional documents (if any) as are required by a determination made under subsection (3); and

PARA.TAB: (i) such additional information (if any) and such additional documents (if any) as are required by a determination made under subsection (3); and
(ii) an information statement that complies with subsection (2A) and any determination made under subsection (3) for the purpose of subsection (2A).

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 51, page 37 (line 25), at the end of subclause (2), add:
and

(e) if the application is made by the employer—the application is accompanied by a statement from the employer certifying that the employee was given the opportunity to nominate whether to contribute to an RSA or another fund and failed to do so within 28 days or such other shorter period of time as is provided for in the determination made for this purpose under subsection (3); and
(13) Clause 51, page 37 (after line 25), after subclause (2), insert:
(2A) A person who applies for an RSA must be provided with a statement approved by the Commissioner which sets out in plain English the following information:

PARA.TAB: (a) a clear and concise statement of recent investment performance of RSAs and similar products; and
(b) an estimate by the RSA provider of the likely performance of RSAs over the following 12 month and two year periods respectively; and
(c) a clear and concise statement of any fees and charges in relation to the RSA; and
(d) an explanation of the dispute resolution process; and
(e) an explanation of the preservation, access and transfer rules in relation to the RSA; and
(f) an explanation of the freedom of choice provisions in section 51A; and
(g) any other matters as may be determined by the Commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Clause 51, page 37 (line 27), omit "subsection (2)", substitute "subsections (2) or (2A)".
(15) Clause 51, page 37 (line 25), at the end of subclause (2), add:

TAB.TAB: ; and (f) the application is made in respect of not more than one person.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments seek to restrict the circumstances in which an employer can open up an RSA on behalf of an employee. Our concern is that employers will effectively force employees to join RSAs offering lower rates of return than industry funds and that employees might not be in an informed position to transfer their funds in the narrow 14‐day cooling‐off period provided by clause 61.

Amendments Nos 11‐14 will add additional information requirements to be provided to the employees before they apply to join a RSA. Central to this is explaining the advantages and disadvantages of joining an RSA.
