The amendments do not prevent an employer applying on behalf of an employee, but only when the employee has failed to make a choice of superannuation vehicle within 28 days, which is our amendment No. 12.

It might be useful if I foreshadow what is intended from the other amendments. Amendment No. 15 seeks to partially implement the government's own freedom of choice policy by making it clear that employees should be given the choice at least of joining an industry super fund—which funds are currently delivering returns twice that of bank term deposits—an RSA with the financial institution to which their salary is paid or the RSA nominated by the employer. We think this is an essential provision to ensure that employers cannot force employees to join a substandard RSA, bearing in mind that RSAs will not have that trustee structure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that Senator Allison made comments in respect of amendment 15, but we have an amendment before we get to that one. We will support Democrat amendments 11 to 14. As I indicated earlier, we took a somewhat more radical approach which has regrettably been defeated. Certainly, as an adequate fallback measure, we will be supporting amendments 11 to 14 moved by the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We will strongly oppose amendments 11 to 14 moved by the Democrats. These amendments require employee consent before an employer can open an RSA. It is inconsistent with existing requirements under section 153 of the SI(S) Act. This is yet another attempt to create an uneven playing field. This attempt has been relentless all through the evening.
—Wait until tomorrow!
—We have not seen your amendments, or have we seen your amendments?
—We have not seen your latest amendments either.

—We may have seen your amendments but they have not been claimed to be your amendments. This is inconsistent with the existing superannuation requirements under section 153 of the SI(S) Act. It creates an uneven playing field and is part of the broad thrust of the amendments coming from the opposition. In our view, it also imposes an undue administrative burden on an employer, especially on small business. This government is about small business. We have a particular view on small business which you may not share, but these RSAs will be of considerable assistance in that area. Small business will have to get details from casual and itinerant workers who may have moved on. We do not think that is efficient.

SPEECH.PARA: Another question was whether employers should be required to use a separate application form for each RSA opened on behalf of an employee. The RSA Bill does not restrict an RSA institution from accepting a single application from an employer to open an RSA for more than one employee. Where this occurs, the application must contain enough information to enable the RSA institution to be able to provide relevant disclosure documentation to the employees. I stress that this is consistent with similar provisions in the SI(S) Act which do not restrict an employer from opening a number of accounts in a superannuation fund with a single application form. That is, any requirement to provide that individual applications be used each time an employer opens an RSA on behalf of an employee would be inconsistent with current practice in the superannuation industry.

A lot of arguments which are now being brought forward are attempting not to assist employees and employers but to disadvantage RSAs on what should be a competitively neutral playing field with the superannuation industry. We believe such a requirement provides little benefit to employees and yet imposes a significant administrative burden on both RSA providers and employers. We will be strongly opposing the amendments that the Democrats have moved. I urge the Senate to reject the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to remind the minister about the policy of the government in relation to choice, because that is what is at the heart of these amendments. I remind the minister that the coalition said:

SPEECH.PARA: The small amounts problem which could be resolved by allowing employees greater freedom to choose the fund into which contribution may be consolidated, the current inflexibility of the superannuation system is contrary to other areas of policy . . . The coalition accepts that unlimited freedom of choice would impose an onerous and costly burden on employers. However, limited freedom of choice will provide the benefits of competition . . .

We are not talking about unbridled, unlimited freedom of choice. We are talking about giving sufficient information to employees at the point at which they enter an RSA so that they have some sort of choice. That is the purpose of these amendments.

Otherwise we do not believe there is any real choice for employees in the bill as it presently stands. We feel very strongly about these amendments. We think they are central to the whole question of choice and to the protection of RSA holders potentially. I urge the Senate to think very carefully about these amendments and to support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —We strongly oppose what you say, Senator Allison. You are not about choice; you are about trying to disadvantage RSAs compared with superannuation. You are not prepared to have the same general rules which apply to superannuation apply to RSAs.
—Different product.

—You and I agree that they are different products, but we are putting a regulatory framework in place which we believe should be competitively neutral. I think you raised that issue earlier. You are not doing that, and this does not do that. Your amendments were very radical. You were determined in one blow to sink RSAs. That failed, and so it should have. We do not believe that the amendments moved by Senator Allison are about choice; they are about weighting the balance greatly in favour of superannuation. If you were about choice, Senator Allison, you would be about trying to establish a reasonably competitively neutral playing field.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if an employee has not filled in an application form, there is money in the account, and they die?
—It goes into a suspense account and then on to their estate.
—What if there is no will?
—The law of intestacy would cut in, Senator.
—The question is that amendments 11 to 14 on amendment sheet No. 457, moved by Senator Allison, be agreed to. Senator Colston, are you voting no?
—That is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 37 (after line 30), at the end of Division 3, add:

An RSA institution must not, intentionally or recklessly, allow a person to become the holder of an RSA unless the RSA institution has verified the identity of the person in accordance with the verification procedures in relation to the opening of accounts, prescribed under the Financial Transactions Reports Act 1988 .
Penalty: 100 penalty units.

The effect of this provision is to ensure that the RSA provider is able to verify the identity of the individual attempting to open the account. You would think this would be pretty basic, but I am sure Senator Kemp is going to find some reason for arguing that this is not a level playing field. We will see.

BREAK.PARA: I will be brief because of time. The government informed the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that there was no need to amend the bill in this way, as the matter will be dealt with in the regulations. Unfortunately, we do not know the government's intent in the regulations, so we believe this is an issue that should be dealt with in the legislation. There is currently no mechanism in the bill to ensure that employers actually open accounts on behalf of their employees, so we believe that verification is very important. I am paraphrasing our arguments in the interest of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this touched on an issue that Senator Lundy raised earlier. I think, Senator, what you are seeking to do is impose the full 100-point test at the point of entry. We stress that that does not apply at the point of entry, but the 100-point test will be required on the point of exit. We believe that our arrangements are efficient and that they provide proper protection. We wonder whether Senator Harradine may not, for once, support us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The way the minister has described RSAs and the product, I would have thought that the requirements of the Financial Transaction Reports Act would have fitted perfectly into the scene in respect of our application. That is why I am supporting the opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Page 37 (after line 30), at the end of Division 3, add:

TAB.TAB: 51A Freedom of choice

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An employer must not provide an employee with an application form to open an RSA unless the employer:

PARA.TAB: (a) if there is a relevant industry‐based superannuation fund—also provides an application form for that fund; or

(b) if there is no relevant industry‐based superannuation fund—also provides an application form for a superannuation fund which may accept payments from the employer under the superannuation guarantee scheme; and

(c) if the employee is paid by electronic funds transfer to an RSA institution—informs the employee that the employer will deposit funds into an RSA provided by that institution if the employee so directs; and
(d) provides the employee with an information statement that complies with subsection 51(2A) and any determination made under subsection 51(3) for the purpose of subsection 51(2A); and

(e) informs the employee that a period of 28 days exists for the employee to make a choice, but if the employee has not made a choice at the end of 28 days, the employer will choose an RSA on behalf of the employee.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Contravention of subsection (1) is an offence.

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 10 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Where an employee becomes an RSA holder and the employer has not fulfilled the requirements of subsection (1), the RSA provider must transfer the balance in the RSA to an account or fund of the employee's choice, if the employee so requests, without imposing any charges on the RSA holder.

Democrat amendment No. 15 partially implements, in our view, the government's own position on freedom of choice policy by making it clear that employees should be given the choice of at least joining an industry super fund. If they are not to be given a choice between RSAs, then they ought to at least be able to choose an industry super fund or something similar.

We believe this legislation not only fails to expand the opportunities for choice to employees but, in fact, imbeds a process which precludes employee choice. Section 51 of the act permits an employer to open up an account without the consent of an employee—we have discussed that at some length—and allows an employer to continue to direct contributions to an RSA even after the employee has directed to transfer funds to another fund.

So, all in all, there is a great deal within this act which works against the matter of choice. Amendment No. 15 would, at least, put in place some aspect of choice for the employee. I urge the Senate to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the Senate is aware, but we have an amendment to the Democrats' amendment. I could not see it on the running sheet, but we have circulated it. It is on sheet No. 454.
—Yes, we have that.
—Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 15, paragraph 51A(1)(e), omit "will choose an RSA on behalf of the employee", substitute "must deposit contributions into a superannuation fund".

We have moved this amendment because we do not believe that an RSA should be the automatically elected vehicle that should be chosen. There are other options available. We believe that this is the appropriate fallback position. That is why we are moving this particular amendment to the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, we are coming back to the general arguments which underlie so many of the amendments which have been moved by the Labor Party. What is involved in this is simply inconsistent with existing SIS arrangements. It is another effort to bias the playing field against RSAs.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Allison, I welcome your constant reiteration of choice, but I have to tell you that virtually all of your amendments are opposed to choice and are an attempt to bias the playing field against RSAs. That is quite inconsistent with the policy that we went to the election on and which we were elected on.

As I said, what you are moving is inconsistent with existing SIS arrangements. It creates an uneven playing field and, again, imposes undue burdens on employers. We are about making things efficient. We are about creating choice. We are about putting into effect a policy which we were elected on, and we urge the Senate to reject the amendments that are before the chamber.
Amendment (Senator Sherry's) negatived.
Amendment (Senator Allison's) negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Clause 52, page 38 (line 6), omit "Subject to subsections (2), (3) and (4), an", substitute "An".
(14) Clause 52, page 38 (line 7), after "person", insert "who is the potential holder of an RSA".
(15) Clause 52, page 38 (lines 16 to 19), omit subclause (2), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (2) An RSA institution must not intentionally or recklessly, allow a person who is the potential holder of an RSA to become the holder of an RSA unless the RSA institution is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the person has received information that relates to an event or change of circumstances that happened after the RSA institution received the application to become an RSA holder.

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 100 penalty units

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 52, page 38 (lines 20 and 21), omit subclause (3), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (3) In subsections (1) and (2), reasonable grounds include that an application from which contains a statement, to the effect that the person who is applying for an RSA has received an explanation and understands the disclosure documentation, has been signed by the person.

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Clause 52, page 38 (line 22), omit "Subsection (1) does not", substitute "Subsections (1) and (2) do not".

In respect of amendment 13, we are reorganising the operation of the provision. As a result of this amendment, if it is carried, the RSA provider will have to comply with all of the subsections contained in section 52. We are moving this amendment because we believe it is critical that the RSA provider takes responsibility for ensuring that an individual becomes a holder of an RSA after receiving all relevant documentation and after being made aware of the consequences of their decision. We believe that is quite fundamental.

Amendment 14 is an amendment to change the subsection by inserting the words `who is the potential holder of an RSA'. This is a relatively minor wording amendment. I do not know whether you could consider accepting that, Senator Kemp, because it is a very minor change.

Amendment 15 omits section 52(2) and inserts a new subsection that requires the RSA provider to be satisfied that the holder of the RSA has received all information regarding any change of circumstances after the application was initially lodged. We believe it is important that the RSA provider be responsible in ensuring that the holder of the RSA is made aware of changed events or circumstances. This is the only way Labor will be convinced that holders of RSAs are continually informed about the nature and the type of product that is RSAs.

The section we seek to omit and substitute removes the responsibility on RSA providers to inform individuals of changing circumstances. If the situation is to remain that employers are able to open RSAs on behalf of employees—this is something we have been fundamentally opposed to—then it is doubly imperative that employees are made aware of all changes in events and circumstances relating to the provision of RSAs. Even if it is solely the individual's choice as to the opening of an RSA, it is still imperative that the RSA provider inform them of any change in circumstances which may alter the offering of the product.

Amendment 16 omits section 52(3) and substitutes a new subsection which sets out the grounds on which it is reasonable for an RSA provider to be assured of the individual's consent to the opening of the RSA. There are reasons for this approach. Firstly, the Australian Banking Association raised a number of important points in its submission to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation regarding the deficiency in the bills in defining what would constitute reasonable grounds for the RSA provider to assume there had been consent and knowledge surrounding the opening of the RSA.

The opposition proposes that the reasonable grounds include the provision of an application form, which would contain statements outlining the nature of the product, and the signing of the application by the individual. This would ensure that the RSA provider could be satisfied that the individual did understand their decision to open an RSA and would ensure the RSA provider a defence to any allegation that they had recklessly or intentionally allowed an individual to open an RSA without full knowledge of the product. We believe this amendment, in concert with previous amendments to eligible applications, provides a strong disclosure regime that will ensure that individual consumers receive adequate information for what is a new type of product.

Our amendment 17 is a rewriting of this section for the purposes of completeness. In not moving to delete section 52(4), we reserve the right to examine the regulations and, where it will be necessary, to seek disallowance to those regulations. I am noting this in passing in respect of our amendment 17. It is important to note that by not deleting section 52(4) we are not necessarily accepting regulations that would give force to this subsection. We have not seen the regulations yet. We do not know the detail of what would be contained in them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —All the amendments moved by Senator Sherry flow from the opposition's policy to remove the ability of the employer to open an account on behalf of the employee. That is the fundamental position of the opposition. It is not our position. Implicit in our policy is that we have quite a different approach to that of the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already opposed these amendments and the underlying principles on the grounds of competitive neutrality and efficiency. We will not be supporting the amendments which have been moved by the Labor Party. It is yet another attempt to put into effect Labor's policy, the opposition's policy. It is not our policy. Our policy has a different approach. We believe that there should be a level playing field and a competitive neutrality between these two types of superannuation products.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support opposition amendment No. 13. We think that that is self-explanatory and arises from the evidence given to the committee. We also support amendments Nos 14 and 15. We think that they will provide that a financial institution be satisfied that a potential applicant has received the necessary information.

BREAK.PARA: We will also support amendment No. 16, because we think that this will keep RSA providers more honest and ensure that they are up to date. But the Democrats will not support amendment No. 17. We have our amendment No. 16, which we would prefer to substitute for that amendment. We do not think that this flows logically from the rest of the group of amendments that are put. Whilst we support a stronger disclosure regime, we think this may just be making it a little too difficult for RSAs to be opened up. I do not know whether we want an indication of the general support for these amendments to see whether it is worth while removing amendment No. 17 and considering that separately.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be seeking leave to withdraw our amendment No. 17 and support the Democrat amendment No. 16 when it is put. So we will be seeking for amendments Nos 13 to 16 to be put together.

—We will be opposing the amendments which have been proposed. I think Senator Allison put it as well as I could. The reality is that this is an attempt to make it too hard and difficult to open an RSA account. That is the opposition's position. It is not our position.

—Before we proceed, I want to clarify with Senator Allison which of the opposition amendments she sees in conflict with hers. The running sheet I have says that opposition amendment No. 16 is in conflict with Democrats amendment No. 16.
—I believe the running sheet is incorrect. It is opposition amendment No. 17 which is in conflict with our amendment No. 16.
—Just to clarify it, I think amendments Nos 13, 14, 15 and 16 of Senator Sherry's—amendment No. 17 has been omitted—
—It has not been dealt with yet. It has been moved; leave has to be sought to withdraw it. We dealing with opposition amendments Nos 13 to 16 at the moment.
—I ask the minister, in relation to amendment No. 13—it seems to me to be reasonable, but obviously the government does not think so—to explain to me why you are not happy with it.

—We will be moving some amendments later in the debate. This is to the financial transactions report. We will be dealing with the issues of the point of entry, which we think are reasonable, and the point of exit. That debate has been covered. This is the 100-point test. We do not accept the 100-point test at the point of commencing an account. But, on the point of exit from an account, the 100-point test which is used for bank accounts will be applied. We will be dealing with that particular matter later. I am not sure whether I can add more to it. I think you asked about item 13; is that right?
—Yes.

—I think there may be some confusion on running sheets here, Senator. Just bear with us. We believe that it would argue against our fundamental position to allow an employer to open an account for an employee. We do not accept that the arguments that are put there are valid. Again, it is part of the general thrust of most of these amendments, which is to bias the choice against RSAs.

—Before we proceed, I have just had further advice. It is my understanding that it is opposition amendment 16 that is in conflict with Democrats amendment 16, not opposition amendment 17. They are the two amendments that deal with subclause (3). I am seeking to clarify whether it is opposition amendment 16 or opposition amendment 17 that conflicts with proposed Democrat amendment 16 before we proceed.

—I am looking at those two amendments in front of me. The ALP's amendment 16 relates to clause 52, page 38, as does our amendment 16, but to lines 16 and 19. It omits subclause (2) and substitutes (2), whereas the Democrats' amendment 16 omits subclause (3) and substitutes a new (3).

—I think you are working on an old sheet, Senator. The advice I have available to me suggests that what you are reading from is an older sheet. My understanding is that a more updated version was presented in the chamber.
—Senator Kemp, on that point, in lines 20 and 21 we omit subclause (3) and substitute `definition'.
—Sixteen or 17?
—It is our amendment 16.
—This is the only sheet of opposition amendments that I have.
—I don't know how we have progressed so far—but not with great effect.

—Looking at the sheets which the clerk has before us at the table, it is the two amendments 16 that are in conflict. The clerk will check with you now, Senator Allison, as to what sheet you are working from.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: KEMP

TALK.START.PARA: —The clerk having spoken to Senator Allison, could we get some advice now from the non‐government parties as to what they are trying to do?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator SHERRY (Tasmania—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (9.25 p.m.) I ask that amendment 13 be put separately; I seek leave to withdraw our amendment 16 and support Democrat amendment No. 16 because they are in conflict; and I ask that amendments Nos. 14, 15 and 17 be put together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that opposition amendments Nos. 14, 15 and 17 be agreed to.
—I just want to indicate to the committee that these amendments and Democrat amendment No. 16 are all about honesty and disclosure. I am all for honesty and disclosure, so I will be supporting them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like anyone to read the Hansard in the years to come and think that we think differently. This is exactly what we are all about: honesty and disclosure. We have been ensuring that the disclosure requirements are, wherever practicable, consistent with current requirements. Senator, we support what we are doing on the basis of honesty and disclosure too, but I do not think we will be voting the same way.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments 14, 15 and 17 negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 52, page 38 (lines 20 and 21), omit subclause (3), substitute:

(3) Subsection (1) does not apply if the application is made by an employer on behalf of an employee and the RSA provider is satisfied, on reasonable grounds, that the provisions of sections 1 and 51A have been complied with.
I move this amendment without discussion. It is possibly not going to get the support of the Senate, but I will move it in any case.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition will be opposing the following:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Clause 53, page 38 (line 24) to page 39 (line 16).

We seek to delete section 53 which provides for information that is to be given to employers who open accounts on behalf of employees. Our reasons for doing this are that we do not support the ability of employers to open accounts on behalf of employees. We have been very consistent about this throughout this debate. It is our belief that, under section 153 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, employers have to seek consent from employees in order to open a fund account on their behalf.

Superannuation funds provide a range of services and benefits and a good investment return to members. Those institutions that are seeking to provide RSAs are not currently proposing to make available insurance cover, for example; access to cheap home loans—that would certainly be against the banks' interests; or other services that are offered by some funds. It is concerning to the opposition that the possibility exists under the present bills for employers to enter into a commercial relationship which may be of benefit between the employer and the RSA provider, provided the employer opens RSAs for employees.

We would argue the reality of the industrial situation is such that if employees are presented with the option of either accepting an RSA or no superannuation and no job the employee will obviously take the RSA option. The government has said that these products are to be for low income earners, casual part-timers and itinerant workers. It is these workers who are in the least powerful industrial position to negotiate where their superannuation contributions are to be placed.

It is these same workers who are the very workers who need to save for their retirement through superannuation as their superannuation guarantee contributions will be relatively modest and it is one of the few ways which will ensure some stability and security in their retirement. It is therefore critical that superannuation they are able to save is in a fund that performs consistently and provides retirement benefits. But RSAs will not achieve this end.

Whilst RSAs will undoubtedly be consistent, they will be consistently performing at a rate varying somewhere between one‐half, one or two per cent below that of other funds. This will fail to produce maximum retirement benefits. I have already illustrated that the Australian Consumers Association gave some figures to our hearings about the lower interest and the resulting outcome can leave people significantly worse off.

It is difficult to see how the employer would be in a position to really consider what would be the best retirement option for an employee's superannuation savings. Why should the employer be involved in such a direct way in effectively choosing the retirement options for their employee? That is the consequence of the approach of the government. The employer is inevitably going to be more concerned about the commercial per formance of their business, as they should be. They are more likely to require an employee to join a particular RSA—and this would not be all employers, but there would certainly be some—in order to gain some commercial advantage.

You only have to ask the banks. Clearly, ANZ, National Australia, Commonwealth, et cetera, will target their business customers and they are most likely to sell products through that link with their employer who is a business customer of theirs at that point in time. They will use that commercial connection to gain the advantage in respect of that employer's employees. I do not think it will be coincidence that we will have banks—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sticking out a mile.

—Yes, it is. We will have a situation where the ANZ, for example, has a commercial relationship with an employer and co-incidentally—surprise, surprise!—all the employees who work for that employer are in the ANZ's RSAs. I am sure there will be a correlation. It will be interesting to have a look at this as it evolves over time. But there will certainly be a connection.

SPEECH.PARA: Why should the employer use what is a different set of relationships, commercial relationships? It is their business that rises or falls on their own performance, but why should that affect an employee's retirement income? So it is for these reasons that the opposition seeks to delete this section. I would ask the committee to give very serious consideration to the arguments that we have presented in respect of removing clause 53.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry has a fundamental position which we do not share. Senator Sherry seeks to effectively remove the ability of an employer to open an account on behalf of an employee. Senator Sherry has come at this in a variety of ways all through this evening.
—You've got to keep trying.

—As he says, he has to keep trying. We have had these arguments and we have gone over them at some length. The Senate has, by and large, had a consistent position through this bill. That position is based on a recognition that the government had an election promise. It is based on the commitment that a new superannuation type product is going to increase choice, and there is to be competitive neutrality between the types of superannuation products as far as practicable.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is probably the fifth or sixth time Senator Sherry has come at this in an attempt to sustain the Labor Party position and in an attempt to defeat the fundamental underlying principles of the coalition policy which we received endorsement for at the election. It is simply not correct, Senator Sherry, that employers are required to obtain consent from an employee under section 153 or other provisions of the SI(S) Act. Your fundamental position was wrong, according to my advice.

Removing the employer ability to open accounts is also at odds with the SG regime. What you are doing, as you have tried to do all evening, is trying to distort the playing field, weighing it heavily in favour of the superannuation funds in order to achieve your goal to impose undue administrative burdens on employers.

Clause 53 is based on section 158 of the SI(S) Act. It provides employers with information on which to make a decision whether an RSA meets the needs of their employees. Section 158 of the SI(S) Act requires a public office superannuation fund to provide information to the employer before they become a standard employer sponsor of the fund—that is, open an account on behalf of their employees. This allows the employer to make a decision about the fund and whether it meets the needs of the employees.

The Labor Party is trying to remove the equivalent requirement from the RSA bill. Employers will not have the opportunity to make this decision, thereby opening an RSA or even providing the choice of an RSA, which the employer may not have made if they were provided with information before opening the account.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that clause 53 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Clause 54, page 39 (lines 18 to 21), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) If a person becomes the holder of an RSA as the result of an application referred to in subsection 53(1), the RSA provider must, as soon as practicable after first providing the RSA:

PARA.TAB: (a) inform the person that he or she may choose to maintain the RSA or have his or her superannuation contributions paid into another superannuation fund of his or her choice; and
(b) provide the person with an information statement that complies with subsection 51(2A) and any determination made under subsection 51(3) for the purposes of subsection 51(2A); and
(c) provide any other prescribed information to the person.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to expand and replace the provision relating to documents to be given to employees when they become a holder of an RSA. This allows, at the point of entry into an RSA, for the RSA provider to inform the person that he or she may choose to maintain the RSA or to have his or her superannuation contributions paid into another fund. We think that at least the last vestiges of choice might be maintained by this substitution. I commend it to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party supports Democrat amendment No. 17 for the reasons that have been outlined by Senator Allison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —To assist the brevity of this debate, we are opposing the Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party will oppose clause 54 in our amendment No. 19. We seek to delete section 54, which outlines the documents to be given to employees when an employer opens an RSA on their behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been consistent in our approach on this issue, as Senator Kemp has acknowledged. We do not find it acceptable that employers can open an RSA on behalf of an employee. As a consequence, it is certainly our intention to remove the ability of the employer to open an RSA on behalf of an employee. There is no requirement for employers to provide documentation to employees. It is the view of the opposition that it should be the sole decision of the individual to open an RSA.

I will paraphrase because I am aware of the time, so I will not go through all our arguments. As I have previously stated, we believe that currently employers have to gain an employee's consent to open a superannuation fund account on behalf of the employee. For all the reasons we have already outlined, we believe that superannuation funds are a far better vehicle through which to save for retirement. We are concerned that should the employer retain the ability to open an RSA on behalf of an employee—this remains in the bill—a number of situations will arise when employees are forced into low growth, low return products in order for the employer to reap a commercial advantage.

In the late 1980s and early 1990s the Industrial Relations Commission arbitrated a number of disputes in relation to employers choosing superannuation funds that were not the preferred choice of the employees. The opposition believes that it is critical to ensure that a similar legal mess does not arise under the RSA regime. We believe that the industrial relations coverage in respect of superannuation has worked well. Currently, awards provide either for a choice of fund or, specifically, a particular fund into which superannuation contributions must be paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that clause 54 should stand as printed. I urge the Democrats to support the government in this position, because the amendment will work strongly towards achieving the opposition objective, which all evening has been to prevent an employer opening an account on behalf of the employee. That is essentially what Senator Sherry is seeking to achieve with this.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is that the Democrats are comfortable with the employer opening an account on behalf of the employee. We would urge them to support the government. If Senator Sherry can achieve this goal, the fact is that a fundamental principle of the bill is undermined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly not comfortable with the proceedings so far. The Democrats will support this opposition to clause 54.
—It is my intention to vote no to the forthcoming motion.
—The question is that clause 54 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20) Clause 60, page 42 (lines 12 to 18), omit subclause (2).

This amendment will remove the ability of an employer to make contributions to the RSA of an employee after opening the RSA on behalf of the employee. We have stated that we do not support the government's position of allowing employers to open accounts on behalf of employees. We believe that this policy position does not meet the government's position to provide greater choice in the superannuation product market for employees and consumers.

The government's RSA bills provide choice for the employer. We think this is a ridiculous approach. It is the employee choice—that is the person who should make the choice. In supporting this concept of choice, we believe the choice has to be informed, free and effective. We hear this continual rhetoric from the government about choice, but what about informed choice, free choice and effective choice? They are the imperatives that underline real choice. This is about real choice.

We do not believe the government is interested in providing real choice to employ ees. If the government were serious about providing choice, this would be a product designed for employees rather than a product designed for employers. Why is the product so fundamentally designed around employers?

Under section 62, the government would allow an employer to open an account on behalf of an employee and then automatically begin contributing into that account. As I have said, certainly in this case we find this a ridiculous situation. The situation could and would undoubtedly arise—should an employer remain capable of opening an account on behalf of an employee—of that employee not even knowing that they have an RSA. That seems to be ridiculous. They are receiving contributions into it.

This could leave the employee in an untenable position. It would be a very brave employee who goes to their employer after the employer has paid the money in without the employee's permission and says, `Sorry, I do not want the RSA. Please redirect my contributions elsewhere.' I suggest that commonsense would dictate that most employers would simply say, `It is there. You may as well leave it there.'

The situation could arise where a casual worker may be put into several different RSAs as a result of having different employers. It is not uncommon for a casual employee to have two or three different jobs at the same—a hotel, a restaurant and a retail job in the same week—and the employer, without the employee's permission, could put money into three different RSA products. That is something that will occur quite frequently.

The government is defeating its own rationale with this approach. Supposedly this is about simplification. If the employee is in an ANZ RSA account, how do they on the government's approach end up in three different RSAs? Because the employer is putting money in before the employee gives authority. It is going to lead to an extremely messy situation.
Senator Kemp, rather than enhancing a cohesion, I submit that when we look back on this legislation in three or five years time, if we are in this place—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will still be here I reckon.

—I hope to be here, yes. But when we look back and reflect, my prediction is that RSAs will lead to a multiplicity of accounts for the sort of reason I have just outlined. Because of the changing nature of the work force, it is very common for an employee to have two or three jobs at the one time and it is happening with increasing frequency. This is going to lead to an absurd position.

BREAK.PARA: Most employees are not informed about and are not particularly well educated about these superannuation choices that the government is giving them. When they find they are in three RSAs accounts and the employer has already been paying the money in, what do they do? I would submit that it is going to be very messy. It will exacerbate the already difficult situation we have with multiple accounts. The government by this approach is adding to this problem.

The people who will be worst affected will be casual and part-time employees. These are the low income employees who can ill afford to be in two or three different RSAs accounts unknowingly because the employer has put them there. They tend to be in the service sector. I know Senator Harradine has had extensive experience in the service sector, like myself. They were different sectors, but Senator Harradine is aware of the practical problems that exist at the workplace level.

It is not uncommon for people to have more than one job. When I go back to my old workplace at Wrest Point—where I started and where work is pretty regular—and talk to the people there, the majority of casual employees often comment to me, `I am working at the Doctor Syntax Hotel, the Downtowner and at Wrest Point as well.' They could well end up in different RSA products without them knowing because the employer has put them in a product because he has struck a deal with his bank.

I know we have made some of these points on previous occasions in this debate, but with some aspects of this legislation, at least, there is going to be some very messy situations that will hurt hardest the casual, the lower paid, the part-time, the itinerant workers who have not got a lot of money going into super. Often these people are in the position of least bargaining power and are the least well educated about how to make an effective choice.

I urge the Senate to strongly consider Labor's position in respect of how money is to be held. I just cannot conceive why employers should be putting money into people's accounts without their knowledge—and probably into more than one account—in respect of the sort of work the government says this legislation is designed for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —To make a general point, I think all your amendments were designed to be an integrated whole and, as a result of what has happened, you have actually achieved a very perverse result from your own point of view. We will obviously have to address that when the bill comes back. My advice is that the effect of deleting clauses 53 and 54 is that the RSA provider will not be required to give any information before it opens an account on behalf of an employee. A very perverse result has resulted from the way this bill has been conducted; I dare say it will have to come back to this chamber to get that fixed up. I just flag that with you. I think you have achieved, in the earlier amendment, the absolute reverse of what you were seeking to achieve. I think this is part of the problem. The way the amendments have flowed, you have been able to get some up and not others.
—Not enough.

—The initial advice is that it has actually produced the reverse result of what you wanted, but I guess we can discuss that later and get that fixed up. We are not supporting the amendment you have moved. Your amendment to clause 60 flows from your opposition policy position to essentially prevent an employer from opening an account for an employee. You have fought that all night. We have opposed that all night. We think we have a mandate and you are unwilling to accept that. If the amendment is carried and the employer can be liable under the SG regime twice, that of course is a double dip in jeopardy. The subclause provides protection for SG money which is inadvertently accepted by an RSA provider who has had their approval as an RSA institution revoked or suspended and is therefore not allowed to accept contributions or where there is a notice under clause 181 not to accept money from an employer. Without this subclause these employers may be forced to pay the superannuation guarantee charge even though they made every attempt to pay the SG levy on time. We strongly oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Clause 61, page 43 (line 6), omit "14 days", substitute "28 days".

This amendment relates to the cooling‐off period where an employer applies for an RSA and paragraph 2 under clause 61 provides for the employee being able at the end of 14 days to provide written notice that he or she wants to close the RSA and transfer the balance to another provider. We do not believe that 14 days is adequate. Our amendment would change that to 28 days. I think 14 days is a very short period in which to provide such a notice, and, especially given that our other amendments, which would have put in place statements regarding the sorts of choices that employees ought to have in making this decision, have been not agreed to by the government, we think this is double the reason, if you like, for increasing that period to 28 days.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this. I just ran through the sort of scenario that could occur for casual part‐time workers who are working in two or three workplaces and are in two or three different RSA accounts—and did not know they were in them, because the employer put them in there. We have not been able to convince the Senate of that argument, but surely workers are entitled to a little more than 14 days to discover they are in accounts that they did not know they were in, and to be able to take some effective action. Surely, 28 days is not an unreasonable period.

BREAK.PARA: There are casual and part‐time workers who do not go back to work within two weeks. Sometimes they might work at a place at the beginning of the month. They might be working at two or three casual jobs at the one time. I have had very extensive experience in this because I worked in the industry and represented it for a long period. Suppose they are in an RSA product at the beginning of the month because they are with employer X. They have got one or two other casual jobs and they come back to employer X at the end of the month. They may discover that they are in an RSA product they did not know they were in, because the employer had paid the money, and they cannot get out because 14 days has expired.

I would have thought 28 days as the cooling‐off period would be a much more reasonable approach, given what Labor believes will be the practical difficulties that will be encountered by many employees in implementing this sort of concept in some of the very difficult employment scenarios that we have outlined.

I should indicate at this stage, in the hope that the cooling‐off period will be extended from 14 days to 28 days, that it would be inconsistent to proceed with our next amendment to delete the entire cooling‐off period—but we were doing that for other reasons. We will not be proceeding with that and we will be supporting this amendment of the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this amendment is eminently reasonable, and I would hope the government would agree to this particular amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry appears to have been misinformed. The 14 days commences when the consumer receives the disclosure information from the RSA provider. Fourteen days is consistent again with the SI(S) Act and the Insurance Contracts Act. It is consistent with the financial system standards generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, we see this constant suggestion that the standards and regulations which apply elsewhere should not apply in relation to RSAs and they should be weighted against the RSAs. I repeat: the 14 days commences when the consumer receives the information. That at least should give you some comfort about the point you made. I repeat that the 14 days is consistent with the SI(S) Act and the Insurance Contracts Act. I urge the Senate to reject the amendment that has been moved by the Australian Democrats.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will judge and determine the date on which the employee receives that information? What will determine the receipt? It obviously will not go by registered mail. Presumably there is some sort of way to verify the date the employer sends it out. It would otherwise be impossible to determine the date of receipt by the employee unless, as I say, there is some sort of very complex process of registration, which we all want to avoid.
—It is a good question and I have sought some advice. The case law in this issue suggests that it is three days from the time of mailing. A reasonable time is provided for postage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That confirms my fears. I am not surprised at your response. I have dealt with what I have said are some real life problems where a person who ends up in two or three RSAs unknowingly—and I accept your case law. They may receive a letter saying they are in an RSA product that they did not know they were in, and this might happen on two or three occasions because they have had two or three different jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: People have come to me with statements from existing funds, both industry funds and employer funds, and they have not understood them on many occasions. Is it reasonable to expect that most people would act on that correspondence within 14 days? These are people who may not be well educated, may not understand what has been sent to them. I submit that real life people will be in those circumstances. Is it reasonable that they would act within 14 days? I think 14 days is unreasonably tight and that 28 days is better.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Kemp keeps making the point that we are attempting different approaches, different requirements—in some cases more onerous requirements—than those with respect to other products. To some extent that is true, because they are different products. What is unique about the effect of this is that an employee could end up in a number of products without their knowledge when their employer pays the money in. That is one of the reasons why we have had to take a slightly tougher, more radical approach on occasions. I just do not think 28 days in those sorts of scenarios is an unreasonable approach. I do not know whether there is any leniency in the government on just one provision. This does not seem to me to be an unreasonable ask.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the other point as well that section 3 of this clause provides that the RSA provider, having received notice that the employee wants to make that change, has 28 days to comply with the request. So it is simply asking for the same length of time to be given to an employee after receipt of documents as is provided for with the provider.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Sherry's point is well made that we are not talking here about a normal financial transaction, an insurance policy or anything else. Each of those transactions would require the instigator, if you like, to have some knowledge of what they were doing, whereas in this case, as Senator Sherry correctly points out, this may all happen without the knowledge of the employee and certainly with not much understanding in some circumstances of what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be accepting the amendment. I have stated the reason why we will not. If the arguments apply to RSAs, they apply equally to superannuation funds. So we do not accept the amendment. There was some confusion about the provider having 28 days to transfer out after the freedom is exercised. I think they are different matters.

—The question is that Democrat amendment 18 be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I have to say that from the chair here I am completely unable to decide. I will put the question again. Those in favour say aye, those against say no.
—The noes have it.
—How would I know that? The chair calls it and I cannot be clear how the numbers fall. Would someone please assist me here? Senator Harradine, can I be clear how you are voting?

—Thank you, Madam Acting Chair, I had previously stated that it was an eminently reasonable request. I am surprised that the government is not going to support it. I am going to support the amendment.
—Thank you, Senator Harradine. I am sorry, I was not here earlier to hear that. Senator Colston, can I have an indication, please?
—I have said twice already I voted no.
—I beg your pardon, Senator. Again, I was not aware of that. I presume that means the vote is negatived.
—We will now turn to opposition amendment 21.
—We have withdrawn that.
—That is withdrawn, so we move to opposition amendments 22 to 25.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 68, page 52 (line 5), omit "and misleading", substitute ", improper and misleading".
(23) Clause 68, page 52 (line 11), omit "and 73", substitute ", 73 and 76A".
(24) Clause 73, page 54 (line 11), omit "or 72", substitute ", 72 or 76A".

PARA.TAB: Note: The heading to clause 73 is altered by omitting "or 72 ", and substituting ", 72 or 76A ".

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Page 56 (after line 15), after clause 76, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 76A Improper conduct in the provision of RSAs

SPEECH.PARA: (1) An RSA provider, or an associate of an RSA provider, must not:

PARA.TAB: (a) supply, or offer to supply, goods or services;
(b) supply, or offer to supply, goods or services at a particular price; or
(c) give or allow, or offer to give or allow, a discount, allowance, rebate or credit in relation to the supply or proposed supply of goods or services by the corporation;

on the condition that the person, or one or more of the employees of the person, to whom the RSA provider supplies or offers or proposes to supply the goods or services, will hold, or has applied or agreed to hold, an RSA provided by the RSA provider.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) An RSA provider, or an associate of an RSA provider, must not refuse:

PARA.TAB: (a) to supply goods or services to a person;
(b) to supply goods or services at a particular price to a person; or
(c) to give or allow a discount, allowance, rebate or credit in relation to the supply of goods or services to a person;
for the reason that the person, or one or more of the employees of that person, does not hold, or has not applied or agreed to hold, an RSA provided by the RSA provider.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) A contravention of subsection (1) or (2) is not an offence, but it may give rise to civil liability under section 73.

Again, I will paraphrase in the interests of time. Firstly, in respect of our amendment 22, we propose to insert the word `improper' into section 68 of part 7 of the bill. This will have the effect of ensuring that civil liability may arise in situations where the RSA provider has behaved in an improper manner. The impropriety that this amendment intends to catch is contained in our amendment 25, which seeks to insert a new clause in the bill that prohibits third line forcing.

Labor is concerned that the situation may arise where the RSA provider may offer a range of inducements to encourage employers to open RSAs on behalf of employees. We had some debate on this earlier. We did carry earlier, and I do thank the Senate for supporting it, a provision that said:

BREAK.PARA: An RSA provider must not enter into any interest offset arrangements or combination of counter arrangements with any employer who, or constitutional corporation which, has established an RSA.

This approach in respect of these amendments is entirely consistent with what was carried earlier and, as Senator Kemp pointed out, he did not want it carried earlier but it was carried. He thought this was the appropriate place and I hope that you, Senator Kemp, will at least consistently approach the position and accept that a proposition of this type should be put in. So this is the effect of opposition amendments 22 to 25. As I said earlier, the Bankers Association told the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that inducements were a normal practice for financial institutions. We have made the point time and time again that these accounts are for the benefit of the employee, not the employer, who may be induced by some relationship with their particular financial institution. We have been over this extensively.

In regard to amendment 23, we extend the objects of the part to ensure that civil liability extends to section 76A. As I have already explained, we believe it would be improper for an employer to open an account on behalf of an employee. The employee must have the liability to action a civil liability claim if that person believes the employer has engaged in improper conduct. I have referred to what might occur with an improper relationship with the financial institution.

Amendment 24 seeks to extend clause 73 so that an individual can bring a civil liability action under clause 73 where our proposed section 76 has been contravened. Our amendment 25 is a new clause which defines what would constitute improper conduct on behalf of an RSA provider and it ensures that a contravention of the section may give rise to civil liability action. Again, paraphrasing because of time, this section defines improper conduct to include the provision of goods or services and the offer to supply goods or services or the allowing of a discount, allowance, rebate or credit in relation to the supply, or proposed supply, of goods or services to a person or corporation where a condition is that one or more of the employees becomes a holder of an RSA.

We contend that this sort of behaviour by the employer—entering into some sort of financial relationship with the financial institution—is fundamentally improper and unfair to the interests of the employee. We believe it is unethical for an employer to be involved in such conduct and that, under this legislation, it should be very clearly outlawed. I hope that Senator Kemp is not going to say, `Look, this is tilting the level playing field the other way.' Other forms of superannuation saving have a trustee governing them. They cannot enter into improper relationships because it is the duty of the trustee to act in the best interests of the members of the fund.

With RSAs, it is a different type of product. It is the duty of the bank to make a profit. As many members as can be are signed up to RSAs through employers and, in most instances, it is arguably the duty of employers to make a profit. They can form a financial relationship to their advantage with their financial institution, which does not advantage the employee, and above all else—as Senator Harradine and other speakers in this debate have alluded to—it is the interests of the employee that must be protected from improper behaviour, which is ethically unsound and insupportable. That is the effect of opposition amendments 22 to 25.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats will support the opposition's amendments. They are, in fact, identical to Democrats amendments 19 to 21 and 24. What they seek to do is to fix a hole in section 47 of the Trade Practices Act which was very clearly identified by the Australian Consumers Association during the inquiry—indeed, they called it third line forcing.

SPEECH.PARA: What is quite clear is that the act will not prevent banks from offering employers an incentive to herd their employees into RSAs even if those RSAs are not in the employees' interests. This provision, which was drafted by the ACA lawyers, will outlaw such conduct and make it very clear that this is what is intended. The Democrats strongly support these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of points to follow up those made by Senator Sherry. I would like to put them in the context of the comparison between what RSAs have to offer to potential members, or potential clients, and what the industry super schemes have to offer. When the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) talks about choice, it is entirely appropriate to compare the types of benefits that are being offered by the two different approaches.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that what is offered to members of industry super funds is far more than the actual contribution that is being made by the employer. By virtue of the fact that trustees are required to act in the best interests of the members, a whole range of benefits have been developed around the industry super schemes. Some of those benefits include: the provision of financial services; the provision of death and disability cover insurance; and the provision of access, by virtue of membership, to other financial services, including home loan services. All of these services do not cost the members of the industry super schemes one cent more. They come as part of the package of being a member of that scheme.

Comparatively, what RSAs have to offer is quite inferior. Unless these amendments are supported, we could actually have the situation where the only group that benefits from any subsidiary benefit, as a result of these contributions being made into an account on behalf of an employee, will be the employers because it will go directly to the employers, and it will go to employers in the form of incentives. Perhaps the incentive will be a slightly lower rate for a commercial loan. Perhaps it will be some sort of deal based on accounts. Perhaps it will go back to the issue that we discussed earlier with respect to offset interest rate accounts. Perhaps the banks will say, `If you open 12 RSA accounts with us, you get this bonus.'

I do not know how they will package it, but, unless these amendments are supported here this evening, we are in the very real danger of voting to allow a direct transfer of subsidiary benefits for employees to go from the employee to the employer. I believe what is being proposed here this evening represents a very serious breach of equity.

I do not need to refer too often to Senator Kemp's rhetoric about choice. This issue points out, almost more clearly than any other that we have discussed in the committee stage, that we are dealing with an inferior product that cannot provide an adequate benefit. Certainly, if these amendments are not passed, there will be a specific inferior benefit and a transfer of benefit from the employees to the employers.

Senator Harradine has consistently made the point throughout the committee stage of this debate that this is workers' money. The employers will be directly benefiting by virtue of the fact that they have arranged for workers' money to go into a specific account. If that is not unfair, then I do not know what Senator Kemp will attempt to define as fair and not fair. I do not believe that this bill has too much in it that is fair. But, unless the government supports these amendments, it will blatantly be unfair in favour of the employer against the employee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We will oppose opposition amendments 19 to 25. They are too broad—
—Use a technicality.

—Senator, you have had your turn; I can have mine. We know you are opposed to RSAs. All through the evening you have attempted to sink RSAs. We understand that, but we do not share your philosophy. You will have to bear with me while I make my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments are too broad because we believe they prevent an individual who is an RSA holder from obtaining discounts on ordinary banking products. I do not know whether that is the intention, but that is the advice I have. This arises because references to `person' cover more than just employers. Of course, industry funds can offer deals and benefits to their members, but a bank customer holding an RSA will not be eligible for any commercial incentives offered by the bank. That is what you are seeking. It is inconsistent with the view that you hold on industry funds. It represents yet another attempt to try to advantage other types of products at the expense of RSAs.

I have explained to you what industry funds can offer. I do not know whether you object to that or not. Do you? You do not appear to, but then again you do not think that RSAs should be able to offer it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, earlier this evening I asked you whether or not an employer could enter into an arrangement that was similar to the product, like the mortgage interest saver account that the Commonwealth Bank provides, on the basis that that employer had employees with RSAs at that bank.

SPEECH.PARA: You said yes, so to me that indicates that what we were talking about then in that context and again here is that employers can benefit from having RSA accounts at a particular bank. So please do not cast aspersions as to the point of view that I am expressing. This deals specifically with incentives offered to employers, not employees. I do not believe you are correct in your interpretation that my view is inconsistent, because at this stage there is certainly an opportunity for employers to gain some benefit unless this amendment is passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with what Senator Sherry said. These amendments are consequential to the one that we carried. I think the minister admitted that undue pressure could be applied and that circumstances could arise where the benefits of the investment of workers' funds in RSAs could go to the employers rather than to those to whom it was designed to go. This matter was raised in Senate committee hearings. I do not see why the government cannot agree with this on the basis of freedom of choice. It should be the freedom of choice of the worker rather than the freedom of choice of the employer.

SPEECH.PARA: In division—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman—I understand, I suspect many other senators do not—under standing order 99 maybe you would indicate how you intend to vote.
—I have already voted, Senator Crowley. I have voted no.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Conroy did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

BREAK.PARA: (Senator Denman did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 73, page 54 (line 13), after "damage", insert ", or seek such relief as the Court considers appropriate,".
(23) Clause 75, page 55 (line 15), after "damage", insert ", or seek such relief as the Court considers appropriate,".

These amendments seek to provide a more level playing field on civil action taken by consumers against financial institutions on RSAs. They seek to broaden the relief that a court can provide from just compensation for loss to include other remedies; for instance, amending or ending the RSA contract, refunding all moneys in the account and so on. Amendment 25, which I will move subsequently, is an important one. It seeks to delete the due diligence defence for banks in an action on RSAs.

The Australian Consumers Association predicts that if section 168 stays, banks' lawyers will be able to use it to defeat virtually any action brought by a consumer. The due diligence defence is not available to superannuation funds. So, if we are to create a true level playing field on superannuation, banks should not be able to access this legal sledgehammer. The Senate should not encourage or facilitate inappropriate litigation practices by banks and the defeat of consumer action by a litigation by exhaustion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The broadening of the remedies is inconsistent with section 148 and 162 of the SI(S) Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the Democrats' amendments. We believe they are consistent with the approach that has been taken this evening in order to safeguard the rights of, in this case, employees who will be involved in RSA products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I also support the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that we will be opposing clause 168 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Clause 168, page 129 (line 1) to page 130 (line 10),

We are seeking to delete the due diligence defence from section 168. We had a discussion about due diligence earlier in the evening. I do not want to keep us too late this evening, but due diligence requires a provider to provide to a court that they took all reasonable steps. This step may include a reasonable mistake, reasonable reliance on information provided by another person, that the act or default was due to the action of another, or they took all reasonable steps to avoid the contravention. Given the compulsory nature of superannuation and the fact that it is specifically required to be saved to provide for an individual's retirement, it is unacceptable to Labor that a provider may avoid liability by providing that they took reasonable steps.

The SI(S) regime imposes a heavy liability on trustees to act in the best interests of members. The trustees of superannuation funds are both personally and professionally liable should something happen to the moneys in the fund. The opposition is of the view that if an RSA provider wishes to administer superannuation moneys, they must be prepared to accept the responsibilities that come with the rights to these moneys and the profit that will be made by the institutions offering them.
In the interests of brevity, I will conclude my remarks there.

TALK.START.PARA: —The due diligence defence in clause 168 of the RSA bill are identical to the due diligence defence contained in section 323 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. Similar defences are commonly used in other legislation, such as section 1011 of the Corporations Law 1989, for relief from contravention giving rise to civil liability in respect of the issuing of public documents or the issuing of products offered to the public. These provisions provide a defence to contraventions giving rise to civil liability if the person can establish that the contravention was due to such causes as a reasonable mistake or circumstances beyond the defendant's control. To deny RSA providers the benefit of this due diligence defence would be unfair and would create an unwarranted difference in the treatment of RSA providers compared to that of superannuation fund trustees.
—The question is that clause 168 stand as printed.
—Could I just indicate that I am not proceeding with the amendment that had been circularised. How's that for cooperation, Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is fantastic and I fully endorse that cooperation. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 18 March 1997. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 85 (after line 11), at the end of the Bill, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 19—Amendment of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988

PARA.TAB: Insert:

TAB.TAB: RSA has the same meaning as in the Retirement Savings Accounts Act 1997.

PARA.TAB: Insert:
(3A) Subsection (3) does not apply in relation to accounts that are RSAs.
Insert:
(4B) Subsections (2), (2A), (4) and (4A) do not apply in relation to withdrawals:

TAB.TAB: (a) made as a result of a request under paragraph 50(1)(a) of the Retirement Savings Accounts Act 1997; or
(b) made as a result of the death of the person who is the holder of the account for the purposes of the Retirement Savings Accounts Act 1997; or
(c) made under section 81, 82, 87, 194 or 195 of the Retirement Savings Accounts Act 1997; or
(d) that are used to make payments of insurance premiums in accordance with the terms and conditions of the account.

PARA.TAB: Omit "the account", substitute "an account other than an RSA".
Omit "an account", substitute "an account other than an RSA".
Add:
(8) This section does not apply in relation to a person (the employer ) in relation to an account if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the account is an RSA; and
(b) the employer made the application for the account on behalf of another person (the employee ) under section 51 of the Retirement Savings Accounts Act 1997; and
(c) the employer is the employer of the employee for the purposes of the Retirement Savings Accounts Act 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: The Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 will be amended in order to modify the signatory identification requirements of the Financial Transactions Reports Act 1988 that ordinarily apply to accounts held with financial institutions in relation to RSAs.

These amendments are necessary to facilitate the government's objective of allowing employers to open RSAs on behalf of an employee. If these amendments were not made, this would have the effect of blocking any withdrawals being made from the RSA until the RSA provider had verified the identity of the employee holding the RSA. This would not be appropriate in circumstances where, for example, an RSA holder is lost or has been transferred out of the RSA, and would also hinder the portability of the benefits from one RSA to another.

As a result of these amendments, the signatory identification requirements that would normally apply to accounts before any withdrawals can be made will only relate to RSAs to the extent that the benefits withdrawn from the RSA are cashed directly to the RSA holder or transferred to the superannuation entity. The requirement that normal signatory identification requirements apply to direct cash payments to RSA holders and transfers to superannuation entities will ensure that RSA benefits are properly maintained in the superannuation system in accordance with the retirement income standards.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1997
Bill agreed to without requests.

Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1997 and Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 reported with amendments; Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill 1997 reported without requests; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Democrats will be voting against the third reading of this bill. Is it an appropriate time to do so now?
—We will make a note of it but we had better move the third reading first.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Kemp) proposed:
That the bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that we will be voting against the third reading of the legislation. Time and time again during this debate this evening we have moved a series of constructive amendments to deal with what we believe were serious deficiencies in the government's approach in respect of retirement savings legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give a few examples of our amendments that were defeated during the committee stage. We moved a very important amendment with Democrat support—we appreciate this—and with the support of Senator Harradine and the Greens in respect of a division, that fees and charges could not reduce the balance of accounts and, indeed, could not be charged by the financial institutions which seek to offer RSAs. A further amendment, which we thought was eminently reasonable and relatively small in the context of the issues being considered, was to ensure that a bank or other financial institution would not hold the moneys for up to 12 months. We sought to substitute 28 days.

Time and time again, Labor has attempted to ensure that it is not the employer that offers the RSA. It is the fundamental choice of the employee. The last division we had concerned third line forcing. Earlier in the evening we were able to have passed one important amendment which stated:
An RSA provider must not enter into any interest off‐set arrangements or combination account arrangements with any employer who, or constitutional corporation which, has established an RSA.

Yet, unfortunately, when we came to further amendments on the problem of third line forcing the government did not accept, and indeed voted against, what we believe were eminently reasonable amendments to protect employees. The central issue of debate here is that this is employees' money and it is not reasonable for employers to impose—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not after the banks have finished with it.

—Exactly. It is not reasonable to allow an employer to control the destiny of an employee's in many cases life savings, which are definitely for retirement purposes and are compulsory savings. We have taken a positive approach.
